column4: BGP/6/BGP_PEER_DOWN_PERIOD_REPORT: Logs are recorded periodically after the BGP neighbor goes Down. (BgpIndex=[BgpIndex], InstanceId=[InstanceId], AddrFamilyAfi=[AddrFamilyAfi], AddrFamilySafi=[AddrFamilySafi], PeerAddrType=[PeerAddrType], PeerIpv4Ipv6Addr=[PeerIpv4Ipv6Addr], LocalIfIndex=[LocalIfIndex], LocalIfName=[LocalIfName], PeerLastError=[PeerLastError], PeerState=[PeerState], ReasonIndex=[ReasonIndex])
column5: Logs are periodically recorded after the BGP peer relationship is interrupted.

column1: [InstanceId]ID of a VPN instance.
[AddrFamilyAfi]Address family: 1: ipv4 2: ipv6 25: vpls 196: l2vpn 16388: link-state 36879: rpd

[AddrFamilySafi]Sub-address family: 1: unicast 2: multicast 3: Unicast & multicast 4: mpls 5: mvpn 65: vpls 66: mdt 70: evpn 71: link-state 73: srpolicy 74: sdwan 128: vpn 129: vpnv4 multicast 132: vpn orf 133: flowv4 134: flowvpn 179: rpd 245: tunnel-encap-ext 255: mvrf
[PeerAddrType]Address type of a peer.
[PeerIpv4Ipv6Addr]Address of a peer. Only IPv6 addresses are reported in this alarm.
[LocalIfIndex]Index of the local interface.
[LocalIfName]Name of the local interface.

[PeerLastError]Error code when the peer was disconnected last time. The value of this parameter is displayed in the format of [ErrorCode][ErrorSubCode], where [ErrorCode] indicates the error code and [ErrorSubCode] indicates the error subcode. For example, 35, where 3 indicates an error code and 5 indicates an error subcode. For details about error codes, see BGP Message Format in BGP Fundamentals. If this parameter is set to 0, no error occurs.
[PeerState]Status of the peer.

[ReasonIndex]Index of the reason why the peer is disconnected. 1: The peer relationship is torn down due to configurations. 2: A Notification message is received. 3: An error message is received. 4: The Hold timer expires. 5: The remote peer is unreachable. 6: The directly connected interface is Down. 7: The number of routes reaches the upper limit. 8: The system memory is overloaded.
Cause 1: The BGP peer relationship is disconnected due to BGP configurations.
Cause 2: BGP received a Notification message.
Cause 3: BGP received an error message.
Cause 4: The BGP hold timer expires.
Cause 5: The BGP remote end is unreachable.
Cause 6: The BGP directly connected interface is disconnected.
Cause 7: The number of BGP routes exceeds the upper limit.
Cause 8: The system memory is overloaded.
Cause 1: The BGP peer relationship is disconnected due to BGP configurations.
1. Check whether the neighbor relationship is disconnected due to its own configuration.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Cancel the configuration that causes the disconnection of the neighbor relationship.
3. Check whether the BGP connection is reset. Wait for a while and check whether the connection is restored.
4. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 2: BGP received a Notification packet.
1. Run the display bgp peer ip-address log-info command to check the Notification messages generated when BGP is disconnected.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 4, the BGP Holdtimer expires and no Keepalive packet is received. Go to Step 3.
�If the error code of the Notification packet is 5, an error occurs on the BGP FSM. Go to Step 17.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 6, BGP proactively closes the connection. Go to Step 2.
2. Run the display bgp peer ip-address log-info command to check whether the notification is sent by the device that generates the alarm.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the ping command to check whether the IP address of the BGP peer can be pinged.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Check whether the CPU usage is too high. The command varies according to the device.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to Step 6.
5. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the BGP peer address routing table exists.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If no, go to Step 8.
6. Run the display acl command to check whether the ACL that denies TCP port 179 is configured on the device.
�If yes, go to to delete the ACL that denies TCP port 179.
�If no, go to Step 9.
7. Run the display interface command to check whether the outbound interface of the route is Up.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to Step 10.
8. Check the origin of the route to the BGP peer address.
�If the route source is OSPF, go to Step 11.
�If the route source is IS-IS, go to Step 12.
9. Check the BGP configuration to see whether the loopback interface is used to establish the BGP connection.
�If so, go to Step 13.
�If no, go to Step 14.
10. Check whether the shutdown command is run on the interface.
�If yes, go to step to run the undo shutdown command on the interface. - If the alarm persists, go to Step 13.
�If no, go to Step 17.
11. Run the display ospf peer command to check whether the OSPF peer relationship is established.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to. For details, see the handling procedure of OSPF_1.3.6.1.2.1.14.16.2.2 ospfNbrStateChange.
12. Run the display isis peer command to check whether the IS-IS peer is set up.

�If no, go to. For details, see the handling procedure of ISIS_1.3.6.1.3.37.2.0.17 isisAdjacencyChange.
13. Check whether the source address used to initiate a BGP connection is specified.

�If not, run the peer connect-interface command to specify the source address used to initiate the BGP connection.
14. If the BGP peer is an EBGP peer and multiple hops exist between EBGP peers, check whether the peer ebgp-max-hop command is configured.
�If so, go to Step 15.
�If not, run the peer ebgp-max-hop command.
15. If the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command is configured, check whether the TTL of the packet received from the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.
�If so, go to Step 16.
�If not, run the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command to ensure that the TTL of the packets sent to the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.

16. Contact the maintenance personnel of the peer device to check whether BGP is reset on the peer device, whether the peer is enabled in another address family on the local device, or whether BGP connection parameters are set.
�If the preceding operations are performed, wait for a while and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 17.
17. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 3: BGP received error packets.

column5: The number of NSSA LSAs generated when an OSPF process imported external routes exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.

column1: [hwOspfv2AreaId]Indicates the ID of an OSPF area.
[hwOspfv2Threshold]Indicates the upper alarm threshold for the number of NSSA LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes.
The number of NSSA LSAs generated when an OSPF process imported external routes exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.

1. Run the display ospf brief command to check whether the number of NSSA LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.
�If the number exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If the number has not exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, go to Step 2.
Check the overload status based on the value of the Current status field in the display ospf brief command output.
�Normal: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes is less than or equal to the lower alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.
�Approach limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes is approaching (reaching or exceeding 90% of) the upper alarm threshold.
�Exceed limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes has reached or exceeded the maximum number allowed.
2. Perform the following operations as required:

�If a change in the limit on the number of NSSA LSAs is allowed, run the import-route limit <limit-number> [ threshold-alarm upper-limit <upper-limit-value> lower-limit <lower-limit-value> ] command to change the limit.
�If a change in the limit on the number of NSSA LSAs is not allowed, go to Step 3.
3. Contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

column4: EAIRP/4/hwResTrendPredOverThres_active: Resource trend predict will exceed threshold under current circumstance. (ChassisId=[ChassisId], SlotId=[SlotId], Object=[Object], ReasonId=[ReasonId], ReasonDesc=[ReasonDesc]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

�Cause 1: Memory-usage trend predict over threshold 80%.
�Cause 2: The ARPs trend predict over threshold 80%.
�Cause 3: ND table used number trend predict over threshold 80%.
�Cause 4: ND prefix table used number trend predict over threshold 80%.
�Cause 1: Memory-usage trend predict over threshold 80%.
Check the memory usage and services. You can run the display memory-usage slot <slot-id> command to check the memory usage of a specified board.
�Cause 2: The ARPs trend predict over threshold 80%.

Check the ARP resource usage and services. You can run the display arp all command to check ARP entry information on the device and run the display arp statistics slot <slot-id> command to check ARP entry statistics on a specified board.
�Cause 3: ND table used number trend predict over threshold 80%.
Check the usage of ND entries and services. You can run the display ipv6 neighbors statistics slot <slot-id> command to check the usage of ND entries on a specified board.
�Cause 4: ND prefix table used number trend predict over threshold 80%.
Check the usage of the ND prefix table and services. You can run the display ipv6-nd <slot-id> statistics command to check the usage of the ND prefix table on a specified board.

(hwPtpPortOldSourcePortNum=[hwPtpPortOldSourcePortNum], hwPtpPortSourcePortNum=[hwPtpPortSourcePortNum], hwPtpOldPortName=[hwPtpOldPortName], hwPtpPortName= [hwPtpPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

[hwPtpOldPortName]The port name of the old tracing source.
[hwPtpPortName]The port name of the current tracing source.
The synchronization source of the NE is changed.
1. Check whether the source switchover is caused by the configuration information. If yes, modify the configuration information or do not perform any operation.
2. Ensure that the physical interface connected to the external clock source is in the Up state.
3. Ensure that PTP packets are sent and received correctly.
4. Ensure the networking environment and related services, and support IEEE 1588v2 time synchronization.
5. If the switchover is abnormal, contact maintenance personnel to locate the fault.
6. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

column4: TRUNK/3/hwExtAllMemberDownNotify_active: The last member interface link status changes to down. (TrunkIfIndex=[ifIndex], TrunkName=[ifName])
column5: The last member interface of an Eth-Trunk interface in static LACP mode went Down.

column1: [ifName]Name of the Trunk interface
All the member interfaces of the Eth-Trunk interface in static LACP mode were Down.
1. Run the display this command in the trunk interface view to check whether the interface is shut down.
�If the interface is shut down, go to Step 2.
�If the interface is not shut down, go to Step 3.
2. Run the undo shutdown command in the trunk interface view and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display this command in the view of each trunk member interface to check whether the member interface is shut down.
�If a member interface is shut down, go to Step 4.
�If no member interface is shut down, go to Step 5.
4. Run the undo shutdown command in the view of the trunk member interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Check whether the physical link is properly connected, including whether hardware such as the network cable or optical module is properly inserted.
�If the link is properly connected, go to Step 7.
�If the link is not properly connected, go to Step 6.
6. Properly connect the physical link and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
7. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
8. End.

column4: OSPF/6/NBR_CHANGE: Neighbor changes event: neighbor status changed. (ProcessId=[ProcessId], NbrIpAddr=[NbrIpAddr], Interface=[InterfaceName], NbrEvent=[NbrEvent], NbrPreviousState=[NbrPreviousState], NbrCurrentState=[NbrCurrentState],CpuUsage=[CpuUsage], AreaId=[AreaId])
column5: The event that neighbor status changed was received.

column1: [NbrIpAddr]IP address of the neighbor
[InterfaceName]Interface name

[NbrEvent]Event that cause neighbor status change: 0: HelloReceived: indicates that a Hello packet is received from the neighbor. 1: Start: indicates that the NBMA interface will send Hello packets to the neighbor at intervals specified by the HelloInterval field. 2: 2WayReceived: indicates that the two ends can communicate with each other. 3: NegotiationDone: indicates that the negotiation between the two ends has been completed. 4: ExchangeDone: indicates that the two ends have exchanged complete DD packets. 5: BadLsReq: indicates that an incorrect LSR is received. 6: LoadingDone: indicates that the two ends have exchanged their databases. 7: AdjOK?: indicates whether the local end needs to establish a neighbor relationship with the peer end and maintain the neighbor relationship. 8: SequenceNumberMismatch: indicates that the sequence numbers of DD packets from the neighbor mismatch that from the local end. 9: 1Way: indicates that a 1-way Hello packet is received from the neighbor. 10: KillNbr: indicates that the neighbor is deleted. 11: LLDown: indicates that the lower-layer link between the two ends goes Down. 12: InactivityTimer: indicates that the Hold timer of the neighbor is triggered
[NbrPreviousState]Previous neighbor states: 0: Down 1: Init 2: Attempt 3: 2Way 4: ExStart 5: Exchange 6: Loading 7: Full
[NbrCurrentState]Current neighbor states: 0: Down 1: Init 2: Attempt 3: 2Way 4: ExStart 5: Exchange 6: Loading 7: Full
[CpuUsage]CPU usage

column1: [hwSubIfInputRatePercentage]Incoming traffic statistics
[hwSubIfInputRateThreshold]Incoming traffic alarm threshold.
[InterfaceName]Interface name.

The interface traffic statistics collection period can be configured. The default value is 300s. The average rate of the previous statistics collection period is calculated in every 1/6 of the statistics collection period and then divided by the interface bandwidth to obtain the interface bandwidth usage. If the interface bandwidth usage falls below the interface alarm threshold, the interface rate threshold-crossing alarm is cleared.

MPLS-OAM
column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamIgrLSPUnAva: Ingress enter unavailable state. (IfIndex=[IfIndex], TunnelName=[TunnelName], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType])
column5: OAM on the ingress detected that the LSP was unavailable.

column1: [TunnelName]Indicates the name of the tunnel.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM ingress. - 0: indicates that the ingress is available. - 1: indicates that the ingress is unavailable.

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect. - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: Cause 1: The link monitored by OAM failed.
Cause 2: An OAM configuration error occurred, which Cause d the ingress and egress to send and receive packets at different frequencies.
1. Run the display interface tunnel command to check whether the link is Up.
�If the link is Up, go to Step 2.
�If the link is Down, go to Step 3.
2. Run the display mpls oam ingress all verbose command to check the configurations. If the LSP or tunnel fails, run the display this command to check whether the MPLS OAM configuration is correct.
�If the MPLS OAM configuration is correct, go to Step 4.
�If the MPLS OAM configuration is incorrect, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display this command in the tunnel interface view to check whether the destination address, type, and ID of the TE tunnel are correctly configured.
�If they are correctly configured, go to Step 5.
�If they are not correctly configured, go to Step 4.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: L2IF/4/hwMacHopAlarm_active: Mac-hopping exist. (VlanId=[VlanId], Vsi=[vsi_name], BDId=[BD_ID], the port list of Mac-hopping = [PortName1], [PortName2], [PortName3], [PortName4], the peer list of Mac-hopping = [PeerList], DetectMac = [DetectMac], trustport = [TrustPortName], trustpeer = [TrustPeerInfo]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: MAC address flapping occurred.

column1: [vsi_name]Name of a VSI.

[PortName1]Interface on which MAC address flapping occurred.
[PortName2]Interface on which MAC address flapping occurred.
[PortName3]Interface on which MAC address flapping occurred.
[PortName4]Interface on which MAC address flapping occurred.
[PeerList]Information about the peer with MAC address flapping.
[DetectMac]Detected MAC address.
[TrustPortName]Trusted port
[TrustPeerInfo]Trusted peer
MAC address transition frequently occurred in the broadcast domain. A Layer 2 loop may exist.

1. Check the configuration of the interface corresponding to the flapping MAC address to determine whether the loop is caused by incorrect configuration. (You can run the display loop-detect eth-loop hop-info command to view the more detailed flapping interface list.)

2. If the configuration is correct, check whether the cable connection of the interface corresponding to the flapping MAC address is correct and whether the loop is caused by incorrect cable connection.
3. Enable the MAC address flapping function to automatically block the corresponding interface.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column1: [isisSysLevelIndex]IS-IS level

[isisPduFragment]64-byte PDU header
[ifIndex]Circuit IfIndex of an interface
[IfName]Interface name
Cause 1: Authentication was configured on an interface or process of the local end, but the authentication type on the peer end was different from that on the local end.
Cause 2: Authentication was configured on an interface or process of the local end, but no authentication was configured on the peer end.
1. Obtain the IS-IS process number based on the isisSysInstance field and IS-IS packet type (1 indicates a Level-1 packet
column3: 3 indicates a P2P Hello packet) based on the isisSysLevelIndex field. Then, find the isisPduFragment field and obtain the system ID of the source device that sends the packet and packet type.

column1: �If the packet type is Hello, go to Step 2.
�If the packet type is LSP or SNP, go to Step 4.

2. Determine the IS-IS interface of the source device based on the system ID, and then run the display this command in the view of the IS-IS interface on the source device to check whether the configured interface authentication mode is consistent with that configured on the local device.
�If the interface authentication modes on the two ends are the same, go to Step 6.
�If the interface authentication modes on the two ends are different, go to Step 3.

3. Run the isis authentication-mode command in the interface view of the source device to configure the authentication mode to be the same as that on the local device, and ensure that the authentication passwords on the two ends are the same. Then, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 7.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 6.

4. Run the display current-configuration configuration isis command on the source device to check whether the area authentication mode or domain authentication mode configured in the IS-IS process is the same as that on the local device, and ensure that the authentication passwords on the two ends are the same.
�If the authentication modes on the two ends are the same, go to Step 6.
�If the authentication modes on the two ends are different, go to Step 5.

5. Run the area-authentication-mode command (Level-1 packet) or the domain-authentication-mode command (Level-2 packet) in the IS-IS view of the source device to configure the authentication type to be the same as that of the local device. Then, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 7.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 6.
6. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

column1: [NbrIpAddress]Indicates the IP address of the neighbor.
[NbrAddressLessIndex]Indicates the interface index.
[NbrRtrId]Indicates the router ID of the neighbor.

[NbrState]Indicates the neighbor status. The trap is a service restoration trap only when the value of Full. Otherwise, it is a fault trap. 1: Down. 2: Attempt. 3: Init. 4: 2-Way. 5: ExStart. 6: Exchange. 7: Loading. 8: Full.
[ProcessId]Indicates the process ID.
[AreaId]Indicates the area ID.
[IfnetIndex]Indicates the physical interface index.
[LocalIfIpAddress]Indicates the IP address of the local interface.
[IfName]Indicates the physical interface name.
[VpnName]Indicates the VPN name.

[NbrStateChangeReason]Indicates the reason why the neighbor status changes. [1]Adjacency HoldTimer Expired. [2] Physical Interface State Change. [3] Protocol reason. [4] BFD session state change. [5] Configuration change. [6] Peer router reason. [7] Waiting for establishing neighbor. [99] Alarm clear. [101] Neighbor deleted. [102] Neighbor full. [103] Interface silent. [104] Interface deleted. [105] DR/BDR change.
[SubReason]Indicates the detailed reason. [57] Neighbor deleted. [58] Neighbor full. [59] Interface silent. [60] Interface deleted. [61] DR/BDR change. [62] Configuration change.
The status of the non-virtual neighbor has changed.
�If the possible causes are appeared, this trap message is informational only, and no action is required.

(EntPhysicalIndex=[EntPhysicalIndex], PhyscialName=[PhyscialName], MacLimitVlanId=[Vlan_ID], MacLimitVsiName=[MacLimitVsiName], MacLimitBDId=[BD_ID], MacLimitEvpnName=[evpn_name], TrapSeverity=[TrapSeverity], TrapProbableCause=[TrapProbableCause], TrapEventType=[TrapEventType], MacDynAddressLearnNum=[MacDynAddressLearnNum], MacLimitMaxMac=[MacLimitMaxMac], MacLimitUpthreshold=[MacLimitUpthreshold], MacLimitDownthreshold=[MacLimitDownthreshold]).

[Vlan_ID]VLAN ID.
[MacLimitVsiName]Name of a VSI.
[BD_ID]BD ID.
[evpn_name]EVPN name.
[TrapSeverity]NMS alarm severity.
[TrapProbableCause]Alarm cause value.
[TrapEventType]Alarm event type.
[MacDynAddressLearnNum]Number of learned MAC addresses.
[MacLimitMaxMac]Maximum number of MAC addresses.
[MacLimitUpthreshold]Indicates the upper MAC address learning limit.
[MacLimitDownthreshold]Indicates the lower MAC address learning limit.

After MAC address limit was configured and the trap function for MAC address limit was enabled, the number of learned dynamic MAC addresses exceeded the upper threshold. The number of learned dynamic MAC addresses then fell below the MAC address limit because some MAC addresses were aged. Consequently, an alarm was generated to inform the user.
This message is informational only, and no action is required.

column4: ARP/4/ARP_SPEED_LIMIT: Packet speed exceeded the configured speed limit. (IfIndex=[IfIndex], SuppressValue=[SupValue], CurrentValue=[CurValue], SuppressType=[SupType], SourceIP=[SrcIp], DestinationIP=[DstIp], VpnInstance name=[VpnName], InterfaceName=[InterfaceName])
column5: The transmit rate of ARP packets exceeded the configured rate limit.

column1: [SupValue]Rate limit of ARP packets or ARP Miss messages.
[CurValue]Current transmit rate of ARP packets or ARP Miss messages.
[SupType]Type of packets that are suppressed: ARP packets or ARP Miss messages.
[SrcIp]Source IP addresses of ARP packets or ARP Miss messages.
[DstIp]Destination IP addresses of ARP packets or ARP Miss messages.
[VpnName]VPN instances that ARP packets or ARP Miss messages belong to.
[InterfaceName]Name of an ARP interface.
Cause 1: The transmit rate of ARP packets exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 2: The transmit rate of ARP Miss messages exceeded the configured rate limit.
1. Run the display arp speed-limit command to check the rate limit of ARP packets configured on the device.

2. Run arp speed-limit destination-ip maximum <maximum> slot <slot-id> to reconfigure the ARP packet rate limit. The value must be greater than the value queried in Step 1 but cannot exceed 65536. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

column4: PIC/3/hwB3TcaAlarm_active: B3 threshold crossing alarm. (hwPhysicalPortIfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],BoardID=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardID=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortID=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],HpID=[hwSDHHpPerfCurrentHpIndex],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The number of B3 error codes in the high-order path exceeded the alarm threshold.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwSDHHpPerfCurrentHpIndex]High-order path ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
�Cause 0: The optical fiber was disconnected.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column5: PTP packets were lost.
column6: [hwPtpPktType]PTP packet type. The values are as follows: Announce(8). Sync(1). Delay_Resp(6). Pdelay_Resp(4).

column1: The Announce, Sync, and Delay_Resp packets detected on the slave interface fail to be received within a specified period.
1. Run the display ptp interface command multiple times to check whether the number of packets on the faulty interface increases normally.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 4.
2. Run the display ptp all config command on the peer device to check whether the peer interface is correctly configured. For example, check whether the packet sending rate is too low.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Adjust the PTP port configuration of the peer port, for example, adjust the packet sending rate. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If yes, go to Step 5.
�If no, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

(isisSysInstance=[isisSysInstance], isisSysLevelIndex=[isisSysLevelIndex], isisCircIndex=[isisCircIndex], isisCircIfIndex=[isisCircIfIndex], isisPduLspId=[isisPduLspId], isisPduOriginatingBufferSize=[isisPduOriginatingBufferSize], ifIndex=[ifIndex], IfName=[IfName])

The size of LSPs generated on the source device was greater than that of LSPs generated on the local device.

1. Identify the source device where the LSP was generated based on the value of the isisPduLspId field. View the size of LSPs generated on the source device and check whether it is greater than the size of LSPs generated on the local device.
�If so, go to Step 2.

2. Run the lsp-length originate command in the IS-IS process on the source device to change the size of generated LSPs to be smaller than or equal to the size of the buffer for locally generated LSPs.

column5: The ACL rules in the traffic policy are not completely delivered.
column6: [SlotId]Indicates the slot ID of a board.

column1: [Reason]Indicates the alarm cause. There are the following cases: 1. The number of configured IPv4&L2&MPLS ACL rules exceeds the maximum number that can be configured on the device. 2. The number of configured IPv6 ACL rules exceeds the maximum number of IPv6 ACL rules that can be configured on the device. 3. The number of configured IPv4&L2&MPLS&IPv6 ACL rules exceeds the maximum number that can be configured on the device.
The board resources are insufficient. As a result, the ACL rules in the policy are not completely delivered.
1. In the interface view, run the display this command to check the applied traffic policy, and then run the undo traffic-policy { inbound | outbound } command to delete unnecessary traffic policies.

2. Run the display this command in the traffic classifier view of the traffic policy to check the ACL rule configuration. Then, run the undo acl acl-number command to delete unnecessary ACL rules or run the undo rule rule-id command in the ACL view to delete unnecessary ACL rules.

3. Run the display traffic policy statistics interface interface-type interface-number { inbound | outbound } command to check whether the value of Current status is OK! and whether all policy rules are delivered.
�If yes, go to step 5.
�If no, go to step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

Cause 1: The attributes of the time source, optimal source, and local time source changed. As a result, the port status changed.
Cause 2: The link was faulty. As a result, the port status changed.
Cause 3: The device restarted. As a result, the port status changed.
1. Run the display interface brife command to check whether the interface is Down.
If yes, the link is faulty. Go to Step 5.
If no, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display this interface and display ptp-adaptive vport commands to check whether the clock attributes of the interface are modified.
If yes, the clock attribute changes. Go to step 5.
If no, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display board-reset all command in the diagnostic view to check the last restart time of the main control board and collect alarm information.
If the fault occurs after the device is restarted, the port status changes due to the device restart. In this case, go to Step 5.
If no, go to Step 4.
4. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: SOC/4/hwL3LoopDetectAlarm_active: L3 loop detect alarmed. (ChassisID=[hwL3LoopDetectChassisID], Slot=[hwL3LoopDetectSlotID], IP=[hwL3LoopDetectIPAddr]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: Layer 3 loop detection detected route loops.

column1: [hwL3LoopDetectSlotID]Board ID.
[hwL3LoopDetectIPAddr]IP address.

When a routing loop occurs, a large number of TTL timeout packets are generated on the network. If the number of TTL timeout packets sent to the CPU is greater than or equal to 6000 within 1 minute, a 1-minute timer is started for sampling and analysis. If the number of packets reaches 1024 or the number of packets exceeds 100 when the timer expires, the destination IP addresses of top 5 packets are tracerted one by one. If a routing loop exists, an alarm is generated.
1. Tracert the destination address of the route displayed in the alarm to check whether a loop occurs on the link.
�If a loop exists, remove the loop. If the alarm is cleared after the loop is removed, go to Step 3. If the alarm persists after the loop is removed, go to Step 2.
�If no loop exists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

(TrapSeverity=[TrapSeverity], ProbableCause=[ProbableCause], EventType=[EventType], PhysicalIndex=[PhysicalIndex], PhysicalName=[PhysicalName], RelativeResource=[RelativeResource], UsageType=[UsageType], SubIndex=[SubIndex], UsageValue=[UsageValue], Unit=[Unit], UsageThreshold=[UsageThreshold]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: Memory or storage usage was sampled for a period of time. In one sampling period (overload times x sampling interval), if each memory or storage usage sample exceeded the pre-set overload threshold, this alarm was generated.

column1: [ProbableCause]Trap cause.
[EventType]Alarm type
[PhysicalIndex]Physical index
[PhysicalName]Entity name
[RelativeResource]Relevant resource name

[UsageType]Overload type. The value 1 indicates the CPU. The default sampling interval is 10 seconds, and the number of overload sampling times is 48. The value 2 indicates the memory. The default sampling interval is 1 second, and the number of overload sampling times is 2. The value 3 indicates a disk. The value 4 indicates flash memory. The value 5 indicates the CF card. The value 6 indicates the physical memory.
[SubIndex]Entity sub-index
[UsageValue]Storage usage
[Unit]Unit
[UsageThreshold]Threshold
�Cause 2: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set overload threshold.
�Cause 3: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set fully loaded threshold.
�Cause 75264: The memory usage exceeded the pre-set overload threshold.
�Cause 75265: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set overload threshold. The default overload threshold is 85%.
�Cause 75268: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set fully loaded threshold. The default full load threshold is 85%.
�Cause 75269: The memory usage of one process exceeded the pre-set overload threshold. The max memory size is 3G for one process.
�Cause 75271: The forwarding CPU memory usage exceed the preset threshold.
�Cause 75272: The physical memory usage exceeded the pre-set overload threshold(total memory < 16G)
�Cause 75274: The message memory usage exceeded the overload threshold.
�Cause 2: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set overload threshold.
1. Run the cd command in the user view to enter the corresponding storage medium directory, and then run the dir command to check the storage space usage of the storage medium.
�If the storage usage of the storage medium is higher than the overload threshold, go to Step 2.
�If the storage medium usage is lower than the overload threshold, go to Step 3.
2. Delete unnecessary files to reduce the storage space usage of the storage medium. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is no longer generated, the problem is resolved.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
�Cause 3: The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set fully loaded threshold.
1. Run the cd command in the user view to enter the corresponding storage medium directory, and then run the dir command to check the storage space usage of the storage medium.
�If the storage space usage of the storage medium is higher than the full-load threshold, go to Step 2.
�If the storage medium usage is lower than the full-load threshold, go to Step 3.
2. Delete unnecessary files to reduce the storage space usage of the storage medium. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.

column4: OSPF/6/CONFLICT_ROUTERID_INTER: OSPF router ID conflict may have occurred in inter-area. (ProcessId=[ProcessId], RouterId=[RouterId])
column5: The router IDs of OSPF devices in different areas might conflict because external routes were constantly refreshed.

column1: [RouterId]Router ID.
The same router ID was configured for devices in different areas, causing route flapping.
This log is generated in the following scenarios:
�Normal scenario: Device A generates a Type 5 LSA and floods it to Device B.
Due to a fault, Device A restarts and reestablishes the neighbor relationship with Device B.
Then, Device A receives the Type 5 LSA generated by itself from Device B.
Because the router ID in the LSA conflicts with the local one, the log is generated.
A large number of Type 5 LSAs may exist in the system.
Therefore, this scenario is very common.
The log generated in this scenario requires no action.
�Conflict scenario: The same router ID is configured for devices in different areas, causing route flapping.
1. Run the ospf router-id <router-id> command to change the router ID.
2. End.

column1: [EntityType]Indicates the type of the physical entity.

The storage component on the subcard was faulty.
1. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3. Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4. If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5. If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6. If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7. If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.
8. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
9. End.

BGP
column4: BGP/4/BGPFLOWSPEC: The route [REIndex] includes conflict rules (ReasonID is [ReasonID]).
column5: The rules contained in the route whose index is REIndex conflict.

column1: [ReasonID]Conflict cause.
The conflict cause (ReasonID) is described as follows:
(1) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with the interface type and either of the source or sink interface type.
(2) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and the TCPFLAG type. No protocol type is configured.
(3) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type.
(4) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a protocol type and any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type. The protocol type is not TCP or UDP.
(5) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a protocol type and the TCPFLAG type. The protocol type is not TCP.
(6) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a protocol type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type. The protocol type is not ICMP.
(7) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a matching rule for multiple field classification that is not supported by the local device. The BGP FlowSpec route failed to be delivered.
The scenarios are as follows:
�An unsupported tcpflag rule matching type was configured.
�A rule type that does not exist was configured.
�The destination-origin-as rule was configured on a board that does not support the destination-origin-as rule or in the view of the board.
(8) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a matching rule for multiple field classification that is not in the valid range. The BGP FlowSpec route failed to be delivered.
(9) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a matching rule for multiple field classification that no packets match. The matching rule for multiple field classification was invalid.

(10) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a rule matching any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and any of the TCPFLAG, ICMPTYPE, or ICMPCODE type. The fragmented packet type is configured.
(11) The number of rules configured for the BGP FlowSpec route exceeded the upper limit supported by the hardware.
(12) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a destination-community rule, but the rule was not enabled globally. As a result, the rule did not take effect.

(13) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a destination-community rule and a rule of another type. The rules did not take effect. Rules of the destination-community type can only be configured together with rules of the source IP address type.
(14) The BGP FlowSpec route was configured with a destination-community rule, which is not supported on the current board.
1. Check whether a conflict occurs in the BGP route with the corresponding index based on the conflict cause corresponding to the index and reason ID in the log information.
2. Modify or delete the conflicting rules in the BGP routing information, and then reconfigure the routes to be sent.
3. Check whether the conflict continues to be reported in the log.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm is no longer reported, go to Step 5.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.
QOS
column4: QOS/2/hwXQoSModeChannelOverEthBnBw_active: The bandwidth sum of sliced sub-interfaces plus the actual effective SQ bandwidth of non-sliced sub-interfaces in an ETH-BN group is greater than the ETH-BN bandwidth. (group-name=[group-name], eth-bn-sub-interface=[eth-bn-sub-interface])
column5: The sum of the total bandwidth of channelized sub-interfaces in the microwave bandwidth sharing group and the actual bandwidth of non-channelized sub-interface SQs was greater than the microwave bandwidth.
column6: [group-name]Name of a microwave bandwidth sharing group.

column1: [eth-bn-sub-interface]Non-channelized sub-interface in the bandwidth group.
The bandwidth sum of sliced sub-interfaces plus the actual effective SQ bandwidth of non-sliced sub-interfaces in an ETH-BN group is greater than the ETH-BN bandwidth.
Actual effective SQ bandwidth = MIN (qos-profile user-queue PIR bandwidth, MAX (10M, microwave bandwidth - bandwidth sum of sliced sub-interfaces in the ETH-BN group)).

1. Reduce the total bandwidth of channelized sub-interfaces in the group or the configured SQ PIR of non-channelized sub-interfaces to meet the following requirement: Total bandwidth of channelized sub-interfaces + Min (10 Mbit/s, configured SQ PIR) &#xfffd
To reduce the total bandwidth of channelized sub-interfaces in the group, run the mode channel bandwidth <bwvalue> command in the interface view.

To reduce the configured SQ PIR of non-channelized sub-interfaces, run the user-queue { cir <cir-value> pir <pir-value> | cir-percentage <percentage-value> pir-percentage <percentage-value> } command to enter the view of the QoS profile applied to the non-channelized sub-interfaces.
�If the alarm is cleared 1 minute later, go to Step 3.

column4: SSH/5/SSH_USER_LOGIN_FAIL: The SSH user failed to login. (ServiceType=[ServiceType], FailedReason=[FailedReason], UserName=[UserName], UserAddress=[UserAddress], LocalAddress=[LocalAddress], VPNInstanceName=[VPNInstanceName])

Cause 1: The SSH user does not exist.
Cause 2: The RSA, DSA, or ECC does not exist.
Cause 3: The user name or password is incorrect.
Cause 4: The SSH service is disabled.
Cause 5: The ACL rule matches the IP address of the user and the action is deny.
Cause 6: The number of users connected to the SSH server reached the maximum value.
Cause 7: The user access permission is not enabled for the default path.
1. The troubleshooting procedures for different causes are as follows:
Cause 1: Run the ssh user command to create an SSH user.
Cause 2:

�Run the display rsa local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local RSA key pair.If no RSA key pair is configured, run the rsa local-key-pair create command to generate a local RSA key pair.

�Run the display ecc local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local ECC key pair.If no ECC key pair is configured, run the ecc local-key-pair create command to generate a local ECC key pair.

�Run the display dsa local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local DSA key pair.If no DSA key pair is configured, run the dsa local-key-pair create command to generate a local DSA key pair.
Cause 3: Ensure that the user name and password are correct.
Cause 4: Ensure that the SSH service is enabled.
Cause 5: Run the acl and rule commands in sequence to change the action of the corresponding rule to permit.
Cause 6: Ensure that the number of users connected to the SSH server does not reach the maximum value.
Cause 7: The user access permission on the default path is enabled.
2. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

Cause 1: The designated port configured with root protection receives BPDUs with higher priorities than that of the local bridge. Cause 2: The priority of a device in the network topology changes.
�Cause 1: The port enabled with the root protection function received BPDUs of a higher priority than that of the bridge.
1. Check whether the new physical link is the required one.
�If the new physical link is the required one, go to Step 2.
�If the new physical link is not the required one, go to Step 3.
2. Run the display stp command to check whether each port complies with the protocol calculation result.
�If each port complies with the protocol calculation result, no action is required.
�If the calculation result of a port does not comply with the protocol, go to Step 4.
3. Correctly deploy the network topology and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Run the display stp command to check whether any port on the network is configured as a root protection port.
�If a port is configured as a root protection port, go to Step 5.
�If no port is configured as a root protection port, go to Step 6.
5. Run the undo stp root-protection command in the interface view to delete the root protection configuration. Then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: The priority of some switch changed in the network.
1. Run the display stp command to check whether the priority change in the network topology is normal.
�If the operation is normal, go to Step 3.
�If the operation is abnormal, go to Step 2.

2. Run the stp [ instance <instance-id> ] priority priority command in the system view to reconfigure the priority of the local bridge as required. Alternatively, run the undo stp [ instance <instance-id> ] priority or undo stp [ instance <instance-id> ] root command to restore the default bridge priority. Check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display stp command to check whether any port on the network is configured as a root protection port.
�If a port is configured as a root protection port, go to Step 4.
�If no port is configured as a root protection port, go to Step 5.
4. Run the undo stp root-protection command in the interface view to delete the root protection configuration. Then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column4: VRRP6/4/vrrp6MasterDown: The VRRP status changed from master to another state. (ifIndex=[ifIndex], VrId=[VrId], MasterIpAddr=[MasterIpAddr], sysName=[sysName], ifName=[ifName], CurrentState=[CurrentState], ChangeReason=[ChangeReason])
column5: VRRP6 was changed from master to another state.

column1: [VrId]VRID of the VRRP6 backup group
[MasterIpAddr]IP address of the master device in the VRRP6 backup group
[sysName]System name
[ifName]Name of the interface on which VRRP6 is configured
[CurrentState]Current VRRP6 status
[ChangeReason]VRRP6 status change reason
Possible Cause s are as follows:
Cause 1: TThe master device in the VRRP6 backup group went down.
Cause 2: The primary link of the VRRP6 backup group went down.
Cause 3: The VRRP6 priority of the master or backup device changed.
Cause 4: VRRP6 backup group was deleted.
1. Check the value of CurentState to see the changed VRRP6 status.
�If the VRRP6 status is initialize, go to Step 2.
�If the VRRP6 status is backup, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the interface on which VRRP is configured is working properly.
�If the interface is working properly, go to Step 5.
�If the interface is working improperly, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display vrrp6 command to check the configured and running priorities of VRRP6 on the original master and backup routers.

�Check whether the VRRP6-tracking interface or BFD went Down, and the VRRP priority was reduced. If the VRRP6-tracking interface or BFD went Down and the VRRP6 priority was reduced, locate the cause of the fault and restore the faulty link. If the faulty link is restored, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP6 tracking interface or BFD is working properly, go to Step 5.
4. Run the display this interface command in the view of the interface on which VRRP6 is configured to check the physical and protocol status of the interface.
�If the physical status is Down, the link is faulty. Locate the cause of the fault and restore the link. Then, go to Step 6.
�If the physical status is Up, check the protocol status. If the protocol status is Down, the IP address of the interface is deleted. Then, go to Step 6.
�If the protocol status is Up, the IP address of the interface and the virtual IP address of VRRP6 are on different network segments.

5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. Check whether the configurations of the local and remote ends are correct. If there is any incorrect configuration, correct it.
6. End.

column4: BGP/2/hwBgpPeerRouteNumThresholdExceed_active: The number of routes received from the BGP peer exceeded the alarm threshold. (InstanceId=[InstanceId], Afi=[AddrFamilyAfi], Safi=[AddrFamilySafi], PeerRemoteAddrType=[PeerIPAddrType], PeerRemoteAddr=[PeerIPAddr], MaxRouteNumber=[RouteLimitNum], AlarmThreshold=[RouteLimitThreshold])
column5: Alarm when route-limit threshold is configured and the number of routes from peer exceed the threshold.

column1: [AddrFamilyAfi]Address family: 1: ipv4 2: ipv6 25: vpls 196: l2vpn 16388: link-state 36879: rpd

[AddrFamilySafi]Sub-address family: 1: unicast 2: multicast 3: Unicast & multicast 4: mpls 5: mvpn 65: vpls 66: mdt 70: evpn 71: link-state 73: srpolicy 74: sdwan 128: vpn 129: vpnv4 multicast 132: vpn orf 133: flowv4 134: flowvpn 179: rpd 245: tunnel-encap-ext 255: mvrf
[PeerIPAddrType]Peer address type
[PeerIPAddr]Peer address
[RouteLimitNum]Route limit number
[RouteLimitThreshold]Route limit threshold
The number of routes received from the BGP peer configured with route-limit exceeds the alarm threshold.

1. Run the display bgp peer verbose command to check whether the number of routes received from the peer exceeds the maximum number of routes configured for the peer multiplied by the alarm threshold (%). 1)Y=>2. 2)N=>9.
2. Check whether the number of routes exceeds the threshold. 1)Y=>8. 2)N=>3.

3. View user logs to check whether the local import policy, such as peer route-policy/ip-prefix/filter-policy, has been modified. As a result, excessive unnecessary routes are received. 1)Y=>4. 2)N=>5.
4. Update the local import policy, such as peer route-policy/ip-prefix/filter-policy, to deny unnecessary routes. Then, go to Step 10.
5. Contact the maintenance personnel of the peer device to check whether all the routes advertised to the local end are necessary. 1)Y=>6. 2)N=>7.
6. Ask the maintenance personnel of the peer device to aggregate routes to reduce the number of advertised routes. Then, go to Step 10.
7. Ask the maintenance personnel of the peer device to modify the policy of importing or advertising routes to withdraw unnecessary routes. Then, go to Step 10.
8. Increase the maximum number of routes that can be received from the peer. Then, go to Step 10.
9. Contact technical support engineers.
10. End.

The PIM neighbor was lost.
1. Run the ping command to check whether the link between PIM neighbors works properly.
�If the link works properly, go to Step 3.
�If the link works improperly, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the unicast route between PIM neighbors is reachable.
�If the unicast route is reachable, go to Step 3.
�If the unicast route is unreachable, rectify the route fault to clear the alarm.
3. Run the display this command in the view of the corresponding PIM neighboring interface to check whether the interface is enabled with PIM-SM.

�If PIM-SM is enabled on the neighboring interface, PIM neighbor loss is caused by the change of the IP address of the neighboring interface. If the PIM neighbor relationship cannot be re-established after a certain period, go to Step 4.
�If PIM-SM is not enabled on the neighboring interface, run the pim sm command in the interface view to enable PIM-SM to clear the alarm.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

�If BFD is disabled on either end, enable BFD and go to Step 1.
�If BFD is enabled on both ends, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display bfd session all command to check whether the BFD sessions are deleted on either end.
�If the BFD sessions are deleted on either end, go to Step 5.
�If the BFD sessions are not deleted on either end, go to Step 4.
4. Run the ping <ip-address> command to check whether the link monitored by the BFD session is working properly.
�If the link monitored by the BFD session is not working properly, go to Step 5.

column4: NTP/2/NTP_TRAP_SYNCHRONIZE_STATUS: NTP synchronization state changed. (hwNtpState=[state], hwNtpSource=[source], hwNtpSourceVpnName=[VpnName])
column5: The status of the local NTP clock changes.
column6: [state]Status of the local NTP clock. Source: specifies the IP address of the server for local NTP clock synchronization.

column1: [source]IP address of the server for local NTP clock synchronization.
[VpnName]VPN instance associated with the peer end that synchronizes with the local NTP clock.
The NTP status changes from synchronized to unsynchronized due to the following reasons:
Cause 1: The system clock is reset.
Cause 2: The specified peer end is deleted.
Cause 3: The specified peer end is unreachable.
Cause 4: The specified peer end fails authentication.
Cause 5: The specified peer clock is not synchronized.
Cause 6: The last update of the peer clock times out.
Cause 7: The source level is higher than the local level.
Cause 8: The system synchronization source is lost.
Cause 9: The NTP mode does not match the specified peer end.
Cause 1: The system clock is reset.
1. Specify a new clock, and the NTP enters the synchronization state.
�If so, no further action is required.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 2: The specified peer end is deleted.
1. Configure an alternative clock source, and the NTP enters the synchronization state.
�If so, no further action is required.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 3: The specified peer end is unreachable.
1. Check the connectivity between the clock and the peer end.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Specify a new clock source, and the NTP enters the synchronization state.
�If so, no further action is required.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 4: Authentication of the specified peer end fails.
1. Check whether NTP authentication has been configured on both the local and peer ends.
�If authentication has been configured, go to Step 2.
�If NTP authentication is not configured, configure NTP authentication.
2. Check whether the NTP authentication keys configured on the local and peer ends are the same.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, reconfigure the NTP authentication key.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 5: The specified peer clock is not synchronized.
1. Configure an alternative clock source.
�If the NTP enters the synchronization state, no further action is required.
�If the NTP does not enter the synchronization state, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 6: The interval since the last update of the peer clock is too long and is not allowed.
1. Configure an alternative clock source.
�If the NTP enters the synchronization state, no further action is required.
�If the NTP does not enter the synchronization state, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 7: The source stratum is greater than the local stratum.
1. Run the display ntp status command to check the stratum of the local NTP.
�If the local NTP stratum is smaller than the peer NTP stratum, go to Step 2.
�If the local NTP stratum is greater than the peer NTP stratum, go to step 3.
2. Configure an alternative clock source and ensure that the stratum of the alternative clock source is smaller than that of the local clock source.
�If the NTP enters the synchronization state, no further action is required.
�If the NTP does not enter the synchronization state, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 8: The system synchronization source is lost.
1. Configure an alternative clock source and ensure that the stratum of the alternative clock source is smaller than that of the local clock source.
�If the NTP enters the synchronization state, no further action is required.
�If the NTP does not enter the synchronization state, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 9: The NTP mode does not match the specified peer end.
1. Run the display ntp sessions command to view the NTP mode.

Cause 1: A new neighbor was discovered.

Cause 3: A neighbor was aged because the aging period expired.
Cause 1: A new neighbor was discovered.
1. Run the display lldp neighbor command, check whether LLDP is enabled for the new neighbor.
�If yes, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If not, go to 2.
2. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
Cause 2: The neighbor relationship was deleted.
1. Run the display lldp neighbor command, check whether LLDP is disabled for the new neighbor.
�If yes, run the lldp enable (system view) command in the system view of the neighboring device to enable LLDP.
�If not, go to 2.
2. Run the display interface brief command, check whether a link fault occurs between the local device and the neighbor.
�If yes, rectify the link fault.
�If not, go to 3.
3. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
Cause 3: A neighbor was aged because the aging period expired.
1. Run the display lldp statistic command, check whether neighboring node information saved on the local device times out.
�If yes, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If not, go to 2.
2. Check whether the interface connecting the local device and the neighbor has been shut down.
�If yes, run the undo shutdown command on the interface to configure it to go Up.
�If not, go to 3.
3. Run the display health command, check CPU resource exhaustion to determine whether the link between the local device and the neighbor is congested.
�If yes, stop the transmission of irrelevant traffic to remove the congestion.
�If not, go to 4.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

Cause 1: Transmission distances of optical modules on two directly connected devices were inconsistent with actual transmission distances. As a result, the input optical power of the devices was either too high or too low, causing error codes or packets over the link.
Cause 2: The connector or extension component (such as a flange or concentrator) on the direct cable or link was not connected securely, causing error codes or packets over the link.
Cause 3: The direct optical fiber or cable was not connected securely with devices on both ends, causing error codes or packets over the link.
Cause 4: The direct optical module or power module was not connected securely with devices on both ends, causing error codes or packets over the link.
Cause 5: The transmission network was faulty, causing routers to receive error codes or packets.
Cause 6: The connector or extension component (such as a flange or concentrator) on the direct cable or link aged, causing error codes or packets over the link.
Cause 7: The configurations of interconnected physical layer devices were inconsistent, causing error codes or packets over the link.
1.Check that the optical fiber is connected properly. Run the display this interface command in the interface view to check the interface status.
�If the interface is Up, go to Step 2.
�If the interface is Down, go to End.
2.Check the optical receive power in the display this interface command output.
�If the optical receive power is within the allowed range, go to Step 3.
�If the optical receive power is not in the allowed range, go to End.
3.Check the link protocol, clock mode and scramble of the local device in the display this interface command output. Then check whether they are consistent with those of the peer device.
�If the link layer protocols and clock modes are consistent, go to End.
�If the link layer protocols and clock modes are inconsistent, go to Step 4.
4.Set the same link protocol, clock mode and scramble for the local and peer devices. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 6.
5.Check the physical link status.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 6.
6.Collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: VRRP6/4/vrrp6NonMaster: The VRRP status changed between backup and initialize. (ifIndex=[ifIndex], VrId=[VrId], MasterIpAddr=[MasterIpAddr], sysName=[sysName], ifName=[ifName], CurrentState=[CurrentState], ChangeReason=[ChangeReason])
column5: The VRRP6 status changed between Backup and Initialize.

column1: [VrId]VRID of the VRRP6 backup group
[MasterIpAddr]IP address of the master device in the VRRP6 backup group
[sysName]System name
[ifName]Name of the interface where VRRP6 is configured
[CurrentState]VRRP6 status after the change. Possible values are as follows: Initialize Backup
[ChangeReason]VRRP6 status change reason
Possible Cause s for the VRRP6 status change from Backup to Initialize are as follows:
Cause 1: The device on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured failed.
Cause 2: The interface on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured or its connected link failed.
Possible Cause s for the VRRP6 status change from Initialize to Backup are as follows:
Cause 1: The device on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured recovered.
Cause 2: The interface on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured or its connected link recovered.
1. Check whether the value of CurentState is Initialize or Backup.
�If the value of CurentState is Initialize, go to Step 2.
�If the value of CurentState is Backup, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the interface on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured or the link monitored by BFD that is associated with VRRP6 is Up.
�If the interface on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the link monitored by BFD that is associated with VRRP6 is Up, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display this interface command in the view of the interface on which the VRRP6 backup group is configured to check the physical and protocol statuses of the interface.
�If the physical status of the interface is Down, the link connected to the interface fails. Rectify the fault and check whether the VRRP6 backup group has recovered.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has not recovered, go to Step 5.

�If the physical status of the interface is Up but its protocol status is Down, the IP address of the interface has been deleted. Reassign an IP address to the interface and check whether the VRRP6 backup group has recovered.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has not recovered, go to Step 5.

�If the physical and protocol statuses of the interface are both Up, the IP address of the interface is not on the same network segment as the virtual IP address of the VRRP6 backup group. Reassign an IP address to the interface and ensure that the IP address is on the same network segment as the virtual IP address of the VRRP6 backup group. Then check whether the VRRP6 backup group has recovered.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has not recovered, go to Step 5.
4. Run the display vrrp6 command and check whether the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is UP.
�If the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is DOWN, the original standby link fails. Rectify the fault and check whether the VRRP6 backup group has recovered.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP6 backup group has not recovered, go to Step 5.
�If the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is UP, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

1. Run the display health command to check detailed information about the CPU usage and memory usage threshold of the current board.

1. Check whether a local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated.
�If a local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated, go to Step 3.
�If no local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated, go to Step 2.

�If a loop is formed by a hub and devices, one of which is connected to the interface, go to Step 4.
�If no loop is formed by a hub and devices, one of which is connected to the interface, go to Step 5.
3. Delete the local loopback configuration, and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.

The status of the virtual interface changed.
1. If the interface status of the virtual link changes from Down to P2P (Point-to-Point), this trap message is informational only, and no action is required.

2. If the interface status of the virtual link changes from P2P to Down, check whether a route with the outbound interface being the virtual link interface exists. If the route does not exist, check the reason why the route does not exist. If the route exists, check whether the configurations of the local and peer virtual link interfaces are correct.

column1: The system use mini-system configurations to recovery.
After the device starts, you can run the display startup command to check whether the restored file is the mini-system file. If so, the device is restored using the minimum system configuration.
1. If you want to start the system using the minimum system configuration, this log message is informational only, and no action is required.

2. If you do not want to start the system using the minimum system configuration, do not run the startup saved-configuration mini-system command in the system view. In addition, you can run the reset saved-configuration mini-system command in the diagnostic view to clear the mini-system configuration file configured on the device.

column4: DEVM/4/hwIfMonitorOutputRateRising_active: Interface output flow bandwidth usage exceeded the trap threshold. (Interface=[IfIndex], BandWidthUsage=[hwSubifOutputRatePercentage], TrapThreshold=[hwSubifOutputRateThreshold], InterfaceName=[InterfaceName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The percentage of the traffic sent by an interface to the total bandwidth of the interface exceeded the threshold.

column1: [hwSubifOutputRatePercentage]Incoming traffic statistics
[hwSubifOutputRateThreshold]Alarm threshold for output traffic
[InterfaceName]Name of the interface.

The interface traffic statistics collection period can be configured. The default value is 300s. The average rate of the previous statistics collection period is calculated in every 1/6 of the statistics collection period and then divided by the interface bandwidth to obtain the interface bandwidth usage. If the interface bandwidth usage exceeds the interface alarm threshold, the interface rate threshold-crossing alarm is triggered.
1. Run the display this interface command in the interface view to check whether the traffic threshold is too low. The proper threshold is determined by users based on actual services.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If not, go to Step 3.
2. Run the trap-threshold output-rate threshold_value command in the interface view to re-set the alarm threshold. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

The number of ROA entries that the device receives from an RPKI session exceeded the configured limit.
1. Run the display rpki session verbose command to check whether the number of ROA entries that the device receives from an RPKI session exceeds the configured limit.
�If the number of ROA entries that the device receives from an RPKI session exceeds the configured limit, go to Step 2.
�If the number of ROA entries that the device receives from an RPKI session has not exceeded the configured limit, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the configured limit is too low.
�If the configured limit is too low, go to Step 5.
�If the configured limit meets the requirements on the live network, go to Step 3.
3. Check logs and contact maintenance personnel of the peer device to determine whether all the data received from the peer device is necessary.
�If all the data received from the peer device is necessary, go to Step 5.
�If not all the data received from the peer device is necessary, go to Step 4.
4. Ask the maintenance personnel of the peer device to delete the unnecessary ROA data and then check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 6.
5. Increase the limit on the number of ROA entries that the device is allowed to receive from an RPKI session and then check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: CLKM/4/hwClockSourceOutputBelowThreshold_active: The SSM of output below threshold notification. (hwClockAttributeChassisIndex=[hwClockAttributeChassisIndex], hwClockChassisId=[hwClockChassisId], hwClockPllId=[hwClockPllId], hwClockAttributeOutThreshold=[hwClockAttributeOutThreshold], hwClockAttributeOutValue=[hwClockAttributeOutValue], hwClockCurSourceName=[hwClockCurSourceName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The output quality level of the external clock was lower than the lower threshold.
column6: [hwClockAttributeChassisIndex]Index of the chassis where the non-PTP clock source is located. In the case of a single chassis, the value is always 1. The chassis index of a PTP source is invalid.

column1: [hwClockChassisId]ID of the chassis where the clock source is located.
[hwClockPllId]Type ID of the clock source. The values are as follows: System(1): system PLL. sync2M-1(2), 2M PLL-1. sync2M-2(3), 2M PLL-2.

[hwClockAttributeOutThreshold]Lower threshold of the output quality level of the external clock. The values are as follows: prc(2). ssua(4). ssub(8). sec(11). dnu(15). The default SSM level corresponding to the lower threshold is dnu, which can be set to prc, sec, ssua, or ssub.
[hwClockAttributeOutValue]Output quality level of the external clock. The values are as follows: prc(2). ssua(4). ssub(8). sec(11). dnu(15).
[hwClockCurSourceName]Name of the current clock source.
Cause1: The lower limit to the SSM level of output clock signals was set too high.
Cause2: The SSM level of the signal output by the traced clock source changed.
1. Run the display clock config command to check the output threshold of the clock source.
�If the output threshold is displayed as dnu, no output threshold is configured. In this case, go to Step 4.
�If the output threshold is a different value, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display clock source command to check the output SSM level of the clock source.
�If the value does not exceed the threshold, go to Step 3.
�If the value exceeds the threshold, go to Step 4.
3. Run the clock bits output-threshold command to set a proper output threshold.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

CLKSYNC
column4: CLKSYNC/4/SYNSTATUS: The synchronization status of the time source changed. (State=[State]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: This log records whether the device is synchronized with a time source.
column6: [State]The synchronization status of the time source. The options are as follows: syn(1): synchronization. non-syn(0): not synchronized.

column1: Cause 1: The PTP function was normal, and the device achieved time synchronization.
Cause 2: The link was faulty or the interface was Down. As a result, the device did not have a synchronized time source.
1. Check the synchronization status.
If the synchronization status is syn, this log message is informational only, and no action is required.
If the synchronization status is non-syn, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display device command to check whether the interface board is registered.
If the interface board cannot be registered, it indicates that the hardware of the interface board is faulty. In this case, replace the interface board.
If the board can be registered after being reset, the software is faulty. In this case, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display ptp all config command to check whether the device configuration is correct.
If yes, go to Step 4.
If no, go to Step 5.
4. Configure the PTP function according to the PTP configuration guide. Check whether the fault is rectified.
If yes, go to Step 6.
If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.
