�Cause 1: The interface went Down.
�Cause 2: The configuration of the tunnel was deleted.
�Cause 3: The link was faulty.
�Cause 4: The hot-standby LSP had nodes through which the primary LSP passed.
�Cause 5: RSVP-TE LSP resources were preempted.
�Cause 6: Transmission of an RSVP message timed out.
�Cause 7: RSVP Hello mechanism detected a downstream node failure.
�Cause 8: The bypass tunnel in use was Down or unbound from the primary tunnel.
�Cause 9: CSPF failed to calculate a path.
�Cause 10: The tunnel was manually shut down.
�Cause 1: The interface went Down.

1. Run the display mpls te tunnel-interface <tunnel-name> command on the ingress (the node where the alarm is generated) to check the tunnel configuration. Check the Tunnel State Desc field to determine whether the tunnel is down. Run the display mpls te tunnel-interface last-error command to check the error message.
�If the following error information is displayed:
�If Cspf failed to calculate a path for Tunnel. is displayed, CSPF has been enabled on the ingress, but CSPF path calculation fails. Go to Step 2.
�If the message Trigger RSVP failed. is displayed, go to Step 2.
�If One LSP is deleted at smooth period. is displayed, go to Step 6.
�If One LSP is deleted at Tunnel aging period is displayed, go to Step 6.
�If other errors occur, go to Step 6.
�If no error message is displayed, go to Step 2.
2. Run the ping command on the egress to check whether the destination IP address of the tunnel can be pinged successfully.

�If the ping fails, rectify the route fault so that the ingress can ping the destination address of the tunnel. Then, check whether the MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.48 hwMplsTunnelHotstandbyUp alarm is generated.
�If yes, go to Step 7.
�If no, go to Step 3.
�If the ping succeeds, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display this command in the MPLS view on the ingress to check whether the mpls te cspf command is run. That is, check whether CSPF is enabled.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.

4. Run the display mpls te cspf destination command on the ingress to check whether a path satisfying the specified constraints exists. If such a path is available, the path information is displayed and CSPF path calculation succeeds. If such a path is unavailable, no path information is displayed and CSPF path calculation fails.

�If the path computation is successful, run the display current-configuration interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command on the ingress to check tunnel configurations. Determine the working tunnel, protection tunnel, and protection interface. Check whether the mpls te auto-frr command is run in the MPLS view. If the command is run, automatic protection is configured. In this case, you can determine which tunnel is the primary tunnel according to the configuration of the tunnel. If the mpls te auto-frr command is not run, check the mpls te fast-reroute, mpls te record-route, and mpls te bypass-tunnel command configurations to determine the primary and backup tunnels.

After determining the primary and backup tunnels, perform the following checks: Check whether the explicit-path command is run to determine whether an explicit path is configured for the tunnel. Check whether the mpls te affinity property command is run to determine whether the affinity attribute is configured for the tunnel. Check whether the mpls te bandwidth command is run to determine whether the bandwidth is configured for the tunnel.

Run the display mpls te cspf destination command with constraints specified based on tunnel configurations. The parameters include priority setup-priority, bandwidth, explicit-path path-name, affinity, and hop-limit hop-limit-number. Then check whether a path that satisfies the constraints exists. If such a path is available, the path information is displayed and CSPF path calculation succeeds. If such a path is unavailable, no path information is displayed and CSPF path calculation fails.

�a. If explicit path calculation fails, check the explicit path and tunnel interface configurations to determine the primary and backup paths. Check whether each interface along the explicit path is up and whether MPLS and MPLS TE are enabled. If explicit path calculation succeeds, check whether the affinity attribute and bandwidth are successfully calculated and whether they are the same as those of the explicit path. You can run the display mpls te cspf destination <ip-address> bandwidth ct0 <ct0-bandwidth> explicit-path <path-name> command.

�b. If affinities fail to be used to compute a path, run the mpls te affinity property command in the tunnel interface view to modify affinities and run the mpls te link administrative group command in the view of each interface along the path to modify the administrative group attribute.

�c. If bandwidth-based path computation fails, run the display mpls te link-administration bandwidth-allocation interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command to check whether the bandwidth of the outbound interfaces along the tunnel is sufficient. If bandwidth resources are sufficient, a higher-priority tunnel may preempt bandwidth resources of an existing tunnel. Run the mpls te bandwidth max-reservable-bandwidth and mpls te bandwidth command to increase bandwidth values.
�d. If path calculation based on other constraints fails, go to Step 6.
Then, check whether the MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.48 hwMplsTunnelHotstandbyUp alarm is generated.
�If yes, go to Step 7.
�If no, go to Step 5.
�If path calculation fails, go to Step 5.

5. Run the display explicit-path command to check the interfaces along the tunnel and run the display this command in the interface view to check whether MPLS, MPLS TE, and RSVP-TE are enabled on the interfaces to the destination address.
�If the functions are not enabled, run the mpls, mpls te, and mpls rsvp-te commands in the interface view.

�If the interface is not in the Up state, restart the interface. That is, run the shutdown command and then the undo shutdown command in the interface view, or run the restart command in the interface view.
Then, check whether the MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.48 hwMplsTunnelHotstandbyUp alarm is generated.
�If yes, go to Step 7.
�If no, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

PTP
column4: PTP/4/hwPtpPassiveMeasureOverflow_active: The time offset of the passive port is abnormal. (hwPtpPortName=[hwPtpPortName], hwPtpPortIfIndex=[hwPtpPortIfIndex], hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue=[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue], hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag=[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag], hwPtpPassiveAlarmThreshold=[hwPtpPassiveAlarmThreshold]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The monitored passive port value exceeded the threshold. This alarm is not supported on passive ports configured as Ethernet reference ports.

column1: [hwPtpPortIfIndex]Index of the current port.
[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue]New time offset caused by the fiber length change of the current port. Unit: ns
[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag]Plus or minus sign of the new time offset caused by the fiber change of the current port. The values are as follows: Negative sign (0). Positive sign (1).
[hwPtpPassiveAlarmThreshold]Passive monitoring threshold configured on the current device.
The offset values of Passive ports are checked every 300s. The time offset value of the current Passive port is larger than the time offset threshold configured on the Passive port.
1. Check whether the fiber length of the primary/backup link changes.
If the fiber length changes, the transmit and receive optical fibers of the new optical fiber are asymmetrical. Go to Step 2.
If the fiber length does not change, go to Step 3.

2. Use a symmetrical optical fiber or configure an asymmetrical value (by running the ptp asymmetry-correction command in interface mode) for the asymmetrical optical fiber port. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 9.
If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.

3. Check whether the asymmetry value is set for the ports on the primary and backup links within 10 minutes before the alarm is generated. Run the display current-configuration | in asymetry command in the system view to check whether new asymmetry values are delivered.
If yes, the asymmetry value is incorrectly configured. Go to Step 4.
If no, no new asymmetry value is delivered. Go to Step 5.
4. Run the ptp asymmetry-correction command in interface mode to re-deliver the asymmetry value. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 9.
If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.

5. Check whether the primary and backup links are stable. There are many unstable links. Occasional unstable links can be ignored. If the links are unstable for a long time, locate the cause of the unstable links.
If no, go to Step 6.
If yes, go to Step 8.
6. Run the disp alarm active | inc PTP_OFFSETSUM_OVER command to check whether time offset accumulation and threshold-crossing alarms are generated on the device.
If yes, there is a high probability that the problem is caused by different frequency and time sources. Go to Step 7.
If no, go to Step 8.
7. Re-plan the deployment to ensure that the frequency and time source are the same. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 9.
If the alarm persists, go to Step 8.
8. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
9. End.

column4: PTP/3/hwPtpPortAttrMisMatch_active: PTP attribute mismatching at both ends. (ClockChassisId=[ClockChassisId], PtpPortIfIndex=[PtpPortIfIndex], PtpPortName=[PtpPortName], AlarmReason=[AlarmReason]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The configuration attributes at both ends did not match. If the configurations at both ends do not match, PTP packets cannot be correctly processed. As a result, time synchronization fails.
column6: [ClockChassisId]Number of the chassis where the clock source is located.

column1: [PtpPortIfIndex]Index of the interface where the clock source is located.
[PtpPortName]Name of the interface where the clock source is located.
[AlarmReason]Cause of the mismatch between the two ends.

Cause1: The P/E modes mismatch. (If the P/E mode on the master side is the P2P mode and the P/E mode on the slave side is the E2E mode, an alarm is generated on the slave side and the slave side triggers clock source switching. if the P/E mode on the master side is the E2E mode and the P/E mode on the slave side is the P2P mode, an alarm is generated only on the master side and the slave side does not trigger clock source switching.)
Cause2: The encapsulation types of the PTP interfaces on both sides are inconsistent.
Cause3: The domain configurations of the PTP interfaces on both sides are inconsistent.
Cause4: The source port IDs of the PTP interfaces on both sides are inconsistent.
1. Check whether the P/E modes at both ends match. If not, modify the P/E modes at both ends to match.
2. Check whether the encapsulation types at both ends match. If not, modify the encapsulation types at both ends to match.
3. Check whether the domains at both ends match. If not, modify the configurations at both ends to match.
4. Check whether an incorrect SourcePortId to be received is configured.

1. Reduce the number of routes sent by the peer end. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. That is, check whether the matching clear alarm (hwBgpVrfRouteNumReachThresholdClear) is generated.

[StatusChanged]Status change information: is abnormal is normal
If the status change value is is abnormal, a unit on the subcard was faulty.
If the status change value is is normal, the fault on a unit of the subcard was rectified.
Cause 1: A unit on the subcard was faulty.
�If the board where the faulty subcard resides does not support flexible cards, do as follows:

1. Run the power off slot slot-id command to power off the board where the faulty subcard resides, and then run the power on slot slot-id command to power on the board. Run the display device command to check whether the board can be registered. That is, check whether the Register field of the board is displayed as Registered.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If not, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether this log is displayed, in which the value of status change is is normal.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 4.
3. Replace the board. Check whether this log is displayed, in which the value of status change is is normal.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.
�If the board where the faulty subcard resides supports flexible cards, do as follows:
1. If the motherboard where the faulty subcard resides starts to reset, wait until the motherboard successfully resets, and no action is required. If the motherboard does not reset, go to Step 2.

2. Run the power off slot slot-id card card-id command to power off the faulty subcard, and run the power on slot slot-id card card-id command to power on the faulty subcard. Then, run the display device [ pic-status | slot-id ] command to check whether the subcard can be registered. That is, check whether the Register field of the subcard is displayed as Registered.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 4.
3. Check whether this log is displayed, in which the value of status change is is normal.
�If so, go to Step 6.
�If not, go to Step 5.
4. Replace the subcard. Check whether this log is displayed, in which the value of status change is is normal.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If not, go to Step 5.

5. If the motherboard of the faulty subcard has only one subcard, run the power off slot slot-id command to power off the motherboard, and run the power on slot slot-id command to power on the motherboard. Then, run the display device command to check whether the motherboard can be registered. That is, check whether the Register field of the motherboard is displayed as Registered.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If not, go to Step 6.
�If more than one subcard is installed on the motherboard, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
7. End.
Cause 2: The fault on a unit of the subcard was rectified.
This log message is informational only, and no action is required.

column1: [ProbableCause]Trap cause.
[EventType]Alarm type
[PhysicalIndex]Physical index
[PhysicalName]Entity name
[RelativeResource]Relevant resource name

[UsageType]Overload type. The value 1 indicates the CPU. The default sampling interval is 10 seconds, and the number of overload sampling times is 48. The value 2 indicates the memory. The default sampling interval is 1 second, and the number of overload sampling times is 2. The value 3 indicates a disk. The value 4 indicates flash memory. The value 5 indicates the CF card. The value 6 indicates the physical memory.
[SubIndex]Entity sub-index
[UsageValue]Storage usage
[Unit]Unit
[UsageThreshold]Threshold
The storage usage of the CF card exceeded the pre-set fully loaded threshold. The default full load threshold is 85%.
1. Run the cd command in the user view to enter the the directory of the CF card, and then run the dir command to check the storage space usage of the CF card.
�If the storage space usage of the CF card is higher than the full load threshold, go to Step 2.
�If the storage space usage of the CF card is lower than the full load threshold, go to Step 3.
2. Delete unnecessary files to reduce the storage space usage of the CF card, and then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is no longer generated, the problem is resolved.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect log files and contact technical support engineers.

2. On the NMS, check whether alarms such as ETH_LOS are reported on all nodes that TWAMP passes through.
�If yes, clear the alarms first.
�If no, go to Step 3.
For details about the alarms, see the iMaster NCE-IP product documentation of the corresponding version.
3. Check whether the bearer layer of the VPN, such as the MPLS/PW layer, is faulty.
�If a fault occurs, rectify the fault at the VPN bearer layer.
�If no, go to Step 4.
4. Check whether the bandwidth of the tunnel is used up.
�If yes, expand the tunnel capacity or eliminate the source that transmits a large amount of invalid data.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column4: CLKM/4/hwClockSourceSwitch: The clock source is switched. (hwClockChassisId=[hwClockChassisId], hwClockPllId=[hwClockPllId], hwClockLastSourceName=[hwClockLastSourceName], hwClockCurSourceName=[hwClockCurSourceName], hwClockSrcSelChassisIndex=[hwClockSrcSelChassisIndex], hwClockSrcSelType=[hwClockSrcSelType], hwClockSrcSelMode=[hwClockSrcSelMode]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The clock source is switched.
column6: [hwClockChassisId]ID of the chassis where the clock source resides. The value is fixed to 1 in the case of a single chassis.

column1: [hwClockPllId]ID of the clock source type. The options are as follows: system(1), system PLL. sync2M1(2), 2M PLL-1. sync2M2(3), 2M PLL-2.
[hwClockLastSourceName]Name of the clock source before the switching.
[hwClockCurSourceName]Name of the current clock source.
[hwClockSrcSelChassisIndex]Index of the chassis where the clock source is located. In the case of a single chassis, the value is fixed to 1.
[hwClockSrcSelType]Type of the clock source. The values are as follows: System(1), system PLL. sync2M1(2), 2M PLL-1. sync2M2(3), 2M PLL-2.

[hwClockSrcSelMode]Clock source selection mode. The values are as follows: auto(0): automatic clock source selection. manual(1): manual clock source selection. force(2): forcible clock source selection.
Cause 1: The attribute of the clock device on the network changed. As a result, the current master clock was switched.
Cause 2: The master clock was switched because the link was faulty or the interface was Down.
Cause 3: The clock source was manually switched in manual or force mode.
1. Run the display clock config command to check the running mode of the clock source.
�If the running mode of the clock source is free, the clock source is in free-run mode. In this case, go to Step 6.
�If the running mode of the clock source is hold, the clock source is forcibly held. In this case, go to Step 6.
�If the running mode of the clock source is normal, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display clock config command to check the clock source selection mode.
�If the clock source selection mode is manual or force, the clock source is forcibly switched. In this case, go to Step 6.
�If the clock source selection mode is auto, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display clock source command to check whether the clock source status is normal.
�If the clock source is not in the normal state, go to Step 5.
�If the clock source status is normal, go to Step 4.
4. Run the display clock source command to check whether the attributes of the clock source change.
�If the attributes of the clock source change, go to Step 6.
�If the attributes of the clock source do not change, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

column4: SSH/5/SSH_QX_USER_LOGIN_FAIL: The SSH user failed to login. (ServiceType=[ServiceType], FailedReason=[FailedReason], UserName=[UserName], Tei=[Tei], TransNo=[TransNo])
column5: The SSH user fails to log in.

column1: [FailedReason]Cause of a user login failure.
[UserName]Login user name.
[Tei]Tei.
[TransNo]Transaction ID.
Cause 1: The SSH user does not exist.
Cause 2: The RSA, DSA, or ECC does not exist.
Cause 3: The user name or password is incorrect.
Cause 4: The SSH service is disabled.
Cause 5: An ACL rule matches the IP address of a user and the action is deny.
Cause 6: The number of users connected to the SSH server reaches the upper limit.
Cause 7: The user access permission is not enabled for the default path.
Cause 8: The SSH server does not support SSHv1.
Cause 1: Check whether the SSH user exists.
Cause 2: Check whether the SSH service is enabled.
Cause 3: Check the local RSA key information.
Cause 4: Check whether the ACL rule information is correct.
Cause 5: Check whether the user name and password are correct.
Cause 6: Check whether the number of users connected to the SSH server reaches the maximum value.
Cause 7: Check whether the user access permission of the default path is enabled.
Cause 8: Check whether the server version is supported and use the correct SSH version tool to log in to the system. SSHv1 is insecure and is not recommended.

column4: L2VPN/4/hwPWOverLdpOverGRENotSupportForwardAlarm_active: The public network tunnel used to carry the VPLS PW or EVPN is a LDP over GRE tunnel and the VPLS PW or EVPN cannot forward traffic. (VsiName=[hwVplsOverLdpOverGreVsiName], RemoteIp=[hwPeerRemoteIp], PwId=[hwVplsOverLdpOverGrePwId], EvpnName=[hwEvpnOverLdpOverGreEvpnName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

column1: [hwPeerRemoteIp]Remote IP address.

[hwEvpnOverLdpOverGreEvpnName]EVPN name.
The VPLS PW or EVPN is carried over a LDP over GRE tunnel, and the signaling protocol status of the VPLS PW or EVPN is Up.

1. Check whether the VSI name or EVPN name is valid. Run the display vsi name <vsi-number> verbose command to check VSI information in the alarm information. In a VSI scenario, locate the PW based on the remote IP address in the alarm information and check whether Tnl Type in the command output is LDP over GRE. If Tnl Type is LDP over GRE, run the display vsi name command to check the public network tunnel type of the VSI.
�If the tunnel is an LDP over GRE tunnel, go to Step 3.
�If the tunnel is not an LDP over GRE tunnel, go to Step 2.

2. Run the tunnel-policy command to enter the tunnel policy view of the PW. Run the tunnel select-seq or tunnel binding TE command to change the public network tunnel type to a non-LDP over GRE tunnel type. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

The fan was installed unstably.
1.Check if the fan is properly installed, if pins have bent, and if the fan connectors become faulty.
2.If the fan is not properly installed, re-install it.
3.If the pins on the backplane have bent, do not install a new fan into the faulty slot. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
4.If only the fan connectors are found faulty, replace the fan with a new one.
5.If services on the fan are abnormal, collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
6.End.

Cause 2: The network was busy.

Cause 1: The number of received public network route prefixes exceeded the upper threshold multiplied by the maximum number allowed but was less than the maximum number allowed.
Cause 2: The number of received VPN route prefixes exceeded the upper threshold multiplied by the maximum number allowed but was less than the maximum number allowed.

Cause 1: The total number of public network route prefixes exceeds the alarm threshold of public route prefixes specified in the ip prefix-limit command, and is smaller than the maximum number of route prefixes.
1. Run the display ip routing-table limit command to check whether the number of public network route prefixes exceeds the upper limit.
2. Run the display ip routing-table statistics command to check whether the number of existing public network route prefixes meets the requirements.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 3.

�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 6.
4. In the system view and run the display this command to view the configuration of the ip prefix-limit command. Then, check whether the set alarm threshold of public routes is proper.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, run the prefix limit <number> { <alert-percent> | simply-alert } command to set a proper alarm threshold of route prefixes. Then, go to Step 6.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

Cause 2: The total number of the VPN route prefixes in the VPN routing table exceeds the alarm threshold of VPN route prefixes specified in the prefix limit command, and is smaller than the maximum number of route prefixes.
1. Run the display ip routing-table limit vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> command to check whether the number of route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeds the upper limit.
2. Run the display ip routing-table vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> statistics command to check whether the number of existing route prefixes in the VPN instance meets the requirements.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 3.
3. Check whether the number of route prefixes still exceeds the alarm threshold after redundant VPN routes are deleted.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 6.
4. Enter the VPN instance view and run the display this command to view the configuration of the prefix limit command. Then, check whether the set alarm threshold of VPN routes is proper.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, run the prefix limit <number> { <alert-percent> | simply-alert } command to set a proper alarm threshold of route prefixes. Then, go to Step 6.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

(EntityPhysicalIndex=[EntityPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalIndex=[EntPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalName=[EntPhysicalName],EntityThresholdType=[EntityThresholdType],EntityThresholdCritical=[EntityThresholdCritical],EntityThresholdCurrent=[EntityThresholdCurrent],EntityTrapFaultID=143618,Reason=The fan temperature was too high.) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The board or subcard temperature alarm.
column6: [EntityPhysicalIndex]Indicates the index of the physical entity.

column1: [EntPhysicalName]Indicates the name of the physical entity, such as SFU | LPU | MPU slot <slotID>. The entity name varies according to the board type, such as the SFU, LPU, and MPU.
[EntityThresholdType]The abnormal type for temperature.The value can be: 1:high 2:low
[EntityThresholdCritical]The warning alarm threshold for warning alarm.
[EntityThresholdCurrent]The current value that been measured.
[EntityTrapFaultID]To describe the fault id of trap.
The fan temperature was too high.
1. Check if the filter screen of the fan module is clogged. If the filter screen is clogged, clean the filter screen.
2. Check the ambient temperature. If the ambient temperature is too high, reduce the temperature to a normal level.
3. Check if the fan module is faulty. If there is a fault on the fan module, rectify the fault first.

4. If the ambient temperature is normal but the alarm is still reported, the possible cause is that the module temperature is too high. In this case, collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamIgrLSPOutDefect: Ingress quit defect. (IfIndex=[IfIndex], TunnelName=[TunnelName], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType])
column5: The LSP fault checked by the OAM module on the source point was rectified.

column1: [TunnelName]Indicates the name of the tunnel.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM ingress: - 0: indicates that the ingress is available. - 1: indicates that the ingress is unavailable.

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: The LSP fault checked by the OAM module on the source point was rectified.

The main interface is configured with MAC flapping association, and the AC interface in the main interface has a loop.
1. Run the display current-configuration command to check whether the loopback local command is configured on AC-side interfaces corresponding to the VSI.

�If the loopback local command is configured on AC-side interfaces corresponding to the VSI, delete the command configuration and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
�If the loopback local command is not configured on AC-side interfaces corresponding to the VSI, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display loop-detect eth-loop command to check whether Action is displayed as Alarm-only.
�If Action is displayed as Alarm-only, go to Step 3.
�If Action is not displayed as Alarm-only, go to Step 4.
3. For the VSI in the alarm, perform either of the following steps:
�Run the shutdown command in the VSI and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4

�Run the loop-detect eth-loop command in the VSI view to change alarm-only to another parameter that allows the device to block an interface or a PW. For example, run the loop-detect eth-loop loop-times 3 detect-cycle 3 cycles 3 retry-times 1 block-time 10 command in the VSI view. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: QOS/4/hwXQoSCarBindwidthExceedChipLimitAlarm_active: The bandwidth configured for CAR exceeds the rate limiting capability of the NP. (slot-id=[slot-id],car-type=[car-type],cir=[cir],pir=[pir],maximum-rate-limiting=[maximum-rate-limit],is-percent=[is-percent])
column5: The configured CAR value exceeded the NP rate limit capability of the corresponding board.

column1: [car-type]CAR type.
[cir]Committed information rate (CIR). When is-percent is set to no, the unit is kbit/s.
[pir]Peak information rate (PIR). When is-percent is set to no, the unit is kbit/s. If the PIR in the alarm is 0, the PIR is set to 0 or does not exist.
[maximum-rate-limit]Maximum rate limit capability of the NP. The unit is kbit/s.
[is-percent]Whether the percentage mode is used.
The CAR value exceeded the rate limit of the NP on the current board.
1. Check whether the CIR or PIR in the alarm information is greater than maximum-rate-limit.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Run the following commands to modify the CIR and PIR configurations based on the value of car-type in the alarm information:
�If car-type in the alarm is INTF_CAR, run the qos car command in the interface view to change the CIR and PIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.
�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_CAR, run the car command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR and PIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_BROADCAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the broadcast-suppression cir command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_UNKNOWN_UNICAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the unknown-unicast-suppression cir command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_MULTICAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the multicast-suppression cir command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_BU_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the bu-suppression cir command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is PROFILE_BUM_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the bum-suppression cir command in the QoS profile view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.
�If car-type in the alarm is ACL_CAR, run the car command in the traffic behavior view to change the CIR or PIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is ACL_BROADCAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the broadcast-suppression cir command in the traffic behavior view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is ACL_MULTICAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the multicast-suppression cir command in the traffic behavior view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.

�If car-type in the alarm is ACL_UNKNOWN_UNICAST_SUPPRESSION_CAR, run the unknown-unicast-suppression cir command in the traffic behavior view to change the CIR so that the CAR value is smaller than the rate limit capability of the NP.
After the configuration is modified, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

column4: PIC/3/hwB2TcaAlarm_active: B2 threshold crossing alarm. (hwPhysicalPortIfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],BoardID=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardID=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortID=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
�Cause 0: The optical fiber was disconnected.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

1.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3.Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4.If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5.If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6.If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7.If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.

EOAM-Y1731
column4: EOAM-Y1731/4/STATISTIC_active: The Y.1731 statistic value exceeded the upper limit value. (MdIndex=[MdIndex], MaIndex=[MaIndex], MepID=[MepID], Type=[Type], MAC=[MAC], Priority=[Priority], MdName=[MdName], MaName=[MaName], Value=[Value], UpperLimitThreshold=[UpperLimitThreshold], LowerLimitThreshold=[LowerLimitThreshold], ValueHigh=[ValueHigh], ValueLow=[ValueLow])
column5: The Y.1731 performance statistic value exceeded the upper alarm threshold.

column1: The Y.1731 statistic value exceeded the upper limit value.
1. Rectify the fault based on the Type field value in the alarm information.
�If the Type field is 0, the alarm is a one-way frame delay alarm. Go to 2.
�If the Type field is 1, the alarm is a two-way frame delay alarm. Go to 3.
�If the Type field is 2, the alarm is a one-way frame jitter alarm. Go to 4.
�If the Type field is 3, the alarm is a two-way frame jitter alarm. Go to 5.
�If the Type field is 4, the alarm is an alarm for the near-end frame loss rate of single-ended frame loss. Go to 6.
�If the Type field is 5, the alarm is an alarm for the far-end frame loss rate of single-ended frame loss. Go to 7.
�If the Type field is 6, the alarm is an alarm for the near-end frame loss rate of dual-ended frame loss. Go to 8.
�If the Type field is 7, the alarm is an alarm for the far-end frame loss rate of dual-ended frame loss. Go to 9.

2. Run the display y1731 threshold-info onedelay-threshold md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for one-way frame delay is too small.
�If yes, run the delay-measure one-way delay-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit upper-limit <lower-limit> <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

3. Run the display y1731 threshold-info twodelay-threshold md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for two-way frame delay is too small.
�If yes, run the delay-measure two-way delay-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

4. Run the display y1731 threshold-info onedelay-variation md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for one-way frame jitter is too small.
�If yes, delay-measure one-way variation-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

5. Run the display y1731 threshold-info twodelay-variation md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for two-way frame jitter is too small.
�If yes, run the delay-measure two-way variation-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

6. Run the display y1731 threshold-info singleloss-localratio md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for the near-end frame loss rate of single-ended frame loss is too small.

�If yes, run the loss-measure single-ended local-ratio-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

7. Run the display y1731 threshold-info singleloss-remoteratio md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for the far-end frame loss rate of single-ended frame loss is too small.

�If yes, run the loss-measure single-ended remote-ratio-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> [ 8021p <8021p-value> ] command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

8. Run the display y1731 threshold-info dualloss-localratio md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for the near-end frame loss rate of dual-ended frame loss is too small.
�If yes, run the loss-measure dual-ended local-ratio-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.

9. Run the display y1731 threshold-info dualloss-localratio md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> command to view the values of UpperLimit and LowerLimit fields. Based on these values, determine whether the upper threshold for the far-end frame loss rate of dual-ended frame loss is too small.
�If yes, run the loss-measure dual-ended local-ratio-threshold mep <mep-id> upper-limit <upper-limit> lower-limit <lower-limit> command to reset the upper threshold. Go to 10.
�If no, go to 11.
10. In the system view, run the display alarm active command to check whether the alarm is cleared. If no, go to 11.
11. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
12. End.

(RecvPkt:Source Address:[PktSrcAddress], Dest Address:[PktDstAddress], Vers:[Vers], Diag:[Diag], State:[State], P:[P], F:[F], C:[C], A:[A], D:[D], M:[M], DetectMult:[DetectMult], Length:[Length], Packet Local Discriminator:[PktLocalDiscriminator], Packet Remote Discriminator:[PktRemoteDiscriminator], Packet Input Interface:[PktInputIfIndex], UDP Port:[PktUdpPort], TTL:[PktTTL], Reason:[reason])
column5: A BFD packet indicating an authentication failure was received.
column6: [PktSrcAddress]Source IP address carried in the received BFD packet.

column1: [PktDstAddress]Destination IP address carried in the received BFD packet.

A BFD packet indicating an authentication failure was received.
1. Run the display current configuration command in any view to check whether the BFD authentication mode and key on the peer end are correct.
�If the authentication mode and key are incorrect, go to step 2.
�If the authentication mode and key are correct, go to step 3.
2. Modify the BFD configuration mode and key on the peer end to be the same as those on the local end. Then, check whether the log is generated again. If the log persists, go to step 3.
3. Collect log and configuration information, and contact Huawei technical support personnel.

(SysInstance=[isisSysInstance], HostName=[hwIsisHostName], HostIpAddress=[hwIsisHostIpAddress], SystemID=[isisPduLspId], SysLevel=[isisSysLevelIndex], PurgeLspNum=[hwIsisPurgeLspNum], AffectedNodeNum=[hwIsisAffectedNodeNum], TotalNodeNum=[hwIsisTotalNodeNum], RuledOutDeviceNum=[hwIsisRuledOutDeviceNum], Interval=[hwIsisInterval])

In this case, log in to the possibly faulty node and check whether it is purging LSPs. If it is purging LSPs, reset or isolate it. If the possibly faulty node is not purging LSPs, check other possibly faulty nodes. To check the analysis report output by IS-IS purge LSP source tracing, run the display isis purge-source-trace analysis-report command.

The IS-IS LSPs advertised by the local device were purged by a neighbor.
1. Run the display isis route command to check whether any route is deleted. If yes, isolate the device from the network by resetting or isolating the device.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

column4: OSPF/3/hwOspfPrefixSidConflict_active: The OSPF prefix-sid conflict is detected. (ProcessId=[hwProcessId],PrefixSid=[hwPrefixSid],PrefixAddress=[hwPrefixAddress],PrefixAddressMask=[hwPrefixAddressMask],Algorithm=[hwAlgorithm],ConflictType=[hwConflictType])
column5: An OSPF prefix SID conflict was detected.

column1: [hwPrefixSid]Prefix SID
[hwPrefixAddress]Prefix address
[hwPrefixAddressMask]Prefix mask
[hwAlgorithm]Flexible algorithm (128-255)
[hwConflictType]1. SID conflict 2. Prefix conflict
Cause 1: The configuration is incorrect.
Cause 2: The SID of the flexible algorithm configured on a LoopBack interface is the same as that configured on another device.
Cause 3: This device is an OSPF ABR, and the LoopBack interfaces of other devices in different areas are configured with the same SID for the same flexible algorithm.

1. If an OSPF prefix SID conflict occurs, run the display ospf [ < process-id > ] routing [ <ip-address> [ <mask> | <mask-length> ] ] command to check the routing entry corresponding to the conflicting prefix. If the value of the Type field is Direct, it indicates that the local device is the conflicting advertising source device. Otherwise, the conflicting advertising source device is the device identified by the AdverRouter field. You need to run the ospf prefix-sid command on the advertising source device to modify the SID configuration.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
DCNM
column4: DCNM/2/hwIpRanDcnNeNumberOverLoad_active: DCN NE number overload start. (NeNumber=[NeNumber]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The number of NEs connected to the GNE exceeds the alarm threshold.

column1: The DCN NE number exceeds the setting threshold
1. Run the display dcn ne-info command to check whether the number of entries in the DCN core routing table has exceeded the upper limit.
2. Run the display this command in the DCN view to check the alarm threshold for the number of NEs connected to the GNE.

3. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. Replan the DCN subnets or change the alarm threshold for the number of NEs connected to the GNE.

column4: DEVM/1/hwBoardInvalid_active: The board totally failed. (EntityPhysicalIndex=[EntityPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalIndex=[EntPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalName=[EntPhysicalName],EntityType=[EntityType],EntityTrapFaultID=132703,Reason=The LTM is abnormal with hard-error.) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The overall function of the board does not take effect.
column6: [EntityPhysicalIndex]Indicates the index of the physical entity.

column1: [EntPhysicalName]Indicates the name of the entity such as a chassis.
[EntityType]Indicates the type of the physical entity. The value can be one of the following: 1: mpu(1) 2: lpu(2) 3: sfu(3) 4: pic(4) 5: cfcard(5) 6: ofc(6) 7: npu(7)
The LTM is abnormal with hard-error.
1. If the faulty board is neither reset nor powered off, and services on the board are normal, go to Step 4. Otherwise, go to Step 2.
2. Power off the faulty board and then power it on again.
3. If the board cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the board is registered, go to Step 4.
4. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support.
5. End.
IGMP
column4: IGMP/4/QUERY_INTERVAL_NOT_CONISITENT_MGMD_VSI: The interval of [protocol] general query packet received is greater than that of current configuration. (VsiName=[VsiName], IfName=[IfName], QueryReceInterval=[QueryReceInterval], QueryInterval=[QueryInterval])
column5: The interval at which the device receives IGMP/MLD general query messages is larger than the interval at which the device sends IGMP/MLD general query messages.

column1: [VsiName]VSI name.
[IfName]Name of the interface using which the device receives IGMP/MLD general query messages.
[QueryReceInterval]Interval at which the device receives IGMP/MLD general query messages.
[QueryInterval]Interval at which the device sends IGMP/MLD general query messages.
The interval at which the device receives IGMP/MLD general query messages is larger than the interval at which the device sends IGMP/MLD general query messages.
1. Check whether the interval at which the device receives IGMP/MLD general query messages is larger than the interval at which the device sends IGMP/MLD general query messages.
�If the IGMP/MLD general query message receiving interval is larger, go to Step 2.
�If the IGMP/MLD general query message receiving interval is not larger, go to Step 3.
2. Set a same value for the General Query message receiving and sending intervals.
3. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
BGP
column4: BGP/2/hwBgpPeerRouteExceed_active: The number of routes received from the BGP peer exceeded the alarm number. (InstanceId=[InstanceId], Afi=[AddrFamilyAfi], Safi=[AddrFamilySafi], PeerRemoteAddrType=[PeerIPAddrType], PeerRemoteAddr=[PeerIPAddr], MaxRouteNum=[RouteLimitNum], AlarmThreshold=[RouteLimitThreshold])
column5: The number of routes received from the BGP peer exceeded the upper limit allowed.

column1: [AddrFamilyAfi]Address family: 1: ipv4 2: ipv6 25: vpls 196: l2vpn 16388: link-state 36879: rpd

[AddrFamilySafi]Sub-address family: 1: unicast 2: multicast 3: Unicast & multicast 4: mpls 5: mvpn 65: vpls 66: mdt 70: evpn 71: link-state 73: srpolicy 74: sdwan 128: vpn 129: vpnv4 multicast 132: vpn orf 133: flowv4 134: flowvpn 179: rpd 245: tunnel-encap-ext 255: mvrf
[PeerIPAddrType]Peer address type
[PeerIPAddr]Peer address
[RouteLimitNum]Maximum number of routes
[RouteLimitThreshold]Alarm threshold
The number of routes received from the BGP peer who configured with route-limit, exceeds the maximum value allowed.
1. Run the display bgp peer command to check whether the number of routes received from the peer exceeds the upper threshold.
�If the number of routes received from the peer exceeds the upper threshold, go to Step 2.
�If the number of routes received from a peer does not exceed the upper threshold, go to Step 9.
2. Check whether the routes received from the peer are necessary ones.
�If the routes received from the peer are necessary ones, go to Step 8.
�If the routes received from the peer are not necessary ones, go to Step 3.

3. View user log information to check whether a large number of unnecessary routes are received because the local import policy is modified using commands such as peer route-policy, peer ip-prefix, and peer filter-policy.
�If a large number of unnecessary routes are received because the local import policy is modified, go to Step 4.
�If a large number of unnecessary routes are received due to other reasons, go to Step 5.

4. Update the local import policy by using the commands such as the peer route-policy command, the peer ip-prefix command, and the peer filter-policy command to deny the unnecessary routes. Then, check whether the problem is solved. If the fault persists, go to Step 9.
5. Contact the maintenance engineer responsible for the remote device to check whether the routes sent by the remote device to the local device are necessary ones.
�If the routes sent by the remote device to the local device are necessary ones, go to Step 7.
�If the routes sent by the remote device to the local device are not necessary ones, go to Step 6.

6. Request the maintenance engineer responsible for the remote device to modify the policy for importing routes or the policy for advertising routes to withdraw the unnecessary routes. Then, check whether the fault is rectified. If the fault persists, go to Step 9.

7. Request the maintenance engineer responsible for the remote device to configure route aggregation to reduce the number of routes to be advertised. Then, check whether the fault is rectified. If the fault persists, go to Step 9.
8. Increase the maximum number of routes that can be received from the peer. Then, check whether the fault is rectified. If the fault persists, go to Step 9.
9. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column1: [ProbableCause]Trap cause.
[EventType]Alarm type
[PhysicalIndex]Physical index
[PhysicalName]Entity name
[RelativeResource]Relevant resource name

[UsageType]Overload type. The value 1 indicates the CPU. The default sampling interval is 10 seconds, and the number of overload sampling times is 48. The value 2 indicates the memory. The default sampling interval is 1 second, and the number of overload sampling times is 2. The value 3 indicates a disk. The value 4 indicates flash memory. The value 5 indicates the CF card. The value 6 indicates the physical memory.
[SubIndex]Entity sub-index
[UsageValue]Storage usage
[Unit]Unit
[UsageThreshold]Threshold
The memory usage exceeded the pre-set overload threshold.
1. Check the memory usage and overload threshold.
�If the memory usage is higher than the overload threshold, go to Step 2.
�If the memory usage is lower than the overload threshold, go to Step 4.

2. Delete unnecessary services and configurations to reduce memory usage, and then check whether the alarm is cleared. When deleting service configurations, submit the configurations in small batches (three to five configurations in a batch)..
�If the alarm is no longer generated, the problem is resolved.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Adjust the overload threshold, and then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is no longer generated, the problem is resolved.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect log files and contact technical support engineers.

column4: TCP/4/SOCKET_TCP_TCP_AO_AUTHEN_FAIL: TCP TCP-AO authentication not success. (tcpConnLocalAddress=[tcpConnLocalAddress], tcpConnLocalPort=[tcpConnLocalPort], tcpConnRemAddress=[tcpConnRemAddress], tcpConnRemPort=[tcpConnRemPort], hwTCPProtocol=[hwTCPProtocol], hwTCPVrfName=[hwTCPVrfName])
column5: The TCP-AO authentication of the TCP connection fails.
column6: [tcpConnLocalAddress]Local IP address of a TCP connection.

column1: [tcpConnLocalPort]Local port number of a TCP connection.
[tcpConnRemAddress]Destination IP address of a TCP connection.
[tcpConnRemPort]Destination port number of a TCP connection.
[hwTCPProtocol]Name of an upper-layer application protocol.
[hwTCPVrfName]VRF name.
Cause 1: TCP-AO was configured on both ends of the TCP connection, but the encryption algorithms or keys in the effective key IDs were inconsistent.
Cause 2: Incomplete TCP-AO is configured on one end.
Cause 3: One end requires TCP-AO to take effect, but the other end is not configured with TCP-AO.

1. Run the display current-configuration command on the devices at both ends of the TCP connection to check whether TCP-AO is configured. If only one end is configured with TCP-AO, configure TCP-AO on the end that is not configured with TCP-AO. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 2. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.

2. Check whether the TCP-AO configurations on both ends are complete. A complete TCP-AO configuration must be bound to a keychain. A key ID must be configured, and the corresponding key ID, algorithm, key, and effective time must be configured in the keychain. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 3. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.

3. Check whether the parameters at both ends are consistent. Ensure that the key-id takes effect at the same time and has the same key and algorithm. For details about the configuration requirements, see the configuration manual. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 4. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.
4. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. END

column6: [hwSrProtocol]Segment Routing protocol that raised the alarm. 1. OSPF: A conflict within the same process in the OSPF protocol, and the prefix-sid in the conflict state displays OSPF. 2. ISIS: A conflict within the same process in the ISIS protocol, and the prefix-sid in the conflict state displays ISIS. 3. OSPF-SR: A conflict between the OSPF protocol and other protocols, the OSPF protocol is not preferred, or the OSPF protocol conflicts between processes, an OSPF process is not preferred, then the hwSrProtocol of the prefix-sid in the conflict state displays OSPF-SR. 4. ISIS-SR: A conflict between the ISIS protocol and other protocols, the ISIS protocol is not preferred, or the ISIS protocol conflicts between processes, an ISIS process is not preferred, then the hwSrProtocol of the prefix-sid in the conflict state displays ISIS-SR. 5. IGP-SR: A conflict between the label of IGP-SR and BGP-SR, the label of IGP-SR is not preferred, then the hwSrProtocol of the prefix-sid in the conflict state displays IGP-SR.

column1: [hwSrProcessId]Process ID
[hwSrPrefixSid]Prefix Sid
[hwSrPrefixAddress]The Prefix Address configured in the Loopback Interface.
[hwSrPrefixAddressMask]Prefix Ip Address Mask.
[hwSrConflictType]Conflict type can be Prefix Sid conflict or Prefix conflict. 1. SidConflict 2. PrefixConflict
[hwSrConflictState]Current conflict state.
Cause 1: The configuration is incorrect.
Cause 2: The prefix on a LoopBack interface is the same as the address of a LoopBack interface on another device.
Cause 3: The SID configured on a LoopBack interface is the same as the SID on another router.
Cause 4: This device is an OSPF ABR, and the LoopBack interfaces of other devices in different areas are configured with the same SID.

1. If an OSPF prefix SID conflict occurs, run the display ospf [ ] routing [ <ip-address> [ <mask> | <mask-length> ] ] command to check the routing entry corresponding to the conflicting prefix. If the value of the Type field is Direct, it indicates that the local device is the conflict advertising source device. Otherwise, the conflict advertising source device is the device identified by the AdverRouter field. You need to run the ospf prefix-sid { absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value> } [ node-disable ] command on the source device to modify the SID configuration.
2. If an IS-IS prefix SID conflict occurs, run the isis prefix-sid { absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value> } [ node-disable ] command on the source device to modify the SID configuration.

3. If an ISIS-SR or ISIS-SR prefix-sid conflict occurs, a conflict occurs between protocols or processes. You need to run the display segment-routing conflict-db segr { { prefix [ <dest-ip> <mask> ] } | { sid [ <sid> ] } } command to view conflict details and run the ospf prefix-sid { absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value> } [ node-disable ] or isis prefix-sid { absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value> } [ node-disable ] command on the source device to modify the SID configuration.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

�If no, go to 3.

column4: DEFEND/4/hwBaseSecurityUrpfDiscardedRateRising_active: Security URPF drop packets alarmed. (ChassisID=[ChassisID], SlotID=[SlotID], CurrentRateLow=[CurrentRateLow], CurrentRateHigh=[CurrentRateHigh], NotifyEnabled=[NotifyEnabled], RateThreshold=[RateThreshold], RateInterval=[RateInterval]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: This alarm was generated when URPF packets were discarded.

column1: [SlotID]Slot ID of an interface board.
[CurrentRateLow]Indicates the least significant 32 bits of traffic statistics.
[CurrentRateHigh]Indicates the most significant 32 bits of traffic statistics.
[NotifyEnabled]Whether the trap function is enabled: 1: enabled 2: disabled
[RateThreshold]Current alarm threshold.
[RateInterval]Current alarm interval.
The number of discarded URPF protocol packets exceeded the alarm threshold.

1. Run the display cpu-defend tcpip-defend statistics slot <slot-id> command to check the committed access rate (CIR) and committed burst rate (CBS) of the interface board. Check the values of Actual CIR in NP and Actual CBS in NP.

�If the protocol rate is too small to meet service requirements, run the car command to increase the rate and wait for 60 seconds. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
�If the configured protocol rate meets service running requirements but the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display cpu-defend policy <policy-number> command to check whether the alarm threshold and alarm interval of the protocol are set properly based on Application apperceive Configuration.
�If the alarm threshold is too low, run the alarm drop-rate command to increase the threshold based on service traffic. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
�If the alarm interval is too small, run the alarm drop-rate command to increase the alarm interval. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.

3. Run the display attack-source-trace slot <slot-id> original-information command to check the Attack Source Data item to check the packet header information cached by the attack source tracing module.

�If the source or destination IP address of a packet is not within the service range, configure an attack defense policy to filter the packet. For details, see Local Attack Defense Configuration in the Configuration Guide. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
�If the source or destination IP address of the packet meets service requirements but the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: EOAM-1AG/3/UNEXPECTEDPERIOD_active: MEP received a CCM with unexpected period. (MdIndex=[MdIndex], MaIndex=[MaIndex], MdName=[MdName], MaName=[MaName], MepId=[MepId], RmepId=[RmepId])

column1: [MdName]Name of an MD
[MaName]Name of an MA
[MepId]ID of a MEP

The CCM interval carried in a CCM sent by the RMEP was different from that specified on the MEP in the scenario where the MEP and RMEP had the same MD level and MA ID, and the MEP was enabled to receive CCMs carrying the specified RMEP ID.

1.Run the display cfm ma [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> ] ] command to view the value of the Interval field on the MEP and RMEP. Check whether the intervals configured on the MEP and RMEP are the same.
�If they are the same, go to Step 3.
�If they are different, go to Step 2.
2.Perform the following steps on the MEP:
�a.Run the cfm md <md-name> command to enter the MD view.

�b.Run the display this command. Check whether the mep ccm-send enable command has been run to enable the MEP to send CCMs and the remote-mep ccm-receive enable command has been run to enable the MEP to receive CCMs.
�c.If the mep ccm-send enable command has been run, run the undo mep ccm-send enable command to disable the MEP from sending CCMs.
�d.If the remote-mep ccm-receive enable command has been run, run the undo remote-mep ccm-receive enable command to disable the MEP from receiving CCMs.

�e.Run the ccm-interval <interval> command to configure the interval between CCMs the same as the interval configured on the RMEP. Then run the remote-mep ccm-receive enable command to enable the MEP to receive CCMs and the mep ccm-send enable command to enable the MEP to send CCMs.
�f.Run the display alarm active command to view the trap. Check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 3.
3.Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

�Cause 1: Neighbor timer expired.
1. Run the ping or ping ipv6 command to check whether the link between PIM neighbors is Up.
�If the link is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the link is Down, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ip routing-table or display ipv6 routing-table command to check whether the unicast route from the local device to the neighbor works properly.
�If the route works properly, go to Step 3.
�If the route works improperly, you can clear the alarm by rectifying the routing fault.
3. Run the display this command in the view of the corresponding PIM neighboring interface to check whether the interface is enabled with PIM-SM.
�If PIM-SM is enabled on the neighboring interface, the IP address of the neighboring interface changes. If the PIM neighbor relationship is not re-established after a certain period, go to Step 4.
�If PIM-SM is not enabled on the neighboring interface, configure the interface enable with PIM-SM.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 3: Interface is down.
1. Run the display interface brief or display ipv6 interface brief command on the device to check whether the protocol layer status of the interface is Up.
�If the protocol status is Up, go to Step 2.
�If the protocol layer status is Down, run the ip address or ipv6 address command to configure an IP address for the interface.
�If the interface is Down, run the undo shutdown command.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 5: Neighbor is deleted.
1. Run the ping or ping ipv6 command to check whether the link between the device and its neighbor is normal.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, check the interface status.
2. Run the display ip routing-table or display ipv6 routing-table command to check whether the unicast route to the neighbor is normal.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, rectify the unicast route fault to clear the alarm.
3. Run the display this command in the corresponding interface view to check whether pim neighbor-policy or pim ipv6 neighbor-policy is configured on the interface.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Run the display acl or display acl ipv6 command to check whether the ACL configuration meets requirements.
�If yes, go to Step 5.
�If no, reconfigure the ACL rules.
5. Run the display this command in the corresponding interface view to check whether pim silent or pim ipv6 silent is configured on the interface.
�If yes, delete the pim silent or pim ipv6 silent configuration.
�If no, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 7: Receive hello cancel message.
1. Run the display this command in the interface view of the neighbor to check whether PIM SM or PIM IPv6 SM is enabled on the interface.
�If PIM SM or PIM IPv6 SM is enabled, go to step 2.
�If PIM-SM or IPv6 PIM-SM is not enabled on the interface, run the pim sm or pim ipv6 sm command on the interface.
2. Run the display ip interface brief or display ipv6 interface brief command to check whether the interface status is Up and whether the interface is configured with an IP address.
�If the protocol status is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the protocol status is Down, run the ip address or ipv6 address command to configure an IP address for the interface.
�If the interface is Down, run the undo shutdown command.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 8: BFD session is down.
1. Run the display this command in the interface view of the neighbor to check whether PIM SM or PIM IPv6 SM is enabled on the interface.
�If PIM SM or PIM IPv6 SM is enabled, go to step 2.
�If PIM-SM or IPv6 PIM-SM is not enabled on the interface, run the pim sm or pim ipv6 sm command on the interface.
2. Run the display ip interface brief or display ipv6 interface brief command to check whether the interface status is Up.
�If the protocol status is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the protocol status is Down, run the ip address or ipv6 address command to configure an IP address for the interface.
�If the interface is Down, run the undo shutdown command.
3. Check whether the route to the peer device is normal using the display ip routing-table or display ipv6 routing-table command.
�If the route is normal, go to Step 4.

column4: INFO/6/IM_SUPPRESS_LOG: Last message repeated [repeat_num] [repeat_times].
column5: Number of repetitions.
column6: [repeat_num]Number of times that the last message is repeated.

column1: [repeat_times]Number of times that the last message is repeated.
If duplicate logs are generated in the system, this log is recorded.

Consecutive duplicate logs refer to the logs with the same ID and parameter content. If there are only two duplicate logs, the system does not generate duplicate statistics logs but generates the original two logs. The system generates duplicate statistics logs only when there are more than two duplicate logs. The log level is the same as the level of the duplicate log that causes the log to be reported.
�This message is informational only, and no action is required.

1. Check whether the corresponding switch on the power panel is turned on.

3. Run the slave switchover command to perform an active/standby switchover. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 6.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Replace the power supply.
Cut off the faulty power supply before replacing it.

column4: DEVM/4/hwIfMonitorOutputRateRising_clear: Interface output flow bandwidth usage resumed below the trap threshold. (Interface=[IfIndex], BandWidthUsage=[hwSubifOutputRatePercentage], TrapThreshold=[hwSubifOutputRateThreshold], InterfaceName=[InterfaceName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

column1: [hwSubifOutputRatePercentage]Incoming traffic statistics
[hwSubifOutputRateThreshold]Alarm threshold for output traffic
[InterfaceName]Name of the interface.

The interface traffic statistics collection period can be configured. The default value is 300s. The average rate of the previous statistics collection period is calculated in every 1/6 of the statistics collection period and then divided by the interface bandwidth to obtain the interface bandwidth usage. If the interface bandwidth usage falls below the interface alarm threshold, the interface rate threshold-crossing alarm is cleared.
This message is informational only, and no action is required.

column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamIgrLSPAva: Ingress enter available state. (IfIndex=[IfIndex], TunnelName=[TunnelName], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType])
column5: The OAM module on the source point detected that the LSP was available.

column1: [TunnelName]Indicates the name of the tunnel.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM ingress: - 0: indicates that the ingress is available. - 1: indicates that the ingress is unavailable.

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: The OAM module on the source point detected that the LSP was available.
This log is informational only, and no action is required.

Neighbor Down Due to LL Down: The OSPF neighbor relationship goes Down because no LLD packet is received within the Dead Time. Neighbor Down Due to Kill Neighbor: The interface or BFD session is Down, or the reset ospf process command is run. In this case, you can check the NeighborDownPrimeReason field to determine the specific cause. Neighbor Down Due to 1-Wayhello Received or Neighbor Down Due to SequenceNum Mismatch: The OSPF status of the local device also goes Down because the peer device first goes Down and sends 1-Way Hello packets to the local device. Neighbor Down Due to AdjOK?: indicates AdjOK. The neighbor relationship went Down because the event timed out. Neighbor Down Due to BadLSreq: The neighbor went Down because the BadLSReq event timed out on the neighbor state machine of the interface.
