column4: RM/4/hwIpv6PrefixThresholdExceed_active: The number of IPv6 prefixes exceeded the threshold. (PrefixCount=[PrefixCount], MaxValue=[MaxValue], ThresholdLowerLimit=[ThresholdLowerLimit], ThresholdUpperLimit=[ThresholdUpperLimit])
column5: The number of IPv6 route prefixes exceeded the alarm threshold.
column6: [PrefixCount]Indicates the number of IPv6 route prefixes in the routing table.

column1: [MaxValue]Indicates the maximum number of IPv6 route prefixes supported by the device.
[ThresholdLowerLimit]Indicates the lower threshold of IPv6 route prefixes.
[ThresholdUpperLimit]Indicates the upper threshold of IPv6 route prefixes.
The number of IPv6 prefixes exceeded the threshold of the routing table.

1. Run the display current-configuration command to check whether the threshold value specified in the ipv6 prefix-limit system threshold-alarm command is too small. - If the threshold value is too small, go to step 2. - If the threshold value is in a proper range, go to step 3. 2. Rerun the ipv6 prefix-limit system threshold-alarm upper-limit <upper-limit-value> lower-limit <lower-limit-value> command to increase the value of <upper-limit-value>. 3. Run the display ipv6 routing-table statistics and display ipv6 routing-table all-vpn-instance statistics commands to check the numbers of IPv6 public and private route prefixes and the number of routes of each protocol that are added to the routing table. Check whether services need these routes or whether the routes are added to the routing table due to incorrect configurations. - If the routes are added to the routing table due to incorrect configurations, go to step 4. - If services need these routes, go to step 5. 4. Adjust the configurations to delete unneeded routes and ensure that the number of IPv6 route prefixes falls below the <lower-limit-value> configured using the ipv6 prefix-limit system threshold-alarm command, then check whether the RM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.145.11.4 hwIpv6PrefixThresholdExceedClear alarm is generated. - If the RM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.145.11.4 hwIpv6PrefixThresholdExceedClear alarm is not generated, go to step 5. - If the RM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.145.11.4 hwIpv6PrefixThresholdExceedClear alarm is generated, go to step 6. 5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. 6. End.

Cause 1: The physical status of the local or remote interface became Down.

�If the physical status of the interface goes Down, run the undo shutdown command to restore the physical status of the interface to Up.

�If the fault is caused by a timeout in receiving EFM OAM PDUs, perform the following operations:
1. Run the display efm command to check whether EFM OAM is disabled on the peer device.
2. If EFM OAM is enabled on the peer device, run the debugging efm command to enable the debugging of the module and check whether packets are received.
3. If the interface does not receive EFM OAM PDUs, check whether the interface is configured to prevent EFM OAM PDUs from being sent to the CPU.
4. If a command is run to prevent EFM OAM PDUs from being sent to the CPU, delete this command.
5. If the device still cannot receive EFM OAM PDUs, stop sending unnecessary EFM OAM PDUs.

column1: [EntPhysicalIndex]Index of the physical entity.
[EntPhysicalName]Name of the physical entity.
[EntityTrapFaultID]Error code.
[ReasonDescription]Indicates the description of the possible cause.
The fiber or optical module on card is abnormal.
1. Check whether the optical fiber fails. If the optical fails, replace it.

2. Check whether the local wavelength and remote wavelength are the same. If they are different, change the channel number. (The WaveLength field in the display this interface command shows the wavelength.)
3. Run the display alarm active command to check whether an alarm is generated on the interface. If the optical module is pluggable, replace the optical module.
4. Run the display alarm active command to check whether an alarm is generated on the remote interface. If the optical module is pluggable, replace the remote optical module.
5. If the optical module is not pluggable or the alarm persists after the optical module is replaced, collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

�Cause 2: The EVPL has been blocked for BD loop, and the loop has already been punished times times.

1. A loop occurs in the BD. The EVPL service is temporarily blocked to eliminate the loop. The blocked EVPL service automatically recovers within the blocking time configured using the loop-detect eth-loop command. If the fault persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

�If there are tunnels of the type configured in the tunnel policy, go to 5.
�If there is no tunnel of the type configured in the tunnel policy, change the tunnel policy used by VPN services.
3. If a binding tunnel policy is used, run the display interface tunnel <interface-number> command to check whether the bound tunnel interface is Up.
�If the bound tunnel interface is Up, go to 5.
�If the bound tunnel interface is not Up, configure the TE interface.
4. Run the display tunnel-info all command to check where there is an LSP.

column4: BGP/2/hwBgpBackwardTransition_active: The BGP FSM moves from a higher numbered state to a lower numbered state. column1: [InstanceId]Instance ID.

[PeerLastError]Error code returned when the peer was disconnected last time. The value of this parameter is displayed in the format of [ErrorCode][ErrorSubCode], where [ErrorCode] indicates an error code and [ErrorSubCode] indicates an error subcode.For example, in the value 35, 3 indicates an error code and 5 indicates an error subcode.For details about error codes, see BGP Packet Format in BGP Principles.The value 0 indicates that no error occurs.
[PeerState]Peer status: 1: indicates that the status is Down. 6: indicates that the status is Up.
[LocalIfName]Local interface name.

[Reason]Cause of the peer disconnection. Configuration lead peer down: The peer is disconnected due to the configuration. Receive notification: A Notification message is received. Receive error packet: An error packet is received. Hold timer expire: The Hold timer expires. Remote peer not reachable: The remote peer is unreachable. Direct connect-interface down: The directly connected interface is Down. Route limit: The number of routes reaches the upper limit. System memory overloaded: The system memory is overloaded.
[Description]Description of a neighbor.
�Cause 1: BGP configuration lead peer down
�Cause 2: BGP receive notification
�Cause 3: BGP receive error packet
�Cause 4: BGP hold timer expire
�Cause 5: BGP remote peer not reachable
�Cause 6: BGP direct connect-interface down
�Cause 7: BGP route exceed the maximum number allowed
�Cause 9: The system memory is overloaded
�Cause 1: BGP configuration lead peer down

1. Check whether the BGP peer relationship is interrupted because of the improper configurations of the local device. - If the configurations of the local device are improper, go to Step 2. - If the configurations of the local device are proper, go to Step 3. 2. Delete the configurations that cause the interruption of the peer relationship. 3. Check whether the BGP connection is reset. If the BGP connection is reset, wait for a while and then check whether the BGP connection is re-established. - If the BGP connection is not reset, go to Step 4. - If the BGP connection is reset, wait for a while and then check whether the BGP connection is re-established. If the BGP connection is not re-established, go to Step 4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: BGP receive notification
1. Run the display bgp peer <ip-address> log-info command to check Notification messages when BGP is disconnected.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 4, the BGP Holdtimer expires and no Keepalive message is received. Go to step 3.
�If the error code is 5, the BGP FSM is faulty. Go to Step 17.
�If the error code in the Notification message is 6, BGP proactively closes the connection. Go to step 2.
2. Run the display bgp peer <ip-address> log-info command to check whether the notification is sent by the device that generates the alarm.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the ping command to check whether the IP address of the BGP peer can be pinged.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Check whether the CPU usage is too high. The command varies according to the device.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If not, go to Step 6.
5. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the BGP peer address routing table exists.
�If yes, go to Step 7.
�If not, go to Step 8.
6. Run the display acl command to check whether an ACL is configured to disable TCP port 179.
�If yes, delete the ACL that denies TCP port 179.
�If not, go to Step 9.
7. Run the display interface command to check whether the outbound interface of the route is Up.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to Step 10.
8. Check the origin of the route to the BGP peer address.
�If the route source is OSPF, go to step 11.
�If the route source is IS-IS, go to Step 12.
9. Check the BGP configuration to see whether the loopback interface is used to establish the BGP connection.
�If yes, go to Step 13.
�If no, go to Step 14.
10. Check whether the shutdown command is run on the interface.
�If so, run the undo shutdown command on the interface. If the alarm persists, go to Step 13.
�If not, go to Step 17.
11. Run the display ospf peer command to check whether the OSPF neighbor relationship is established.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, rectify the fault according to the handling procedure of OSPF_1.3.6.1.2.1.14.16.2.2 ospfNbrStateChange.
12. Run the display isis peer command to check whether the IS-IS neighbor relationship is set up.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, rectify the fault according to the handling procedure of ISIS_1.3.6.1.3.37.2.0.17 isisAdjacencyChange.
13. Check whether the source address used to initiate a BGP connection is specified.
�If yes, go to Step 14.
�If not, run the peer connect-interface command to specify the source address used to initiate the BGP connection.
14. If the BGP peer is an EBGP peer and multiple hops exist between EBGP peers, check whether the peer ebgp-max-hop command is configured.
�If yes, go to Step 15.
�If not, run the peer ebgp-max-hop command.
15. If the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command is run, check whether the TTL of the packet received from the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.
�If yes, go to Step 16.
�If not, run the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command again to ensure that the TTL of the packets sent to the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.

16. Contact the maintenance personnel of the peer device to check whether BGP is reset on the peer device, whether the peer enable command is used to enable the peer in another address family on the local device, or whether BGP connection parameters are set. If any of the preceding operations is performed, wait for a while and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 17.
17. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 3: BGP receive error packet

1. Run the display bgp peer <ip-address> log-info command to check the Notification packet sent by the local device when the BGP peer relationship is interrupted. - If the value of the Error Code field in the Notification packet is 1, a packet with an error header has been received. Go to Step 2. - If the value of the Error Code field in the Notification packet is 2, an error Open packet has been received. Go to Step 2. - If the value of the Error Code field in the Notification packet is 3, an error Update packet has been received. Go to Step 2. 2. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 4: BGP hold timer expire
1. Run the ping command to check whether the IP address of the BGP peer can be pinged.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If not, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the CPU usage is too high. The command varies according to the device.
�If yes, go to Step 15.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the BGP peer address routing table exists.

(Index=[Index], ConfigurationName=[ConfigurationName], BindIfIndex=[BindIfIndex], BindIfName=[BindIfName], Diagnosis=[Diagnosis], BindVrfIndex=[BindVrfIndex], BindVpnName=[BindVpnName], SessionType=[SessionType], BindType=[BindType], StaticLspName=[StaticLspName], PwSecondary=[PwSecondary], VcId=[VcId], VsiName=[VsiName], VsiPeerAddress=[VsiPeerAddress], DiscrAuto=[DiscrAuto], PeerIpv6=[PeerIpv6], Ipv6NextHop=[Ipv6NextHop], EvplId=[EvplId])

column1: [ConfigurationName]BFD session name
[BindIfIndex]Bound interface index
[BindIfName]Bound interface name

[Diagnosis]Session diagnostic word 0: No diagnostic word 1: Detection time Down 2: Echo detection Down 3: Neighbor advertisement Down 4: Forwarding plane reset 5: Path Down 6: Cascading path Down 7: Administratively Down 8: Reverse cascading path Down 9: Peer administratively Down 25: IP error code stop 26: IP error code start 27: Section error code stop 28: Section error code start 29: LSP error code stop 30: LSP ingress error code start 31: LSP transit error code start
[BindVrfIndex]Index of the bound VPN instance
[BindVpnName]Name of the bound VPN instance

[SessionType]Indicates the type of a session. 1: static, which indicates that the BFD session is statically configured. 2: Dynamic, which indicates that the BFD session is dynamically triggered. 3: Entire_Dynamic: indicates that a BFD session is dynamically triggered. After the function of passively creating a BFD session is enabled on the egress of the LSP, the BFD session is created. 4: Static_Auto: indicates a static BFD session with automatically negotiated discriminators.

[BindType]Bound type: 2 or 3: Peer IP address (multi-hop IP link detection). 1 or 4: Interface (single-hop IP link detection). 9: LDP_LSP (LDP LSP detection). 11: TE_LSP (detection of the LSP bound to a TE tunnel). 12: TE_TUNNEL (TE tunnel detection). 13: PW (PW link detection). 15: VSI_PW (VSI PW link detection).
[StaticLspName]Static LSP name The value is always -.
[PwSecondary]Secondary PW flag. 1: primary PW. 2: secondary PW. 3: non-PW link.
[VcId]VC ID
[VsiName]VSI name
[VsiPeerAddress]VSI peer address
[DiscrAuto]Static auto-negotiation discriminator
[PeerIpv6]Bound destination IPv6 address
[Ipv6NextHop]Next hop IPv6 address
[EvplId]ID of an EVPL instance
Cause 1: The interface to which the session is bound went Down.
Cause 2: The peer BFD session was deleted or shut down.
Cause 3: The link went Down or was blocked, which Cause s a forwarding failure.
1. Run the display interface command to check whether the physical state of the interface bound to the session is Up.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the session state is automatically restored.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display bfd session all command to check whether the BFD sessions are deleted on the two ends.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Run the ping ip-address command to check whether the link monitored by the BFD session is working properly.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

column4: ISIS/3/ISIS_AUTHENTICATION_FAILURE: The authentication password of received PDU is different from local configuration. (isisSysInstance=[isisSysInstance], isisSysLevelIndex=[isisSysLevelIndex], isisCircIndex=[isisCircIndex], isisCircIfIndex=[isisCircIfIndex], isisPduFragment=[isisPduFragment], ifIndex=[ifIndex], IfName=[IfName])
column5: The authentication password contained in the received PDU is inconsistent with the locally configured one.

column1: [isisSysLevelIndex]IS-IS level
[isisCircIndex]Circuit index of an interface
[isisCircIfIndex]IfIndex of an interface
[isisPduFragment]64-byte PDU header
[ifIndex]IfIndex of an interface
[IfName]Interface name
Authentication was configured on an interface or a process of the local end.
The authentication type configured on the peer end was the same as that configured on the local end, but the authentication passwords configured on the two ends were different.
1. Obtain the IS-IS process number and packet type (1 indicates a Level-1 packet
column3: 3 indicates a P2P Hello packet) contained in the PDU based on the command output. Then, find the isisPduFragment field and obtain the system ID of the source device that sends the packet and packet type.

column1: �If the packet type is Hello, go to Step 2.
�If the packet type is LSP or SNP, go to Step 4.

2. Determine the IS-IS interface of the source device based on the system ID. Run the display this command in the interface view of the source device to check whether the configured interface authentication password is the same as that of the local device.
�If the interface authentication passwords on the two ends are the same, go to Step 6.
�If the interface authentication passwords on the two ends are different, go to Step 3.

3. Run the isis authentication-mode command in the interface view of the source device to configure the authentication password to be the same as that on the local device. Then, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 7.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 6.

4. Run the display current-configuration configuration isis command on the source device to check whether the area authentication password or domain authentication password configured in the IS-IS process is the same as that on the local device.
�If the area authentication passwords or domain authentication passwords on the two ends are the same, go to Step 6.
�If the area authentication passwords or domain authentication passwords on the two ends are different, go to Step 5.

5. Run the area-authentication-mode command (Level-1 packet) or the domain-authentication-mode command (Level-2 packet) in the IS-IS view of the source device to configure the authentication password to be the same as that of the local device. Then, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 7.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 6.
6. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

SubCard backup control bus failed.
1. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3. Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4. If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5. If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6. If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7. If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.

9. End.

column5: The number of ASE LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imported external routes exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.

column1: [hwOspfv3Threshold]Upper alarm threshold configured for the number of ASE LSAs
The number of ASE LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imported external routes exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.

1. Run the display ospfv3 command to check whether the number of ASE LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imported external routes exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.
�If the number exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If the number has not exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, go to Step 2.

Check the overload status based on the value of the Current status field in the display ospfv3 command output. Normal: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imports external routes is less than or equal to the lower alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed. Approach limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imports external routes is approaching (reaching or exceeding 90% of) the upper alarm threshold. Exceed limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPFv3 process imports external routes has reached or exceeded the maximum number allowed.
2. Perform the following operations as required:

�If a change in the limit on the number of ASE LSAs is allowed, run the import-route limit <limit-number> [ threshold-alarm upper-limit <upper-limit-value> lower-limit <lower-limit-value> ] command to change the limit.
�If a change in the limit on the number of ASE LSAs is not allowed, go to Step 3.
3. Contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

Two MPUs of a CLC were connected to the same ICU.
1. View the EntPhysicalName field in alarm information. Check which two interfaces form a ring.

2. Remove the cables of the corresponding interfaces. Note that the alarm generated when the device is started with a ring will not be cleared after the ring is broken. You must run a command to clear the alarm or restart the device.
3. Connect the cables as specified.

OSPF
column4: OSPF/2/ospfMaxRecvLsaExceed_active: The number of LSAs learned by OSPF exceeded the threshold. (hwOspfv2ProcessIdIndex=[hwOspfv2ProcessIdIndex], hwOspfv2RecvLsaUpper=[hwOspfv2RecvLsaUpper])
column5: This alarm is reported when the number of LSAs learned by an OSPF process exceeds the threshold.

column1: [hwOspfv2RecvLsaUpper]Upper threshold for the number of LSAs learned by OSPF.
When other processes in the OSPF domain import routes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrect. As a result, the local device learns a large number of LSAs.

1. Run the display ospf brief command to check the Alarm Status field in the command output to determine whether the number of LSAs exceeds the threshold. Normal indicates that the number of LSAs does not exceed 90% of the alarm threshold. Exceed indicates that the number of LSAs reaches or exceeds the alarm threshold.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to step 4.

2. Run the display this command in the OSPF process for which the alarm is generated to check whether an import policy is configured on the source device that advertises LSAs or whether an improper import policy is configured. As a result, a large number of LSAs are imported and the local device learns a large number of LSAs.

�If no import policy is configured, run the import-route { direct | static | bgp [ permit-ibgp ] | { ospf | isis | rip } [ < process-id > ] } { route-policy <route-policy-name> | route-filter <route-filter-name> } command to configure an import policy to restrict the number of imported routes. After the configuration is complete, check whether the alarm is cleared. If yes, no further action is required. If no, go to Step 3.

�If an import policy is configured but the configuration is improper, run the import-route { direct | static | bgp [ permit-ibgp ] | { ospf | isis | rip } [ < process-id > ] } { route-policy <route-policy-name> | route-filter <route-filter-name> } command to modify the corresponding policy. After the configuration is complete, check whether the alarm is cleared. If yes, no further action is required. If no, go to Step 3.
�If the import policy is correctly configured, go to step 3.
3. Run the maximum received-lsa threshold <value> command to adjust the threshold for learning LSAs and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If yes, no further action is required.
�If no, go to step 4.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.

4. End.

column5: The SSH user logged out.
column6: [ServiceType]Service type, such as STelnet, SNETCONF, and SFTP.

column1: [LogoutReason]User logout reason.
[UserName]Login user name.
[Tei]Tei.
[TransNo]Transaction ID.
Cause 1: The SSH client requests to disconnect from the SSH server.
Cause 2: The CLI requests to disconnect the connection.
Cause 3: The SSH service port changes.
Cause 4: The SSH service is disabled.
Cause 5: The idle time reaches the maximum value.
Cause 1: This log message is informational only, and no action is required.
Cause 2: This log message is informational only, and no action is required.
Cause 3: Run the display ssh server status command to check the correct SSH service port number and use the correct port number to log in.
Cause 4: Run the stelnet [ ipv4 | ipv6 ] server enable command to enable the STelnet service on the SSH server.
Cause 5: Log in again and run the idle-timeout minutes [ seconds ] command to set the timeout period for disconnecting from the user interface.

column4: AAA/6/REMOTE_ACCOUNT_LOCK: Remote account [account] has been locked. (OperatorName=[operateUserName],UserIp=[OperatorIPAddress])
column5: The remote account has been locked.

column1: [operateUserName]Operation user name.
[OperatorIPAddress]IP address of the operator.

After the function of locking an account that fails remote AAA authentication is enabled using the administrator remote authen-fail command, if a user uses remote AAA authentication (RADIUS or HWTACACS authentication) and enters incorrect accounts or passwords for consecutive times within the configured retry time, the account is locked.
1. If the account is incorrectly locked or needs to be enabled in an emergency, run the remote-user authen-fail unblock command to unlock the account.

2. If the account is not locked due to misoperations, the administrator can further determine whether an unauthorized user is cracking the account or password and enhance account protection on the RADIUS or HWTACACS server.

Fuse <slotid> is failed, Fuse is absent.
1. Locate the faulty fuse.
2. Check whether a fuse component needs to be inserted into the position.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 5.
3. Insert the fuse into the position where the alarm is generated, and then check whether the fault is rectified.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.
PTP
column4: PTP/4/hwPtpTimeSyncFaulty_active: Time source traced status is faulty. (hwPtpTimeSynchronizationStatus=[hwPtpTimeSynchronizationStatus]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The device lost the clock synchronization relationship.
column6: [hwPtpTimeSynchronizationStatus]Whether the device is in the synchronization or out-of-synchronization state. The values are as follows: unsynchronization(1). synchronization(2).

column1: Cause1: The link was faulty or the interface went Down, and as a result, the device failed to keep track of the clock source.
Cause2: The priority of the local device was set so high that the local device is in local state, and it will not trace other clock source.
1. Run the display device command to check whether the interface board is registered.
If the interface board cannot be registered, it indicates that the hardware of the interface board is faulty. Replace the interface board.
If the board can be registered after being reset and the link fault is rectified, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ptp all command to check whether the device is in the local state.
If so, go to Step 3.
If no, go to Step 6.
3. Run the display ptp all command to check whether the status of the external BITS is normal.
If so, go to Step 4.
If not, go to Step 6.
4. Run the ptp clock-source local priority1 <priority1-value> command to correctly configure the clock parameters of the device.
5. After the parameters are configured, run the display ptp all command to check whether the device is still in the local state.
If so, go to Step 6.
If not, go to Step 7.
6. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

column4: DEVM/3/hwSdbereAlarm_active: Exceeding block error B2 counter in the multiplex section alarm. (hwPhysicalPortIfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],BoardID=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardID=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortID=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The signal bit error rate detected by the B2 byte in the multiplex section exceeded the alarm threshold (the default value is 1*10-6).

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
�Cause 0: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column1: [EntPhysicalName]The index for this entry.

[Reason]Reason.
[EntPhysicalIndex]The index for this entry.
�Cause 143360: The board was improperly installed.
�Cause 143361: The subcard was installed unstably.
�Cause 143362: The fan was installed unstably.
�Cause 143360: The board was improperly installed.
1. If the board runs no services after being inserted into the slot, check whether the board is properly inserted, whether there are bent pins, or whether the board connector is faulty.
2. If the board is not properly inserted, insert the board properly.
3. If there are bent pins, do not insert a new board into this slot. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. If the board connector is faulty, replace the board.
5. If the board runs services normally after being inserted into the slot, collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.
�Cause 143361: The subcard was installed unstably.

1.If the faulty subcard is just installed and no service is run, pull out the subcard and check whether any bent or broken pins exist on the connector of the subcard and the slot where the subcard resides.

2.If the slot where the subcard resides has bent or broken pins, do not install a new subcard into the faulty slot. Collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3.If only the connector of the subcard has bent or broken pins, replace the subcard.
4.Install the subcard securely, for example, tighten screws to fix the subcard.
5.If services on the subcard become normal but the alarm persists, collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6.End.
�Cause 143362: The fan was installed unstably.
1.Check if the fan is properly installed, if pins have bent, and if the fan connectors become faulty.
2.If the fan is not properly installed, re-install it.
3.If the pins on the backplane have bent, do not install a new fan into the faulty slot. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
4.If only the fan connectors are found faulty, replace the fan with a new one.
5.If services on the fan are abnormal, collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
6.End.

column6: [ProcessID]Indicates the ID of an MSTP process.

column1: [InstanceID]Indicates the instance ID.
The number of TC messages received by an MSTP process in a specified period exceeded the threshold.
1. Check whether network topology flapping occurs.
�If network flapping occurs, go to Step 3.
�If no network flapping occurs, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display stp command to check whether the number of TC BPDUs on the interface exceeds the threshold.
�If the number of TC BPDUs on the interface exceeds the threshold, go to Step 4.
�If the number of TC BPDUs on the interface does not exceed the threshold, go to Step 7.
3. Check the cause of network topology flapping and rectify the fault. Check whether the fault is rectified. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.

4. Run the stp tc-protection threshold <threshold> command in the MSTP process view to re-set the number of TC BPDUs that the MSTP process can process. Check whether the fault is rectified. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Check whether malicious attacks exist.
�If malicious attacks exist, go to step 6.
�If no malicious attack exists, go to step 7.
6. Find out the attack source and rectify the fault. Then, check whether the fault is rectified. If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
7. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

[TunnelId]Indicates the tunnel ID on the sink point.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM ingress. - 0: Available. - 1: Unavailable.

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: The LSP fault checked by the OAM egress was rectified.

column4: L3VPN/2/L3V_TRAP_THRE_EXCEED_active: The number of prefixes in the VPN instance exceeded the maximum value. (VpnInstanceName=[VpnInstanceName], VpnInstanceRouteCount=[VpnInstanceRouteCount], MaxValue=[MaxValue])
column5: The number of public network route prefixes exceeded the maximum limit, or the number of VPN route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeded the maximum limit.
column6: [VpnInstanceName]Indicates the name of a VPN instance. If a VPN instance name is _public_, the alarm cause is that the number of public network route prefixes exceeds the maximum limit.

column1: [VpnInstanceRouteCount]Indicates the number of existing route prefixes.
[MaxValue]Indicates that the maximum number of route prefixes allowed.
Cause 1: The number of received public network route prefixes exceeded the maximum number of route prefixes configured for the IPv4 public network routing table.
Cause 2: The number of received VPN route prefixes exceeded the maximum number of VPN route prefixes defined in the license file or that configured for the routing table of the VPN instance.

Cause1: The number of public network route prefixes in the public network routing table exceeded the maximum limit. 1. Run the display ip routing-table limit command to check the maximum limit for public network route prefixes. 2. Run the display ip routing-table statistics command to check whether the number of existing public network route prefixes exceeds the maximum limit. - If so, go to Step 4. - If not, go to Step 3. 3. Check whether the number of public network route prefixes exceeds the maximum limit after deleting excess public network routes. - If so, go to Step 5. - If not, go to Step 6. 4. In the system view, run the display this command to check whether the ip prefix-limit command configuration is appropriate. - If so, go to Step 5. - If not, run the ip prefix-limit <number> { <alert-percent> [ route-unchanged ] | simply-alert } command to set an appropriate maximum limit for public network route prefixes. Then, go to Step 6. 5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. 6. End. Cause2: The number of VPN route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeded the maximum limit. 1. Run the display ip routing-table limit vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> command to check whether the number of VPN route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeds the upper limit. 2. Run the display ip routing-table vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> statistics command to check whether the number of existing VPN route prefixes in the VPN instance meets the requirements. - If so, go to Step 4. - If not, go to Step 3. 3. Check whether the number of VPN route prefixes still exceeds the maximum limit specified in the license or specified using the prefix limit command after deleting excess VPN routes. - If so, go to Step 5. - If not, go to Step 6. 4. Enter the VPN instance view and run the display this command to check the configuration of the prefix limit command. Check whether the maximum limit for VPN route prefixes is appropriate. - If so, go to Step 5. - If not, run the prefix limit <number> { <alert-percent> | simply-alert } command to set an appropriate maximum limit for VPN route prefixes. Then, go to Step 6. 5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. 6. End.

column4: SSH/5/SSH_USER_LOGIN_FAIL_SCHD: Failed to login through SSH [failed_count] time(s) in last [time_gap] minute(s).
column5: The SSH user failed to log in for multiple times within 1 minute.

column1: [time_gap]Interval.
Cause 1: The SSH user does not exist.
Cause 2: The RSA, DSA, or ECC does not exist.
Cause 3: The user name or password is incorrect.
Cause 4: The SSH service is disabled.
Cause 5: The number of users connected to the SSH server reaches the upper limit.
Cause 6: An ACL rule matches the IP address of a user and the action is deny.
The troubleshooting procedures for different causes are as follows:
Cause 1: Run the display ssh user-information command to check the configurations of all SSH users.
�If no SSH user is created, run the ssh user command to create an SSH user.
�If an SSH user has been created, perform other steps.

Cause 2: Run the display rsa local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local RSA key pair. Run the display ecc local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local ECC key pair. Run the display dsa local-key-pair public command to check information about the public key in the local DSA key pair.
�If no RSA key pair is configured, run the rsa local-key-pair create command to generate a local RSA key pair.
�If no ECC key pair is configured, run the ecc local-key-pair create command to generate a local ECC key pair.
�If no DSA key pair is configured, run the dsa local-key-pair create command to generate a local DSA key pair.
Cause 3: Ensure that the user name and password are correct.
Cause 4: Ensure that the SSH service is enabled.
Cause 5: Ensure that the number of users connected to the SSH server does not reach the maximum value.
Cause 6: Run the display acl command to check ACL rules.
�If the user IP address is matched and the action is deny, run the acl and rule commands in sequence to change the action to permit.
�If the user IP address is not matched and the action is deny, perform other steps.
2. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column4: VRRP/4/vrrpTrapNonMaster: The VRRP status changed between backup and initialize. (ifIndex=[ifIndex], VrId=[VrId], MasterIpAddr=[MasterIpAddr], sysName=[sysName], ifName=[ifName], CurrentState=[CurrentState], ChangeReason=[ChangeReason])

column1: [VrId]VRID of the VRRP group

[CurrentState]Initialize Backup
[ChangeReason]Status change reason
The VRRP status changes from Backup to Initialize. Possible causes are as follows:
Cause 1: The device on which the VRRP group is configured is faulty.
Cause 2: The interface on which the VRRP group is configured or the directly connected link is faulty.
The VRRP status changes from Initialize to Backup.
Possible causes are as follows:
Cause 1. The device on which the VRRP group is configured recovers from a fault.
Cause 2: The VRRP-enabled interface or the directly connected link recovered.
1. Check whether the value of CurentState is Initialize or Backup.
�If the value of CurentState is Initialize, go to Step 2.
�If the value of CurentState is Backup, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the interface on which the VRRP group is configured or the link monitored by BFD that is associated with VRRP is Up.
�If the interface on which the VRRP group is configured is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the link monitored by BFD that is associated with VRRP is Up, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display this interface command in the view of the interface on which the VRRP group is configured to check the physical and protocol statuses of the interface.
�If the physical status of the interface is Down, the link connected to the interface fails. Rectify the fault and check whether the VRRP group has recovered.
�If the VRRP group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP group has not recovered, go to Step 5.

�If the physical status of the interface is Up but its protocol status is Down, the IP address of the interface has been deleted. Reassign an IP address to the interface and check whether the VRRP group has recovered.
�If the VRRP group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP group has not recovered, go to Step 5.

�If the physical and protocol statuses of the interface are both Up, the IP address of the interface is not on the same network segment as the virtual IP address of the VRRP group. Reassign an IP address to the interface and ensure that the IP address is on the same network segment as the virtual IP address of the VRRP group. Then check whether the VRRP group has recovered.
�If the VRRP group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP group has not recovered, go to Step 5.
4. Run the display vrrp command and check whether the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is UP.
�If the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is DOWN, the original standby link fails. Rectify the fault and check whether the VRRP group has recovered.
�If the VRRP group has recovered, go to Step 6.
�If the VRRP group has not recovered, go to Step 5.
�If the value of BFD-Session State in the command output is UP, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

�Cause 0: The configurations of flag j1 is incorrect.
�Cause 1: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 2: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 3: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 4: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 5: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1. Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
2. Check whether the flag j1 configuration of the peer device is correct. If it is incorrect, change the configuration and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
3. Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.

4. Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.

5. Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
6. Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
7. Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
8. Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
9. Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 10.
10. Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: L2IF/4/hwMacLimitNumRaisingThreshold_active: The port learned mac-address number rising threshold. (PortIndex=[port_index], VlanId=[Vlan_ID], BDId=[BD_ID], VsiName=[vsi_name], PortNum=[port_num], BaseTrapSeverity=[Base_Severity], BaseTrapProbableCause=[trap_cause], BaseTrapEventType=[trap_event], LearnNumber=[learn_number], LimitNumber=[limit_number], PortName=[port_name], EvpnName=[evpn_name]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The number of MAC addresses learned by the interface reached the limit.

column1: [Vlan_ID]VLAN ID.
[BD_ID]BD ID.
[vsi_name]Name of a VSI.
[port_num]Indicates the port number.
[Base_Severity]NMS alarm severity.
[trap_cause]Alarm cause value.
[trap_event]Alarm event type.
[learn_number]Number of learned MAC addresses.
[limit_number]Maximum number of MAC addresses.
[port_name]Port name
[evpn_name]EVPN name.
MAC address limit was configured and the alarm function for MAC address limit was enabled. The number of learned dynamic MAC addresses reached the configured upper limit.
Method 1:
1. Run the mac-limit maximum <max> rate <interval> command to increase the maximum number of MAC addresses that can be learned,
a) If the alarm is generated due to MAC address limit in a VLAN, run the mac-limit action discard maximum <max> rate <interval> command in the VLAN view.
b) If the alarm is generated due to MAC address learning limit on an interface in a VLAN, run the mac-limit vlan <vlanid> action discard alarm enable maximum <max> rate <interval> command.
Check whether the alarm is cleared.
If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 3.
If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
Method 2:
1. Run the undo mac-address command to manually delete some or all MAC addresses,
a) If the alarm is generated due to MAC address limit in a VLAN, run the undo mac-address dynamic vlan <vlanid> command to delete some or all MAC addresses in the VLAN.
b) If the alarm is generated due to MAC address learning limit on an interface in a VLAN, run the undo mac-address vlan <vlanid> command to delete MAC addresses from the interface in the VLAN.
Check whether the alarm is cleared.
If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 3.
If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

The number of ASE LSAs generated when an OSPF process imported external routes exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.

1. Run the display ospf brief command to check whether the number of ASE LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.
�If the number exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If the number has not exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, go to Step 2.
Check the overload status based on the value of the Current status field in the display ospf brief command output.
�Normal: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes is less than or equal to the lower alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed.
�Approach limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes is approaching (reaching or exceeding 90% of) the upper alarm threshold.
�Exceed limit: The number of LSAs generated when an OSPF process imports external routes has reached or exceeded the maximum number allowed.
2. Perform the following operations as required:

�If a change in the limit on the number of ASE LSAs is allowed, run the import-route limit <limit-number> [ threshold-alarm upper-limit <upper-limit-value> lower-limit <lower-limit-value> ] command to change the limit.
�If a change in the limit on the number of ASE LSAs is not allowed, go to Step 3.
3. Contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

column1: [VCType]Indicates the VC type.
[VCID]Indicates the L2VC ID.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an ingress:

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: [BdiDefectType]Indicates the BDI defect type.
The L2VC monitored by OAM entered the defective state, and the MEP did not receive CCMs from the RMEP within five consecutive intervals.
1. Run the display mpls oam l2vc command to check whether the MEP and RMEP configurations are correct.
�If the MEP and RMEP configurations are correct, go to Step 2.
�If the MEP and RMEP configurations are incorrect, go to Step 4.
2. Run the display interface command to check whether any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down.
�If any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 4.
�If no physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 3.
3. Run the undo shutdown command to enable the physical interface, and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 5.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 4.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: IFNET/4/hwIfControlFlapSuppress_active: The state of interface changed from unsuppress to suppress. (InterfaceIndex=[InterfaceIndex], InterfaceExtIndex=[InterfaceExtIndex], InterfaceName=[InterfaceName], SuppressState=[SuppressState])
column5: After the flapping control function is configured on an interface, the interface became suppressed.

column1: [InterfaceExtIndex]Extended interface index
[InterfaceName]Interface name
[SuppressState]Interface suppression status: 0: The interface is not suppressed. 1: The interface is suppressed.

The interface had the flapping control function configured. When the interface alternated between Up and Down frequently, the interface became suppressed. The number of the interface flapping times that triggers the suppression alarm depends on the control-flap command configuration.

1. Check the physical link. Interface flapping usually results from a physical link fault or link instability during a short time.If the physical link works improperly, you need to check whether the hardware such as the network cable or optical module is disconnected or loosely connected and correctly connect the physical link and then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 2.
�If the alarm is generated on a physical interface, check whether the physical link of the interface works properly.
�If the alarm is generated on a sub-interface, check whether the physical link of the main interface works properly.
�If the alarm is generated on a trunk interface, check whether the physical links of the trunk member interfaces work properly.
2. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: SNMP/4/SNMP_IPUNLOCKSTAT: In the last 5 minutes, [NUM] IP addresses were unlocked. (IPList=[IPList])
column5: IP addresses unlocked in the last 5 minutes were recorded in combined mode.

column1: [IPList]List of locked IP addresses. If a large number of locked IP addresses cannot be completely displayed in one log, they are displayed in multiple logs.

When the number of IP addresses in the locking record exceeds three, the system does not separately record unlocking logs for newly locked IP addresses. Instead, the system records combined logs every 5 minutes. The list of IP addresses that are unlocked within 5 minutes is recorded in the combined unlocking log.
1. Check whether the community string corresponding to the source IP address or the SNMPv3 user name and password are correct.
2. Check whether the source IP address in the IP address list recorded in the log is valid.

column4: TRANSMISSION-ALARM/3/hwPrefecTcaAlarm_active: PreFec tca detected alarm. (IfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],SlotId=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardId=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortId=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: Pre-FEC BER threshold-crossing alarm.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
Cause 1: The input optical power of the optical interface is excessively high or low.
Cause 2: The optical fiber is bent heavily.
Cause 3: The optical fiber connector is unclean.
Cause 4: The optical module is installed loosely or the optical module is faulty.
Cause 5: The FEC modes of two connected boards are different.
Cause 6: The board that reports the alarm is faulty.
Cause 7: The remote board is faulty.
Cause 8: The loss and reflection of the connector between optical cables are large.
Cause 1: The input optical power of the optical interface is excessively high or low.
1. Check whether the optical power of the optical interface is abnormal.
Cause 2: The optical fiber is bent excessively.
1. Check the fiber jumper. If the fiber jumper is bent too much, damaged, or aged, adjust or replace the fiber jumper.
Cause 3: The fiber connectors at both ends are dirty.
1. Check the fiber connector. If the fiber connector is dirty, clean or replace the fiber. For details, see Checking and Cleaning Fiber Connectors.
Cause 4: The optical module is not securely inserted or is faulty.
1. If the optical module is pluggable, check whether it is securely installed. If yes, reinstall the optical module. If the alarm persists, replace the optical module.
Cause 5: The FEC modes of the two interconnected boards are different.
1. Check whether the FEC modes of the two interconnected boards are the same. If not, change the FEC modes to ensure that they are the same.
Cause 6: The board or optical module that reports the alarm is faulty.
1. Use an optical fiber to perform a self-loop on the optical port. If the alarm is cleared, the optical module and the board are normal.
Cause 7: The peer board or optical module is faulty.
1. Use an optical fiber to perform a self-loop on the optical port. If the alarm is cleared, the optical module and the board are normal.
Cause 8: The loss and reflection of the intermediate connector of the optical cable are large.

1. Disconnect the peer optical fiber and use the OTDR to test the loss and reflection of each link and node at the local end. Check whether the loss and reflection of each link and node are normal (splicing connector loss < 0.3 dB/node, connector loss < 0.75 dB/node, and connector reflection < &#xfffd
column3: 30 dB/node). If the loss and reflection exceed the requirements, in this case, handle the abnormal port.

column1: 2. Based on the distance of the abnormal point in the OTDR test result, locate the equipment room where the port is located and preliminarily determine the port location. Disconnect the port and perform the OTDR test on the port that reports the alarm to check whether the distance is consistent with the previous test. If not, continue to test other ports.
3. After locating the abnormal port, use a fiberscope to check the port. If the port is contaminated, clean it. For details, see Checking and Cleaning Fiber Connectors.

4. After the ports are cleaned, restore the ports and tighten the connectors. Perform an OTDR test on the ports that report alarms to check whether the loss and reflection of each link and node are normal.
5. If the fault persists, replace the flange plate and perform an OTDR test on the port that reports the alarm to check whether the loss and reflection of each link and node are normal.
6. If the fault persists, replace the fiber and perform an OTDR test on the port that reports the alarm to check whether the loss and reflection of each link and node are normal.
7. If there are multiple abnormal points on the link, repeat steps 2 to 6.

column4: LDP/4/LDP_SSN_INIT_EXCEED: The number of session initialization messages exceeds the mplsLdpEntityInitSessionThreshold. (PeerLdpId=[PeerLdpId],EntityIndex=[EntityIndex],Times=[InitSessionThreshold])
column5: mplsLdpEntityInitSessionThreshol was not zero and the sequence number of an Initialization message exceeded mplsLdpEntityInitSessionThreshold.

column1: [EntityIndex]LDP instance index
[InitSessionThreshold]Indicates the number of attempts for session negotiation through Init messages.

�Cause 1: The local end no longer supports the DoD mode but the peer supports DoD mode, leading to label advertisement mode inconsistency. Cause 2: Keepalive time negotiation fails because the Keepalive time value on the peer end is set to 0. In this version, the minimum value is 30.This means the log is displayed when the peer Keepalive time is 0s.
1. Check whether both ends are Huawei devices.
If so, go to Step 2.
If not, go to Step 3.

2. Check whether the label advertisement modes configured on both ends are the same. Run the display mpls ldp peer command to check neighbors. The value of must be the same as the value of the PeerLdpId field in the alarm information.

Check whether the mpls ldp advertisement dod/du command configurations on the interfaces corresponding to Peer Discovery Source in the command output are the same as those on the remote peer. If they are different, configure them to be the same. Then run the display mpls ldp session command to check the session status.
If the status of the neighbor is Operational, go to Step 4. Otherwise, go to Step 5.
3. Check whether the Keepalive protection time configured on the peer device is 0.
�If so, change the value to a non-zero value.
�If not, go to Step 5.
4. The session has gone Up again. This indicates that the fault is caused by inconsistent label advertisement modes. No further action is required.
5. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

3. If the failure port or peer port is in managing down status, then enter the interface view and run the undo shutdown command, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If so, go to End.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column5: The local device received a flush LSA from a neighbor indicating that the OSPFv3 LSAs advertised by a third device were flushed. Possibly faulty devices do not support OSPFv3 flush LSA source tracing. In this case, log in to a possibly faulty node and check whether it is flushing LSAs. If it is flushing LSAs, reset or isolate it. If the possibly faulty node is not flushing LSAs, check other possibly faulty nodes. To check the analysis report output by OSPFv3 flush LSA source tracing, run the display ospfv3 flush-source-trace analysis-info command.

OSPFv3 routes advertised by another device were deleted, and the possibly faulty device did not support OSPFv3 flush LSA source trace.

1. Log in to the suspected faulty device and run the display ospfv3 routing command to check whether routes are deleted. If routes are being deleted from the suspected faulty device, isolate the faulty device from the network (reset or isolate the faulty device). Otherwise, check other devices.

column4: PIM/4/NBR_LOSS_NORMAL: The PIM neighbor was lost. (NbrIntIndex=[NbrIntIndex], NbrAddrType=[NbrAddrType], NbrAddr=[NbrAddr], NbrUpTime=[NbrUpTime] seconds)
column5: The PIM neighbor relationship is lost.

column1: [NbrAddrType]Address type of the neighboring interface
[NbrAddr]Address of the neighboring interface
[NbrUpTime]Lifetime of the neighbor relationship
Cause 1: The physical link was faulty.
Cause 2: The hardware of the neighbor was faulty.
Cause 3: Protocol configurations for the neighbor were incorrect.
1. Run the ping command to check whether the link between the device and its lost PIM neighbor is Up.
�If the link is Up, go to Step 4.
�If the link is not Up, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ip interface command on the neighbor to check whether the neighboring interface is physically Up and then whether the protocol status is Up.
�If the protocol status is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the protocol status is not Up, configure an IP address for the interface.
3. Check whether the interface is physically Up.
�If the interface is physically Up, go to Step 4.
�If the interface is not physically Up, check the interface board.
4. Run the display this command in the interface view of the neighbor to check whether PIM-SM is enabled on the neighboring interface.

�If PIM-SM is enabled on the neighboring interface, PIM neighbor loss is caused by the change of the IP address of the neighboring interface. If the PIM neighbor relationship cannot be re-established after a certain period, go to Step 5.
�If PIM-SM is not enabled on the neighboring interface, run the pim sm command in the interface view to enable PIM-SM.
5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

1. Check whether a local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated.
�If a local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated, go to Step 3.
�If no local loopback is configured on the interface where the alarm is generated, go to Step 2.
2. Check whether a loop is formed by a hub and devices, one of which is connected to the interface.
�If a loop is formed by a hub and devices, one of which is connected to the interface, go to Step 4.
�If no loop is formed by a hub and devices, one of which is connected to the interface, go to Step 5.
3. Delete the local loopback configuration, and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
4. Remove the self-loop network cable from the hub and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: DRIVER/2/CARDKEYCHIPERROR: Card [CardInfo] is failed, the common chip on PIC is abnormal ([Reason]). In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: A key module of a subcard was faulty.

column1: [Reason]Fault cause
A key module of a subcard was faulty.
1. Check whether the board where the subcard resides is an FPIC board.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 2.
2. Check whether the mother board of the faulty subcard is reset.
�If so, go to Step 10.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Power off and then power on the faulty subcard.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 4.
4. Remove and then insert the faulty subcard.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 5.
5. Check whether the mother board of the faulty subcard has only one subcard.
�If only one subcard is installed, go to Step 6.
�If more than one subcard is installed, go to Step 9.
6. Power off and then power on the board.
6. For non-FPIC boards:
1. For non-FPIC boards:
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the board cannot be registered, go to Step 8.
2. For FPIC boards:
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the board cannot be registered or the alarm cannot be cleared after the board is registered, go to Step 7.
7. Replace the subcard.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 8.
8. Replace the board.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 10.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 9.
9. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
10. End.

column4: NETCONF/3/NCA_SYNC_OP_FILE_TRANSFER_FAIL: Failed to transfer synchronization operation file to target server. (File=[File], Target address=[Targetaddress], VPN Instance=[VPNInstance], Reason=[Reason].)
column5: NETCONF synchronization fails when files are transferred to or saved on the server. Any error that occurs during file transfer is logged.

column1: [Targetaddress]Destination IP address.
[VPNInstance]VPN instance name.

[Reason]Indicates the cause of the file transfer failure. Source file error: The source file is incorrect. Target server information error: The target server information is incorrect. The specified target server is not reachable: The specified target server is unreachable. The specified user is deleted in the target server: The specified user has been deleted from the target server. The specified port is modified in the target server: The specified port has been changed on the target server. The specified file transfer to the target server timed out: File transfer times out. Processing the file times out when the file is transferred to the target server. The specified local path or filename is invalid: The specified local path or file name is invalid. Failed to open file: The file fails to be opened. Local file open permission is not available: The user does not have the permission to open the local file. Local file not found or file is renamed: No local file is found or the file name has been updated. Failed to transfer file: The file fails to be transferred. Target server return error after file transfer is started: The target server returns an error when file transfer is started. An application schema model is being updated: The schema application module is being upgraded. Unrecognized host or wrong IP address: The host is unknown or the IP address is incorrect. Destination server is not reachable: The target server is unreachable. Destination server is not in service: The target server is not in the service range. Authentication failed: Authentication failed. Username or password authentication error: The username or password is incorrect. SFTP client key exchange error: An error occurred during key exchange on the SFTP client.
Cause 1: The source file is incorrect.
Cause 2: The target server information is incorrect.
�The specified target server is unreachable.
�The specified user has been deleted from the target server.
�On the target server, the specified port has been changed.
Cause 3: The file transfer times out. The file transfer to the target server times out.
Cause 4: The specified local path or file name is invalid.
Cause 5: Failed to open the file.
�You do not have the permission to open the local file.
�The local file is not found or the file name has been updated.
Cause 6: Failed to transfer the file.
�The target server returns an error when file transfer is started.
�The Schema application module is being upgraded.
Cause 7: The host is unknown or the IP address is incorrect.
�The target server is unreachable.
�The target server is not in the service range.
Cause 8: Authentication failed.
�The user name or password is incorrect.
�An error occurs in key exchange on the SFTP client.
Cause 1: Ensure that the source file exists.
Cause 2: Check whether the target server is shut down, whether the user is deleted, or whether the port number is changed.
For cause 3: Ensure that the connection to the target server is normal.
Cause 4: Ensure that the source file name in the request is the same as the local file name.
Cause 5: Check whether the authorization source file is modified.
Cause 6:
�Check whether the target server is shut down.
�Ensure that file transfer and synchronization are complete after the patch upgrade is complete.
Cause 7: The destination IP address is valid.
Cause 8: Check whether the user name, password, or SFTP key exchange parameters are valid.

column4: TRUNK/2/TRUNK_MEM_LINKDOWN: The link status of the trunk member interface turned to DOWN. (ifIndex=[ifIndex], ifAdminStatus=[ifAdminStatus], ifOperStatus=[ifOperStatus], ifDescr=[ifDescr], hwIFExtPhyStatus=[hwIFExtPhyStatus], hwIFExtMemberOf=[hwIFExtMemberOf])
column5: A trunk member interface went Down.

[hwIFExtPhyStatus]Physical status of a trunk member interface
[hwIFExtMemberOf]Name of the trunk interface to which the member interface belongs
Cause 1: The interface goes Down and the physical link is disconnected.
Cause 2: The link layer protocol went Down.
�Cause 1: The interface was shut down, and its inserted physical link was disconnected.
1. Run the display this command in the interface view to check whether the trunk member interface is shut down.
�If the interface is shut down, go to Step 2.
�If the interface is not shut down, go to Step 3.
2. Run the undo shutdown command in the interface view to enable the interface and then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Check whether the physical connection of the interface is proper (for example, whether the network cable is properly connected and optical module is properly inserted).
�If the physical connection is proper, go to Step 5.
�If the physical connection is improper, go to Step 4.
4. Correctly connect the physical link and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: The link-layer protocol status of the interface became Down.
1. Run the display this command in the interface view to check whether the trunk member interface is shut down.
�If the interface is shut down, go to Step 2.
�If the interface is not shut down, go to Step 3.
2. Run the undo shutdown command in the interface view to enable the interface and then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Troubleshoot the Down fault of the link-layer protocol. If the link-layer protocol still cannot go Up, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
