column5: The BGP peer relationship is interrupted.
column6: [PeerIpv4Addr]IP address of a BGP peer. In the current implementation, this log is reported to the NMS based on the bgpBackwardTransNotification object in the common MIB file (Bgp4-mib.mib). This MIB object supports only the IPv4 peer scenario and does not support the IPv6 peer scenario. As a result, this log is not reported when the IPv6 peer status changes. Check the bgpBackwardTransition alarm on the device.

column1: [PeerLastError]The value of the Error Code field in the Notification packet generated when the peer relationship was interrupted last time.
[PeerState]The status of the BGP peer.
[VpnInstance]The name of the VPN instance.
Cause 1: Incorrect configurations caused the BGP peer relationship interruption.
Cause 2: Notification messages were received.
Cause 3: BGP received error packets.
Cause 4: The BGP hold timer expired.
Cause 5: The BGP peer was unreachable.
Cause 6: The originally interconnected interfaces were disconnected.
Cause 7: The number of BGP routes exceeded the upper limit.
Cause 1: The BGP peer relationship is disconnected due to BGP configurations.
1. Check whether the neighbor relationship is disconnected due to its own configuration.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Cancel the configuration that causes the disconnection of the neighbor relationship.
3. Check whether the BGP connection is reset. Wait for a while and check whether the connection is restored.
4. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 2: BGP received a Notification packet.
1. Run the display bgp peer ip-address log-info command to check the Notification messages generated when BGP is disconnected.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 4, the BGP Holdtimer expires and no Keepalive packet is received. Go to Step 3.
�If the error code of the Notification packet is 5, an error occurs on the BGP FSM. Go to Step 17.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 6, BGP proactively closes the connection. Go to Step 2.
2. Run the display bgp peer ip-address log-info command to check whether the notification is sent by the device that generates the alarm.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the ping command to check whether the IP address of the BGP peer can be pinged.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Check whether the CPU usage is too high. The command varies according to the device.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to Step 6.
5. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the BGP peer address routing table exists.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If no, go to Step 8.
6. Run the display acl command to check whether the ACL that denies TCP port 179 is configured on the device.
�If yes, go to to delete the ACL that denies TCP port 179.
�If no, go to Step 9.
7. Run the display interface command to check whether the outbound interface of the route is Up.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to Step 10.
8. Check the origin of the route to the BGP peer address.
�If the route source is OSPF, go to Step 11.
�If the route source is IS-IS, go to Step 12.
9. Check the BGP configuration to see whether the loopback interface is used to establish the BGP connection.
�If so, go to Step 13.
�If no, go to Step 14.
10. Check whether the shutdown command is run on the interface.
�If yes, go to step to run the undo shutdown command on the interface. - If the alarm persists, go to Step 13.
�If no, go to Step 17.
11. Run the display ospf peer command to check whether the OSPF peer relationship is established.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to. For details, see the handling procedure of OSPF_1.3.6.1.2.1.14.16.2.2 ospfNbrStateChange.
12. Run the display isis peer command to check whether the IS-IS peer is set up.
�If yes, go to Step 17.
�If no, go to. For details, see the handling procedure of ISIS_1.3.6.1.3.37.2.0.17 isisAdjacencyChange.
13. Check whether the source address used to initiate a BGP connection is specified.
�If so, go to Step 14.
�If not, run the peer connect-interface command to specify the source address used to initiate the BGP connection.
14. If the BGP peer is an EBGP peer and multiple hops exist between EBGP peers, check whether the peer ebgp-max-hop command is configured.
�If so, go to Step 15.
�If not, run the peer ebgp-max-hop command.
15. If the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command is configured, check whether the TTL of the packet received from the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.
�If so, go to Step 16.
�If not, run the peer valid-ttl-hops <hops> command to ensure that the TTL of the packets sent to the peer is within the range of 255-hops+1 to 255.

16. Contact the maintenance personnel of the peer device to check whether BGP is reset on the peer device, whether the peer is enabled in another address family on the local device, or whether BGP connection parameters are set.
�If the preceding operations are performed, wait for a while and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 17.
17. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 3: BGP received error packets.
1. Run the display bgp peer ip-address log-info command to check the Notification messages generated when BGP is disconnected.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 1, BGP has received packets with incorrect headers. Go to Step 2.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 2, BGP has received incorrect Open messages. Go to Step 2.
�If the error code in the Notification packet is 3, BGP has received incorrect Update packets. Go to Step 2.
2. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
Cause 4: The BGP hold timer expired.
1. Run the ping command to check whether the IP address of the BGP peer can be pinged.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the CPU usage is too high. The command varies according to the device.
�If so, go to Step 15.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the BGP peer address routing table exists.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If no, go to Step 6.
4. Run the display acl command to check whether the ACL that denies TCP port 179 is configured on the device.

column4: ISIS/2/isisLspSeqThresholdExceed_active: The LSP sequence number has exceeded the upper threshold value. (SysInstance=[isisSysInstance], SysLevel=[isisSysLevelIndex], LspId=[isisPduLspId], ThresholdValue=0x[thresholdVal])
column5: The LSP sequence number exceeds the specified upper threshold. After the sequence number of an IS-IS LSP exceeds a specified upper threshold, this alarm is generated. After the sequence number of an IS-IS LSP falls below a specified upper threshold, this alarm is cleared.

column1: [isisSysLevelIndex]Indicates the IS-IS level.
[isisPduLspId]Indicates the LSP ID.
[thresholdVal]The upper threshold value of LSP sequence Number
Cause 1: An attacker simulated a locally generated LSP, set its sequence number to a value that is greater than the upper alarm threshold, and sent the LSP to the local device.
Cause 2: Another device on the network had the same IS-IS System ID as the local one.
1. Run the display isis lsdb command to check the sequence number of the LSP generated by the local device.
�If the sequence number increases normally, this log message is informational only, and no action is required.
�If the sequence number increases too fast, go to step 2.

2. Run the timer lsp-refresh command in the IS-IS view to increase the value of the LSP refresh timer, and then run the display isis lsdb command to view the sequence number of the LSP generated by the local device.
�If the sequence number increases normally, go to step 5.
�If the sequence number still increases too fast, go to step 3.
3. Check whether there is a device whose system ID conflicts with the local system ID in the domain.
�If so, change the system ID of one of the conflicting devices.
�If no, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column1: [slot-id]Slot ID.
[reason-id]ID of the alarm cause.
[reason-description]Alarm cause description.

�Cause 1: When more than two port queue cir configurations are configured on a board, the function is normal. When a board that supports only two port queue cir configurations is inserted into the same slot as the board, the port-queue cir configurations do not take effect and a trap is generated.
�Cause 2: The scheduling tree of the sliced sub-interface can't be able to be created due to insufficient resources.
�Cause 3: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of queues in 4-CoS mode configured based on the board exceeds the upper limit.
�Cause 4: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of uplink queues in enhanced 8-CoS mode configured based on the board exceeds the upper limit.
�Cause 5: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of downlink queues in enhanced 8-CoS mode exceeds the upper limit.

�Cause 1: When more than two port queue cir configurations are configured on a board, the function is normal. When a board that supports only two port queue cir configurations is inserted into the same slot as the board, the port-queue cir configurations do not take effect and a trap is generated.
1. Switch the PQ CIR configurations to another board that supports more than two PQs, or change the number of PQ CIR configurations of all interfaces on the board to a value less than or equal to 2.
2. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 2: The scheduling tree of the sliced sub-interface can't be able to be created due to insufficient resources.
1. Check whether the number of configured channelized sub-interfaces exceeds the board specifications.
�If yes, switch some channelized sub-interface configurations to another board and go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 3: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of queues in 4-CoS mode configured based on the board exceeds the upper limit.
1. Check whether the number of 4-CoS queue resources configured on the board exceeds the board's specification.
�If yes, decrease the value of <4cos-size> in the qos user-queue resource 4cos <4cos-size> command based on the specification. Then, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
4. End.
�Cause 4: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of uplink queues in enhanced 8-CoS mode configured based on the board exceeds the upper limit.
1. Check whether the number of enhanced 8-CoS upstream queue resources configured on the board exceeds the board's specification.
�If yes, decrease the value of <8cos-enhance-size> in the qos user-queue resource 8cos-enhance <8cos-enhance-size> inbound command based on the specification. Then, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
4. End.
�Cause 5: During configuration restoration or board replacement, the number of downlink queues in enhanced 8-CoS mode exceeds the upper limit.
1. Check whether the number of enhanced 8-CoS downstream queue resources configured on the board exceeds the board's specification.
�If yes, decrease the value of <8cos-enhance-size> in the qos user-queue resource 8cos-enhance <8cos-enhance-size> outbound command based on the specification. Then, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
4. End.

column4: ISIS/2/ISIS_SEQUENCE_NUMBER_SKIP: ISIS received a self-originated LSP with a greater sequence number. (isisSysInstance=[isisSysInstance], isisSysLevelIndex=[isisSysLevelIndex], isisCircIndex=[isisCircIndex], isisCircIfIndex=[isisCircIfIndex], isisPduLspId=[isisPduLspId], ifIndex=[ifIndex], IfName=[IfName],oldSeqNum=[oldSeqNum],newSeqNum=[newSeqNum])
column5: When local IS-IS LSPs were refreshed, the sequence number increased irregularly.

column1: [isisSysLevelIndex]IS-IS level
[isisCircIndex]Interface index
[isisCircIfIndex]Interface index
[isisPduLspId]LSP ID
[ifIndex]IfIndex of an interface
[IfName]Interface name
[oldSeqNum]Old sequence number
[newSeqNum]New sequence number
Cause 1: After the IS-IS process was restarted, the LSP sequence number increased from 1. IS-IS received an LSP with a larger sequence number and the same LSP ID from the neighbor.
Cause 2: The system ID of the device was the same as that of another device on the network. As a result, the LSP was continuously refreshed.
1. Run the display history-command command to check whether the reset isis all command is run on the local device to restart the IS-IS process.
�If yes, this log message is informational only, and no action is required.
�If not, go to Step 2.

2. Run the display isis lsdb command to check whether the LSP sequence number of the local device increases rapidly. That is, the actual LSP refresh interval is smaller than the LSP refresh interval set using the timer lsp-refresh command.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.
3. Run the display current-configuration command to check whether the system ID or virtual system ID of another device is the same as that of the local device.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.

4. (Exercise caution when running the undo network-entity or undo virtual-system command.) Enter the IS-IS view of the local device or another device that has the same system ID or virtual system ID as the local device and run the undo network-entity or undo virtual-system command to delete the duplicate system ID or virtual system ID. Then, run the network-entity or virtual-system command to configure a different system ID or virtual system ID for the device. Check whether the fault is rectified.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log and configuration information, and contact Huawei technical support personnel.
6. End.

column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamBidirectionalTunnelAva: BidirectionalTunnel enter avaliable. (TunnelIndex=[TunnelIndex], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType], BdiDefectType=[BdiDefectType])
column5: The static bidirectional co-routed LSP monitored by MPLS OAM enters the available state.
column6: [TunnelIndex]Indicates the ID of a MIB object.

column1: [AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM. - 0: Available - 1: Unavailable

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: [BdiDefectType]Indicates the BDI defect type.

Cause 1: The address used to forward the packet could not be pinged.
Cause 2: The peer end considered the packet to be invalid.
1. Check the number of retransmission times for each packet.
�If a packet is retransmitted once or twice and the number of retransmitted packets is small, ignore the problem and go to Step 5.
�If some packets are retransmitted for many times and continuously, go to Step 2.
2. Find the IP address of the neighbor to which packets are retransmitted from the alarm information and ping the IP address.
�If it can be pinged, go to Step 4.
�If it cannot be pinged, go to Step 3.

3. Check whether the alarm 1.3.6.1.2.1.14.16.2.9 is generated on the local and neighboring devices. If the alarm is generated, clear the alarm according to the alarm handling procedure. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.

5. End.

�Cause 140288: The monitoring channel of the board is abnormal.
�Cause 140289: The data channel of the board is abnormal
�Cause 140304: The I2C control bus on the backplane malfunctions.
�Cause 140310: The control channel of the board is abnormal.
�Cause 140311: The serial management bus of the board malfunctions.

�Cause 140288: The monitoring channel of the board is abnormal.
1. Run the display device command in the user view to check the status of the faulty board.
2. Run the display interface command twice in the user view to check whether traffic is being transmitted on the interface of the faulty board.
3. If the alarm persists, collect information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
�Cause 140289: The data channel of the board is abnormal
1. Run the display device command in the user view to check the status of the faulty board.
2. Run the display interface command twice in the user view to check whether traffic is being transmitted on the interface of the faulty board.
3. If the alarm persists, collect information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
�Cause 140304: The I2C control bus on the backplane malfunctions.
1. Replace the involved subcard in the coprresponding slot.
2. If the fault persists, replace the main control board in the slot.
3. If the fault persists, replace the chassis.
4. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 140310: The control channel of the board is abnormal.
1. Run the display device command in the user view to check the status of the faulty board.
2. Run the display alarm command in the user view to check Is there a LCM or module fault alarm.
3. Run the display lcm channel command in the diagnostic view to see if lcm channel was open, and status is OK.
4. Collect information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 140311: The serial management bus of the board malfunctions.
1. Replace the involved subcard in the coprresponding slot.
2. If the fault persists, replace the main control board in the slot.
3. If the fault persists, replace the chassis.
4. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 140317: The communication between the CMUs is abnormal
1. Run the display device command in the user view to check the status of the faulty CMU.
2. If the alarm persists, collect information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
�Cause 140318: Service backup channel failed.
1. Reset the slave board,check whether the alarm is cleared.
�if so,go to step 5.
�if not,go to step 2.
2. Replace the slave board,check whether the alarm is cleared.
�if so,go to step 5.
�if not,go to step 3.
3. Replace the master board.check whether the alarm is cleared.
�if so,go to step 5.
�if not,go to step 4.
4. If the alarm persists, collect information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 140321: The UART communication of the board is faulty.

column1: [ProbableCause]To describe the probable cause of trap.
[BaseTrapEventType]To describe the type of trap.

[ReasonDescription]To describe the reason of trap in DisplayString style.
A communication failure occurred on the fan module.

1. Run the reset slot command to reset the faulty fan, and then check whether the fan can work normally after being reset. If the alarm persists after the fan is registered, the fan board is faulty. Replace the fan. If the fan can be registered and work normally after being reset and no such alarm is generated, it indicates that the software is faulty.

2. Upgrade the system software. Download the system software of a later version to the CF cards of the active and standby main control boards, run the system-software command to specify the system software for next startup, and restart the router.
3. Run the display device command to check whether the faulty board is registered successfully.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamL2vcInDefect: L2VC enter defect. (PeerIp=[PeerIp], VCType=[VCType], VCID=[VCID], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType], BdiDefectType=[BdiDefectType])
column5: OAM detected that the L2VC was defective.

column1: [VCType]Indicates the VC type.
[VCID]Indicates the L2VC ID.
[AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an ingress. - 0: indicates that the ingress is available. - 1: indicates that the ingress is unavailable.

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: [BdiDefectType]Indicates the BDI defect type.
Cause 1: The MEP was enabled to receive CCMs, but the RMEP was not enabled to send CCMs.
As a result, the MEP did not receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 2: The interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel was shut down, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 3: Congestion occurred on the MPLS TE tunnel, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 4: Link performance deteriorated, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 5: The TTSI was configured incorrectly on the MEP, causing the TTSI in the received packet to fail to match the expected TTSI.
As a result, a connection defect was generated.
1. Run the display mpls oam l2vc command to check whether the MEP and RMEP configurations are correct.
�If the MEP and RMEP configurations are correct, go to Step 2.
�If the MEP and RMEP configurations are incorrect, go to Step 4.
2. Run the display interface command to check whether any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down.
�If any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 4.
�If no physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 3.
3. Run the undo shutdown command to enable the physical interface, and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 5.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 4.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: DEVM/2/hwSfbereAlarm_active: Exceeding block error B2 counter in the multiplex section alarm. (hwPhysicalPortIfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],BoardID=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardID=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortID=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: B2 Sf counter in the multiplex section alarm.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
�Cause 0: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column1: [PatchName]Name of a patch package
A patch package running on a board was damaged.
1. Run the display device command and check whether the patch package on the slave main control board is damaged.
�If yes, run the reset slot <slot-id> command to restart the slave main control board. The patch package can be fixed automatically.
�If no, go to step 2.
2. Run the display device command and check whether only the patch package on the master main control board is damaged.
�If yes, run the slave switchover command in the system view to perform a master/slave main control board switchover if conditions permit and services are not affected.
�If no, go to step 3.

3. If the master/slave switchover cannot be performed or patch packages on both main control boards are damaged, ignore the alarm until the patch package of the next version is loaded using the patch load <file-name> all run command to clear the alarm.
�If the alarm persists, go to step 4.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

�If the number exceeds the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, this trap message is informational only and no action is required.
�If the number has not exceeded the upper alarm threshold (in percentage) multiplied by the maximum number allowed, go to Step 2.
2. Perform the following operations as required:

�If a change in the limit on the number of NSSA-LSAs is allowed, run the import-route limit <limit-number> [ threshold-alarm upper-limit <upper-limit-value> lower-limit <lower-limit-value> ] command to change the limit.

column5: Peer E-Trunk authentication failed.

column1: [AuthenticationMode]E-Trunk authentication mode
Authentication modes or keys were inconsistent on the two E-Trunk ends.

1. Run the authentication-mode { hmac-sha1 | hmac-sha256 | enhanced-hmac-sha256 } command in the E-Trunk view to configure the authentication mode of one end to be the same as that of the other end. Then, Check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.

2. Run the security-key { simple <simple-key> | cipher { <cipher-key1> | <cipher-key2> | <cipher-key3> } } command in the E-Trunk view to configure the key of one end to be the same as that of the other end. Check whether the alarm persists. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column5: The local device received a flush LSA from a neighbor indicating that the OSPF LSAs advertised by a third device were flushed. Possibly faulty devices do not support OSPF flush LSA source tracing. In this case, log in to a possibly faulty node and check whether it is flushing LSAs. If it is flushing LSAs, reset or isolate it. If the possibly faulty node is not flushing LSAs, check other possibly faulty nodes. To check the analysis report output by OSPF flush LSA source tracing, run the display ospf flush-source-trace analysis-info command.

column1: [hwOspfv2PurgeHostName]Hostname of the faulty node
[hwOspfv2PurgeIpAddress]Host IP address of the faulty node
[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId]Router ID in the process
[hwOspfv2AreaId]OSPF area ID
[hwOspfv2FlushLsaNum]Number of times an LSA was flushed
[hwOspfv2AffectedNodeNum]Number of affected nodes
[hwOspfv2TotalNodeNum]Total number of nodes on the network
[hwOspfv2RuledOutDeviceNum]Number of nodes that have been identified as faultless nodes
[hwOspfv2PurgeStatPeriod]Statistical period
OSPF routes advertised by another device were deleted, and the possibly faulty device did not support OSPF flush LSA source trace.

1. Log in to the suspected faulty device and run the display ospf routing command to check whether any route is deleted. If yes, isolate the faulty device from the network (reset or isolate the faulty device). If not, check other devices.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

column4: EOAM-1AG/1/MISMERGE_active: MEP received a CCM with unexpected MEG ID. (MdIndex=[MdIndex], MaIndex=[MaIndex], MdName=[MdName], MaName=[MaName], MepId=[MepId])
column5: A MEP receives a CCM carrying an MD or MA name different from the local setting.

column1: [MdName]Name of an MD
[MaName]Name of an MA
[MepId]ID of a MEP
An MD or MA name carried in a CCM sent by the RMEP was different from that specified on the MEP when the MEP and RMEP had the same MD level and service type in a MEG.

1. Run the display cfm mep [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> [ mep-id <mep-id> ] ] ] command to view the value of the MD Name field on the MEP and RMEP that have the same service type and MD level. Check whether the MD names are the same.
�If they are the same, go to Step 2.
�If they are different, go to Step 3.

2. Run the display cfm mep [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> [ mep-id <mep-id> ] ] ] command to view the value of the MA Name field on the MEP and RMEP that have the same service type, MD level, and MD name. Check whether the MA names are the same.
�If they are the same, go to Step 5.
�If they are different, go to Step 4.
3. Perform the following steps on the MEP:
�a. Run the undo cfm md name <md-name> command to delete existing MD configurations.
�b. Run the cfm md <md-name> level <leve> command to reconfigure an MD the same as that on the RMEP.
�c. Run the display alarm active command to view the trap. Check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 5.
4. Perform the following steps on the MEP:
�a. Run the undo ma <ma-name> command to delete existing MA configurations.
�b. Run the ma <ma-name> command to reconfigure an MA the same as that on the RMEP.
�c. Run the display alarm active command to view the trap. Check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

(Index=[Index], ConfigurationName=[ConfigurationName], PeerIp=[PeerIp], BindIfIndex=[BindIfIndex], BindIfName=[BindIfName], Diagnosis=[Diagnosis], BindVrfIndex=[BindVrfIndex], BindVpnName=[BindVpnName], SessionType=[SessionType], DefaultIp=[DefaultIp], BindType=[BindType], StaticLspName=[StaticLspName], PwSecondary=[PwSecondary], NextHop=[NextHop], VcId=[VcId], VsiName=[VsiName], VsiPeerAddress=[VsiPeerAddress], DiscrAuto=[DiscrAuto], PeerIpv6=[PeerIpv6], Ipv6NextHop=[Ipv6NextHop], EvplId=[EvplId])

column6: [Index]Indicates the index of the BFD session.

column1: [ConfigurationName]Indicates the configuration name of the BFD session.
[PeerIp]Indicates the bound destination IP address.
[BindIfIndex]Indicates the index of the bound interface.
[BindIfName]Indicates the name of the bound interface.

[Diagnosis]Indicates information about session diagnostic characters. 0: No diagnostic word 1: Detection time Down 2: Echo detection Down 3: Neighbor advertisement Down 4: Forwarding plane reset 5: Path Down 6: Cascading path Down 7: Administratively Down 8: Reverse cascading path Down 9: Peer administratively Down 25: IP error code stop 26: IP error code start 27: Section error code stop 28: Section error code start 29: LSP error code stop 30: LSP ingress error code start 31: LSP transit error code start
[BindVrfIndex]Indicates the index of the bound VPN instance.
[BindVpnName]Indicates the name of the bound VPN instance.

[SessionType]1: static, which indicates that the BFD session is statically configured. 2: Dynamic, which indicates that the BFD session is dynamically triggered. 3: Entire_Dynamic: indicates that a BFD session is dynamically triggered. After the function of passively creating a BFD session is enabled on the egress of the LSP, the BFD session is created. 4: Static_Auto: indicates a static BFD session with automatically negotiated discriminators.
[DefaultIp]Indicates the default multicast IP address.

[BindType]2 or 3: Peer IP address (multi-hop IP link detection). 1 or 4: Interface (single-hop IP link detection). 5: FEC (detection of a specified FEC link). 6: TUNNELIF (detection of a specified tunnel interface link). 7: OSPF (OSPF neighbor link detection). 8: ISIS (ISIS neighbor link detection). 9: LDP_LSP (LDP LSP detection). 10: STATIC_LSP (static LSP detection). 11: TE_LSP (detection of the LSP bound to a TE tunnel). 12: TE_TUNNEL (TE tunnel detection). 13: PW (PW link detection). 14: LSP_PASSIVE (reversed LSP link detection). 15: VSI_PW (VSI PW link detection). 16: LDP_TUNNEL (LDP tunnel detection). 17: VXLAN (VXLAN link detection).

�Cause 1: Adjacency holdTimer expired
1. Run the display ipv6 interface and display ospfv3 peer commands to check the Up/Down status of the interface connected to the neighbor.
�If the physical interface is Down, check the link and ensure that the link is Up, and then go to Step 2.
If the physical interface is Up, go to Step 2.
2. Check whether packets are correctly forwarded and ping the IP address of the peer interface.
If the ping operation fails, go to step 5.
If the ping operation succeeds, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display ipv6 interface command on the neighbor to check whether the interface of the OSPFv3 neighbor is Up.
If the interface is Down, go to Step 5.
If the interface is Up, go to Step 4.
4. Run the display ospfv3 interface command to check whether the configurations on both ends are correct.
If the configurations are correct, go to step 6.
If the configuration is incorrect, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.
�Cause 2: Physical interface change
1. Run the display ipv6 interface command to check whether the physical status of the interface on which the OSPFv3 neighbor relationship is established is normal.

�If the physical status of the interface is Down, check the optical power of the interface and whether the transmission device is normal. Restore the physical status of the interface to clear the alarm.
�If the physical status of the interface is *down, the interface has been shut down manually. Run the undo shutdown command on the interface to clear the alarm.
�If the physical status of the interface is Up, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ipv6 interface command to check the protocol status of the interface that establishes the OSPFv3 neighbor relationship.
�If the current protocol status is Down, check whether an IPv6 address is configured and whether the IPv6 address is correct. If yes, clear the alarm by checking the IPv6 address.
�If the protocol status is Up, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 3: Protocol reason
1. Run the display this command in the interface view and OSPFv3 view of the local and remote devices to check whether the same protocol is enabled on the devices at both ends of the link.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If not, configure the same protocol on the interfaces at both ends of the link where the neighbor relationship needs to be established.
2. Run the display ospfv3 peer command to check OSPF neighbor information.
�If no neighbor information is displayed, the local device cannot receive Hello packets from the peer device or the received Hello packets are discarded. Go to step 3.

�If Init is displayed, the local device can receive Hello packets from the peer device, but the peer device cannot receive Hello packets from the local device. Run the ping command to check whether the link to the peer device is normal. Generally, this problem occurs because the forwarding plane is faulty. As a result, packets are discarded. If the alarm cannot be cleared by rectifying the forwarding fault, go to step 4.

�If 2-way is displayed, ospfv3 dr-priority 0 has been configured on the OSPFv3 interface. Run the ospfv3 dr-priority command to set the DR priority of the interface to a value greater than 0 to clear the alarm.
�If Exstart is displayed, the device keeps performing DD negotiation and cannot complete DD synchronization. Go to step 3.

�If Loading is displayed, the local device considers the received LSAs invalid, discards them, and keeps requesting for LSAs. You can run the reset ospfv3 process-id command on both ends of the link where the OSPFv3 neighbor relationship needs to be established to clear the alarm.
Resetting an OSPFv3 connection (using the reset ospfv3 process-id command) interrupts the OSPFv3 neighbor relationship between devices. Exercise caution when resetting OSPFv3 connections.
3. Run the display this command in the interface view and OSPFv3 process view to check whether the authentication configurations on both ends of the link are the same.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, configure the same authentication mode on both ends of the link.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 4: BFD session state change
1. Run the ping command to check whether the link to the peer device is normal.
�If the peer device cannot be pinged, check the transmission devices, links, and interfaces, and adjust the hardware to restore services.
�If the ping operation succeeds, go to step 4.
2. Run the ping command in the interface view to check whether the link configuration is correct.
�If the configurations are correct, go to Step 3.
�If the configuration is incorrect, modify the configuration.
3. Run the display ospfv3 peer command to check whether the neighbor relationship is Up.
�If the neighbor relationship is Up, go to Step 4.
�If the neighbor relationship is Down, rectify the fault.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.
�Cause 5: Configuration change
1. Run the display this command in the OSPFv3 process view to check whether the area configurations on both ends of the neighbor are consistent.
�If they are different, change them to be the same.
�If they are consistent, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ospfv3 interface command to check whether the ospfv3 network-type values of the interfaces at both ends of the link are the same.
�If they are different, change them to be the same.
�If they are consistent, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 7: Peer router reason
1. Check whether the peer device is provided by another vendor.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 3.
2. Contact the vendor to check the running status of the peer device.
3. Check whether the peer device or OSPFv3 process is restarted.
�If the peer device or OSPFv3 process has been restarted, locate the fault based on the alarm and log information on the peer device.
�If the peer device or OSPFv3 process is not restarted, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

2. After the upload is complete, if the trust certificate expires, run the trusted-ca load command to replace the certificate. The command is as follows:
�Load the trusted-CA file trusted-ca load asn1-ca filename in ASN1 format for the SSL policy.
�Load the trusted-CA file trusted-ca load pem-ca filename for the SSL policy.
�Load a PFX trusted-CA file trusted-ca load pfx-ca filename auth-code cipher password for the SSL policy.
3. If the identity certificate has expired, run the certificate load command to replace the certificate.
�To load a PEM certificate for an SSL policy, run the certificate load pem-cert filename key-pair dsa key-file filename auth-code cipher password command.
�Load the PFX certificate certificate load pfx-cert filename key-pair rsa key-file filename auth-code cipher password to the SSL policy.
�Load a PEM certificate chain for the SSL policy: certificate load pem-chain filename key-pair rsa key-file filename auth-code cipher password.

1. Check whether the network topology flapping occurs.
�If the network topology flapping occurs, go to Step 3.
�If the network topology flapping does not occur, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display stp command to check whether the number of TC BPDUs exceeds the set threshold on the interface.
�If the number of TC BPDUs exceeds the set threshold on the interface, go to Step 4.
�If the number of TC BPDUs does not exceed the set threshold on the interface, go to Step 7.
3. Locate the cause of the network topology flapping and rectify the fault. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.

4. Run the stp tc-protection threshold <threshold> command in the system view to reset the maximum number of TC BPDUs that the device can process. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Check whether the malicious attack exists.
�If the malicious attack exists, go to Step 6.
�If the malicious attack does not exist, go to Step 7.
6. Locate the attack source and remove the attack. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
7. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column5: The received rate of ND packets or ND miss messages exceeded the configured rate limit.

[SupType]Suppress type
[IfName]Interface name.
[WorkIfName]Work interface name.
[SrcMac]Source MAC address.
[DstMac]Destination MAC address.
[SrcIp]Source IP address.
[DstIp]Destination IP address.
[TgtIp]Target IP address.
[PeVlan]Outer VLAN ID.
[CeVlan]Inner VLAN ID.
Cause 1: The rate of receiving ND packets based on the source MAC address exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 2: The rate of receiving ND packets based on the source IP address exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 3: The rate of receiving ND packets based on the destination IP address exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 4: The rate at which ND packets are received based on the destination IP address exceeds the configured rate limit.
Cause 5: The rate of receiving VR-based ND packets exceeds the configured rate limit.
Cause 6: The rate at which ND Miss messages are received based on VR exceeds the configured rate limit.
Cause 7: The rate at which ND packets are received based on the source IP address of the interface exceeds the configured rate limit.
Cause 8: The rate at which interface-based ND packets are received exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 9: The rate at which ND Miss messages are received on an interface exceeded the configured rate limit.
Cause 10: The rate at which ND packets are received based on LR exceeds the configured rate limit.
Cause 11: The rate at which ND Miss messages are received based on LR exceeds the configured rate limit.
1. Check the value of SuppressType.
2. Run the display ipv6 nd anti-attack rate-limit configuration command to check the rate limit for ND packets or ND Miss messages.
3. Adjust the value of the corresponding command according to the prompt in Step 1.

�If Suppress Type is SRCIP, run the ipv6 nd {ns |na | rs | ra | miss} anti-attack rate-limit source-ip maximum command in the system view or the ipv6 nd {ns |na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit source-ip all maximum command in the system view.

�If Suppress Type is SRCMAC, run the ipv6 nd {ns |na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit source-mac maximum command in the system view or run the ipv6 nd {ns |na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit source-mac all maximum command in the system view.

�When Suppress Type is set to INTERFACE(Interface), run the ipv6 nd {ns | na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit command in the interface view or run the ipv6 nd miss anti-attack rate-limit command in the interface view.
�If Suppress Type is INTERFACESRCIP, run the ipv6 nd {ns | na | rs | ra | miss} anti-attack rate-limit source-ip maximum command in the interface view.
�If Suppress Type is set to VSGLOBAL, run the ipv6 nd {ns | na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit or ipv6 nd miss anti-attack rate-limit command in the system view.
�If SuppressType is set to LSGLOBAL, the overall rate limit does not need to be adjusted.

�If Suppress Type is set to DSTIP, run the ipv6 nd {ns | na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit destination-ip maximum command in the system view or run the ipv6 nd {ns |na | rs | ra} anti-attack rate-limit destination-ip all maximum command in the system view.

�If Suppress Type is set to TGTIP, run the ipv6 nd {ns | na} anti-attack rate-limit target-ip maximum command in the system view or run the ipv6 nd {ns |na} anti-attack rate-limit target-ip all maximum command in the system view.
4. Reconfigure the rate limit for ND packets or ND Miss packets (the value must be greater than the value queried in step 2) and check whether logs are reported.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 6.
5. Collect log and configuration information, and contact Huawei technical support personnel.
6. End.

�Cause 132619: The master or slave ACT signal of the MPU board is abnormal.
1. Check whether other boards have low-power-related alarms or power-related alarms. If so, handle these alarms first.

2. Remove and reinstall the current standby main control board and check whether the standby main control board is securely installed, whether any bent pins exist, and whether the connectors of the standby main control board are normal. Then, go to Step 4.

3. If the device is reset, remove the other main control board and check whether the main control board is securely installed, whether any bent pins exist, and whether the connectors of the main control board are normal. Then, go to Step 4.
4. If the board is not securely installed, install it securely.
5. If the backplane has bent pins, avoid installing a new board into the faulty slot. Contact technical support.
6. If only the connectors of the board are found to be faulty, replace the board and go to Step 8.
7. If the standby main control board is still not registered or the alarm persists, contact technical support.
8. End.

column4: BGP/6/PEER_STATE_CHG: The state of the peer changed after receiving an event. (PrevState=[prev-state], CurrState=[curr-state], InputEvent=[input-event], Peer=[peer-address], SourceInterface=[SourceInterface], VpnInstance=[VpnInstance])
column5: The peer status changed.
column6: [prev-state]Original status. The details are as follows: IDLE: BGP denies any connection request. This is the initial state of BGP. CONNECT: BGP is waiting for the TCP connection to be established before performing subsequent operations. ACTIVE: BGP attempts to establish a TCP connection. This is the intermediate state of BGP. OPENSENT: BGP is waiting for an Open message from the peer. OPENCONFIRM: BGP is waiting for a Notification or Keepalive message. ESTABLISHED: BGP peers can exchange Update, Notification, and Keepalive messages.

column1: [curr-state]Current status. The details are as follows: IDLE: BGP denies any connection request. This is the initial state of BGP. CONNECT: BGP is waiting for the TCP connection to be established before performing subsequent operations. ACTIVE: BGP attempts to establish a TCP connection. This is the intermediate state of BGP. OPENSENT: BGP is waiting for an Open message from the peer. OPENCONFIRM: BGP is waiting for a Notification or Keepalive message. ESTABLISHED: BGP peers can exchange Update, Notification, and Keepalive messages.

[input-event]Input event. The details are as follows: START: A connection is created. STOP: The connection is stopped. IH_TIMER: The idleholdtimer expires. CR_TIMER: The connectretrytimer times out. OD_TIMER: The Opendelaytimer times out. HOLD_TIMER: The holdtimer expires. KA_TIMER: The keepalivetimer times out. TCP_SUCCEED: A TCP connection is successfully established. TCP_FAIL: The TCP connection fails to be established. TCP_INCOMING: A TCP connection establishment request is received. RECV_OPEN: An Open message is received. RECV_KA: Keepalive messages are received. RECV_UPDATE: indicates that an Update message is received. RECV_RR: indicates that a RouteRefresh message is received. RECV_NOTIF: A Notification packet is received. RECV_NOTIF_VER: A BGP version error notification is received. RECV_HEAD_ERR: A BGP message with an incorrect header is received. RECV_OPEN_ERR: An Open message is received incorrectly. RECV_UPDATE_ERR: The Update message is received incorrectly. RECV_RR_ERR: indicates that an error RouteRefesh message is received. OPEN_COLLION_DUMP: The conflicting connection is closed. LINK_UNREACHABLE_DETECTED: The link is unreachable.
[peer-address]IP address of the peer.
[SourceInterface]Name of a multi-source interface.
[VpnInstance]Name of a VPN instance.
The peer status changed.
This message is informational only, and no action is required.

column4: PIC/1/hwCardInvalid_active: The card failed completely. column6: [EntityPhysicalIndex]Indicates the index of the physical entity.

column1: [EntityType]Indicates the type of the physical entity.
[ReasonDescription]Indicates the description of the cause of the trap.
The clock unit on the subcard was faulty.
1.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3.Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4.If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5.If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6.If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7.If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.
8.Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: DEVM/4/hwEthHalfDuplex_active: Eth half duplex. (IfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],IfName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: Interface negotiation into half-duplex mode, resulting in a large number of packet loss.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.

Port configurations are different between the two sides (one port is set to speed force, and the other port is set to negotiation). As a result, the ports negotiate to half-duplex, and packet loss occurs, triggering a half-duplex alarm.
1. Check whether the speed configurations are different between the two sides. If not, change them to be the same.
2. If the configurations are the same, check the connections on the two sides. Modify the connection problem, and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to step 4.
�If the alarm persists, go to step 3.
3. Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

column1: [current]Current number of IPv6 routes in the VPN instance.
[max]Maximum number of IPv6 routes in the VPN instance.
Cause1: The number of VPN IPv6 routes to be added to the routing table exceeded the upper threshold of the VPN instance.
Cause2: The routing-table limit command was run, or the existing configuration of the command was modified to reduce the upper threshold.
1. Run the display ipv6 routing-table limit command to check the configured limit on the maximum number of routes allowable in the VPN instance and the current total number of routes.
2. Run the display ipv6 routing-table statistics command to check whether redundant VPN routes exist in the VPN instance.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 4.
3. Delete the redundant VPN routes and then check whether the alarm persists.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 6.
4. Run the display this command in the VPN instance view to check the routing-table limit configuration. Check whether the number of routes in the VPN instance reaches the upper threshold.

�If so, the alarm is informational only, and no action is required. To clear the alarm, run the routing-table limit <number> { <alert-percent> | simply-alert } command to reconfigure a proper limit on the maximum number of routes. Then go to Step 6.
�If not, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

1. Check whether the power supply is normal. Check whether the power switch is turned off. Turn on the power switch if it is off. Check whether the power input is normal. If not, connect the power module properly. After the external power input is complete, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 5.

2. Check whether the power module is completely inserted. If not, remove and reinstall the power module, and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 3.
3. Replace the power module and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

MPLS-OAM
column4: MPLS-OAM/3/hwMplsOamBidirectionalTunnelInDefect: BidirectionalTunnel enter defect. (TunnelIndex=[TunnelIndex], AvailableState=[AvailableState], DefectType=[DefectType], BdiDefectType=[BdiDefectType])
column5: OAM detected that the static bidirectional co-routed LSP was defective.
column6: [TunnelIndex]Indicates the ID of a MIB object.

column1: [AvailableState]Indicates the availability state of an OAM. - 0: Available - 1: Unavailable

[DefectType]Indicates the type of the defect: - 0: Indicates no defect. - 1: Indicates the server layer defect arising below the MPLS network layer. - 2: Indicates the peer maintenance entity defect arising outside the MPLS sub-network. - 3: Indicates the defect of the packet loss for the connectivity detection. - This defect occurs if no FDI packet is received from the server layer or lower level LSP, and no CV or FFD packet with expected TTSI is received. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected CV packet in 3 consecutive seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR does not receive the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals for sending the FFD packet. - If there is an incoming FDI packet from the server layer, the defect type is set to dServer
column2: if there is an incoming FDI packet from the lower level LSP within the MPLS network, the defect type is set to dPeerMe. In both cases, no more defects occur on this LSP. - 4: The defect of mismatching TTSI. This defect occurs when unexpected and no expected TTSI is carried in the incoming CV or FFD packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in 3 seconds and does not receive the CV packet with the expected TTSI. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI in any period of three consecutive intervals and does not receive the FFD packet with expected TTSI. - 5: TTSI mismerge defect. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with the unexpected TTSI and the CV packet with the expected TTSI in of 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives the CV or FFD packet with unexpected TTSI and the FFD packet with the expected FFD packet in any period of three consecutive intervals. - 6: Receiving excess rate of CV or FFD OAM packets. - For the LSP that is detected by the CV packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five CV packets with expected TTSI in 3 seconds. - For the LSP that is detected by the FFD packet, the egress LSR receives five or more than five FFD packets with expected TTSI in the period of three consecutive intervals. - 7: An unknown defect that is detected in the MPLS layer and affects the user plane traffic. This defect is not detected by MPLS OAM
column3: it is reported to MPLS OAM. - 8: OAM Ingress Down.

column1: [BdiDefectType]Indicates the BDI defect type.
Cause 1: The MEP was enabled to receive CCMs, but the RMEP was not enabled to send CCMs.
As a result, the MEP did not receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 2: The interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel was shut down, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 3: Congestion occurred on the MPLS TE tunnel, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 4: Link performance deteriorated, causing the MEP to fail to receive a CCM from the RMEP within a period of three times a specified interval.
Cause 5: The TTSI was configured incorrectly on the MEP, causing the TTSI in the received packet to fail to match the expected TTSI.
As a result, a connection defect was generated.
1. Run the display interface tunnel command to check whether the link is Up.
�If the link is Up, go to Step 2.
�If the link is Down, go to Step 3.
2. Run the display interface command to check whether any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down.
�If any physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 5.
�If no physical interface connected to the MPLS TE tunnel is shut down, go to Step 3.

3. Run the display this command in the MPLS OAM view to view the MPLS OAM configuration, and run the display mpls oam bidirectional-tunnel command in the system view to view the LSP configuration. Based on the outputs of the preceding commands, check whether the MPLS OAM and LSP configurations are consistent.
�If they are consistent, go to Step 4.
�If they are inconsistent, go to Step 5.
4. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: MSTP/4/MSTPLOG_PROROOT_CHANGED: The root bridge of MSTP process changed. (ProcessID=[ProcessID], InstanceID=[InstanceID], RootPortName=[PortName], PreviousRootBridgeID=[PreRootBridgeID], NewRootBridgeID=[NewRootBridgeID], RootPwName=[PwName], PreHello=[PreHello], PreMessageAge=[PreMessAge], PreFwdly=[PreFwdly], PreRemainingHops=[PreMessHop], NewHello=[NewHello], NewMessageAge=[NewMessAge], NewFwdly=[NewFwdly], NewRemainingHops=[NewMessHop], Tag=[Tag])
column5: The root bridge in the MSTP process changed.
column6: [ProcessID]Indicates the ID of an MSTP process.

column1: [InstanceID]Indicates the instance ID.
[PortName]Indicates the name of the root port.
[PreRootBridgeID]Indicates the bridge ID of the previous root bridge.
[NewRootBridgeID]Indicates the ID of the new root bridge.
[PwName]Indicates the PW name as the root port.
[PreHello]Indicates the time of the Hello Timer before the root bridge changed.
[PreMessAge]Indicates the aging time of the information before the root bridge changed.
[PreFwdly]Indicates the forwarding delay timer before the root bridge changed.
[PreMessHop]Indicates the number of hops of the spanning tree before the root bridge changed.
[NewHello]Indicates the time of the Hello Timer after the root bridge changed.
[NewMessAge]Indicates the aging time of the information after the root bridge changed.
[NewFwdly]Indicates the forwarding delay timer after the root bridge changed.
[NewMessHop]Indicates the number of hops of the spanning tree after the root bridge changed.
[Tag]tag in an MSTP packet.
Cause 1: A new device, which had the optimal bridge ID, was added.
Cause 2: The priorities of the devices or the domain configuration on the current network were modified.
�Cause 1: A new device is added, and the bridge ID of the device is the optimal.
1. Check whether the new physical link is the required one.
�If the physical link is required, go to Step 2.
�If the physical link is not required, go to Step 3.
2. Run the display stp command on the new device to check whether the bridge ID is optimal on the entire network.

�Cause 131560: The PTN mode of the master chassis in a virtual cluster device is different from that of the slave chassis.
�Cause 131586: The type of SFU dismatch with the device
�Cause 131587: The board types of the master and slave MPUs are different.
�Cause 131588: Software Test Right license is not activated, the boards or cards will be reset after 72 hours.
�Cause 131589: Software Test Right license will expire. After it expires, the boards or cards will be reset once every 24 hours.
�Cause 131590: Software Test Right license is not activated or expired, the boards or cards will be reset once every 24 hours.
�Cause 131560: The PTN mode of the master chassis in a virtual cluster device is different from that of the slave chassis.

1. Disconnect the slave chassis from the master chassis, configure the PTN mode of the slave chassis to be the same as that of the master chassis using the active mode-control license command or its undo form, and then connect the slave chassis to the master chassis.
2. If the alarm still exists, collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 131586: The type of SFU dismatch with the device
1. Change the sfu match with the device.
2. If the alarm still exists, collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 131587: The board types of the master and slave MPUs are different.
1. Install master and slave MPUs of the same board type.
2. If the alarm still exists, collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 131588: Software Test Right license is not activated, the boards or cards will be reset after 72 hours.
1. Check whether license control items are activated.
�If they are not activated, go to Step 2.
�If they are activated, go to Step 3.
2. Re-apply for and activate the license control items. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 131589: Software Test Right license will expire. After it expires, the boards or cards will be reset once every 24 hours.
1. Check whether license control items are about to expire.
�If they are about to expire, go to Step 2.
�If they are not about to expire, go to Step 3.
2. Re-apply for and activate the license control items. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 131590: Software Test Right license is not activated or expired, the boards or cards will be reset once every 24 hours.
1. Check whether license control items are activated.
�If they are not activated, go to Step 2.
�If they are activated, go to Step 3.
2. Re-apply for and activate the license control items. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.

column4: ISIS/5/ISIS_ADJ_PROTO_CHANGE: The protocol of IS-IS adjacency changes. (InstanceID=[InstanceID], IfName=[IfName], SystemID=[SystemID], OldState=[OldState], NewState=[NewState], ChangeReason=[ChangeReason])
column5: IS-IS neighbors support protocol changes.

column1: [IfName]Interface name.
[SystemID]System ID.
[OldState]Original status of the IS-IS neighbor: IPv4 IPv6 IPv4, IPv6
[NewState]Current status of an IS-IS neighbor: IPv4 IPv6 IPv4, IPv6

[ChangeReason]Reason why the protocol supported by the IS-IS neighbor changes: The received IIH packet does not support IPv4. The received IIH packet does not support IPv6. The received IIH packet does not carry a link-local address. The link-local address in the received IIH packet is invalid. The received IIH packet supports both IPv4 and IPv6. The BFD session is Down. BFD is associated with the cost, and the BFD session is still Down.
The protocol status of an IS-IS neighbor changes due to the following reasons:
1. The received IIH packet does not support IPv4.
2. The received IIH packet does not support IPv6.
3. The received IIH packet does not carry a link-local address.
4. The link-local address in the received IIH packet is invalid.
5. The received IIH packet supports both IPv4 and IPv6.
6. The BFD session went Down.
7. The BFD session is associated with the cost, and the BFD session is still Down.
Check whether the neighbor change complies with the configuration. If not, collect log and configuration information, and contact Huawei technical support personnel.

[groupID]ID of an update peer-group.
[time]Time taken to send messages, in seconds.
[Flag]Peer status.
[SourceInterface]Source interface.

If the time taken to send messages to a peer is greater than or equal to the absolute time threshold for detecting slower peers to implement hierarchical slow-peer switching and all the other peers in the slow update peer-group have received messages from the device, message sending to other slow peers in the same group is suppressed.
When the maximum number of slow peer groups that can be automatically switched to a single-peer update peer-group is reached, the system prompts you to perform manual intervention.

column4: PIC/1/hwCardInvalid_active: The card failed completely. column5: The card failed completely.
column6: [EntityPhysicalIndex]Indicates the index of the physical entity.

column1: [EntityType]Indicates the type of the physical entity.
[ReasonDescription]Indicates the description of the cause of the trap.
The EPLD logic of the subcard was faulty.
1.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2.If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3.Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4.If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5.If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6.If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7.If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.

A new LSP generated by another device is received, and the Remaining Lifetime value of the LSP is not 0 and less than 60 seconds.
1. Run the display isis lsdb command to check the Holdtime field. This field indicates the value of Remaining Lifetime. Check whether the value is less than 60s.
a. Check whether the Remaining Lifetime of the LSP is less than 60s when the neighbor sent it.
b. Check whether the LSP is an attack packet.
c. Check whether the Remaining Lifetime was changed manually.
�If the Remaining Lifetime of the LSP is less than 60s, check whether it was changed manually.
�If the Remaining Lifetime was changed manually, no action is required, and go to Step 3.
�If the Remaining Lifetime was not changed manually, go to Step 2.
�If the Remaining Lifetime of the LSP is not less than 60s, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

�Cause 2: A new router ID has been configured for an ABR in the NSSA, and the configuration has taken effect.
�Cause 3: A new device was added to the NSSA, or a device was removed from the NSSA.
�Cause 4: In the backbone area or NSSA, the OSPF protocol was restarted or an active/standby switchover was performed on a device, causing topology flapping.
�Cause 5: Manual command configuration or parameter modification caused a topology change in the backbone area or NSSA.

For example, the no-summary and no-import-route parameters of the nssa command were configured or canceled. As a result, neighbor relationships between the local device and neighbors in the backbone area and NSSA need to be re-established.
�Cause 6: The local device changed to be an ABR or changed from an ABR to another role.

�Cause 7: The topology of the backbone area or NSSA changed. As a result, the local device could not route traffic from the backbone area or NSSA to an ABR with a larger router ID or with the translator-always parameter configured.

�If no, go to Step 3.
�If the Nt bit does not change, go to Step 3.

�If yes, go to Step 11.
�If no, go to Step 4.
4. If a new router ID has been configured for an ABR other than the translator in the NSSA, check the configuration of this ABR.
4. If the router ID of an ABR changes, check whether the NSSA translator state of the local device is correct after the topology in the NSSA is stable.
�If yes, go to Step 11.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. If a new device is added to the NSSA or a device is removed from the NSSA:
�If no ABR is added to or removed from the NSSA, check whether the NSSA translator state of the local device is restored after the topology in the NSSA is stable.
�If yes, go to Step 11.
�If no, go to Step 6.
�If an ABR is added to or removed from the NSSA, check whether the NSSA translator state of the local device is correct after the topology in the NSSA is stable.
�If yes, go to Step 11.
�If no, go to Step 6.

�If no, go to Step 8.

If the translator state of the local device changes from DISABLED to ELECTED, but an ABR with a larger router ID or with the translator-always parameter configured exists in the NSSA, run the display ospf routing router-id [router-id] command to check whether there are backbone-area and NSSA routes to the original forwarder.

column4: PTP/4/hwPtpPortStateChange: The port status changes. (hwPtpPortIfIndex=[hwPtpPortIfIndex], hwPtpPortName=[hwPtpPortName], hwPtpPortState=[hwPtpPortState], hwPtpOldPortState=[hwPtpOldPortState]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

Cause 1: The attributes of the clock device on the network changed. As a result, the port status changed.
Cause 2: The link was faulty or the port was Down. As a result, the port status changed.
1. Run the display ptp all command to check whether the port is in the faulty state.
If yes, the link is faulty or the port is Down. In this case, go to Step 4.
If no, go to Step 2.

column4: EVPN/2/hwEvpnStickyMacConflict_active: Local sticky mac-addresses were conflicted in an EVPN instance. (EVPNInstanceName=[EVPNInstanceName], BdId=[BdId]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: A sticky MAC address conflict occurs in an EVPN instance.

column1: [BdId]Local BDID.

When different interface boards of the device learn the same MAC at the same time and synchronize messages with each other, the synchronization messages are discarded because Sticky MAC and reverse address checking are configured, resulting in inconsistent Sticky MAC entries among different interface boards.
According to the alarm information, run the reset mac-address <mac> bridge-domian <bdid> command to delete one sticky MAC address to ensure that no sticky MAC address conflict exists.
