TCPIP related traffic's discarded rate exceeded alarm threshold.

1. Run the display cpu-defend tcpip-defend statistics slot <slot-id> command to check the committed access rate (CIR) and committed burst rate (CBS) of the interface board. Check the values of Actual CIR in NP and Actual CBS in NP.

�If the protocol rate is too small to meet service requirements, run the car command to increase the rate and wait for 60 seconds. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
�If the configured protocol rate meets service running requirements but the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display cpu-defend policy <policy-number> command to check whether the alarm threshold and alarm interval of the protocol are set properly based on Application apperceive Configuration.
�If the alarm threshold is too low, run the alarm drop-rate command to increase the threshold based on service traffic. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
�If the alarm interval is too small, run the alarm drop-rate command to increase the alarm interval. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.

3. Run the display attack-source-trace slot <slot-id> original-information command to check the Attack Source Data item to check the packet header information cached by the attack source tracing module.

�If the source or destination IP address of a packet is not within the service range, configure an attack defense policy to filter the packet. For details, see Local Attack Defense Configuration in the Configuration Guide. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
�If the source or destination IP address of the packet meets service requirements but the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

7. Run the display eth-trunk <trunk-id> command to check whether the lower threshold for the number of Eth-Trunk member links in the Up state is configured for the Eth-Trunk, which causes the Eth-Trunk member interfaces to fail to negotiate with each other.
�If yes, go to Step 8.

vBRAS NLS:
1. Run the display interface brief command to check whether the member interface is Down.
2. Run the undo shutdown command and check whether the alarm is cleared.
3. Check whether the physical link fails.
4. Run the display eth-trunk [ <trunk-id> [ interface <interface-type> <interface-number> | verbose ] ] command to check whether the link aggregation group has member interfaces.

5. Run the display eth-trunk <trunk-id> command to check whether the lower threshold for the number of Eth-Trunk member links in the Up state is configured for the Eth-Trunk, which causes the Eth-Trunk member interfaces to fail to negotiate with each other.

column4: BFD/4/STACHG_TODWN: BFD session changed to Down. (SlotNumber=[SlotNumber], Discriminator=[Discriminator], Diagnostic=[Diagnostic], Applications=[Applications], ProcessPST=[ProcessPST], BindInterfaceName=[BindInterfaceName], InterfacePhysicalState=[InterfacePhysicalState], InterfaceProtocolState=[InterfaceProtocolState], TunnelName=[TunnelName], DownReason=[DownReason], NpDownTime=[NpDownTime], EvplId=[EvplId], PeerIpAddr=[PeerIpAddr], RootIp=[RootIp], LspId=[LspId], PrimaryFlag=[PrimaryFlag], Color=[Color], SegmentListId=[SegmentListId], MplsRvsBsid=[MplsRvsBsid], SRv6RvsBsid=[SRv6RvsBsid])
column5: The BFD session went Down.

column1: [Discriminator]Discriminator of a session.

[Diagnostic]Indicates the type of the Down state. The values are as follows: AdminDown: The local end proactively enters the AdminDown state. ReceiveAdminDown: The local end enters the Down state after receiving a BFD packet with the AdminDown state from the remote end. DetectDown: The local end enters the Down state when the detection expires because it does not receive BFD packets from the remote end. NeighborDown: The local end enters the Down state after receiving a BFD packet with the Down state from the remote end.
[Applications]Application that is bound to the BFD session.
[ProcessPST]Flag bit of the PST that is modified.
[BindInterfaceName]Name of the bound interface.
[InterfacePhysicalState]Physical status of the interface.
[InterfaceProtocolState]Protocol status of the interface.
[TunnelName]Name of the tunnel.
[DownReason]Reason why the session goes down.
[NpDownTime]Date and time when the BFD session goes down.
[EvplId]ID of an EVPL instance.
[PeerIpAddr]Destination address of a BFD session.
[RootIp]IP address of the P2MP tunnel's root node.
[LspId]P2MP LSP ID.
[PrimaryFlag]LSP primary/backup flag.
[Color]Color attribute of an SR Policy.
[SegmentListId]Segment list ID of an SR Policy.
[MplsRvsBsid]Binding SID of an MPLS return tunnel.
[SRv6RvsBsid]Binding SID of the return tunnel of an SRv6 TE Policy.
Cause 1: The session bound interface goes down.
Cause 2: The peer BFD session is deleted or shut down.
Cause 3: The link went Down or was congested. Consequently, packet forwarding fails.
1. Run the display interface command to check whether the physical status of the interface where the session resides is Up.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the session status is automatically restored.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display bfd session all command to check whether the BFD sessions at both ends are deleted.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Run the ping <ip-address> command to check whether the link detected by the BFD session fails to forward packets.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

[hwIsisPeerFlappingSuppressStatus]Suppression status are as follows: None: IS-IS neighbor relationship flapping suppression is not started yet. Hold-down: IS-IS neighbor relationship flapping suppression works in Hold-down mode. Hold-max-cost: IS-IS neighbor relationship flapping suppression works in Hold-max-cost mode.

[Reason]Suppression causes are as follows: The suppression exits because the hold-max-cost timer expires. The suppression exits because the hold-down timer expires. A configuration change occurs. A manual operation is performed to exit from flapping suppression. The neighbor relationship frequently flaps. The Hold-down mode exits, and then the Hold-max-cost mode takes effect.
IS-IS neighbor relationship flapping suppression started, or the interface exited from the suppression.

�Cause 65536: The board is pulled out.The trap was generated because the user pulled out the board without pressing the Offline button or running the power off command.
1. Check whether you need to insert a board in the slot.
�If you need to insert a board in the slot, go to Step 2.
�If you need not to insert a board in the slot, remove the trap. Then, go to Step 8.
2. Check which board is pulled out.
�If an interface board is pulled out, go to Step 3.
�If an SFU is pulled out, go to Step 4.
�If an MPU is pulled out, go to Step 5.
3. If an interface board is pulled out, you can select to insert an interface board or take no action according to your needs.
When the interface board is inserted, check whether the board works normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
4. If an SFU is pulled out, you can perform the following steps:
�If the current system works in 3+1 backup mode, you need not to take any action but go to Step 8.
�If less than three SFUs work in the current system, you need to insert SFUs and check whether the SFUs work normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
5. If an MPU is pulled out, you need to insert an MPU in the slot. Then, check whether the MPU works normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
6. Replace the corresponding board and then check whether the fault is rectified.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
7. Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration of the router, and contact technical support personnel.
8. End.
�Cause 65537: The board is pulled out.The trap was generated because the user pressed the Offline button and then pulled out the board.
1. Check whether you need to insert a board in the slot.
�If you need to insert a board in the slot, go to Step 2.
�If you need not to insert a board in the slot, remove the trap. Then, go to Step 8.
2. Check which board is pulled out.
�If an interface board is pulled out, go to Step 3.
�If an SFU is pulled out, go to Step 4.
�If an MPU is pulled out, go to Step 5.
3. If an interface board is pulled out, you can select to insert an interface board or take no action according to your needs.
When the interface board is inserted, check whether the board works normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
4. If an SFU is pulled out, you can perform the following steps:
�If the current system works in 3+1 backup mode, you need not to take any action but go to Step 8.
�If less than three SFUs work in the current system, you need to insert SFUs and check whether the SFUs work normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
5. If an MPU is pulled out, you need to insert an MPU in the slot. Then, check whether the MPU works normally.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
6. Replace the corresponding board and then check whether the fault is rectified.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
7. Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration of the router, and contact technical support personnel.
8. End.
�Cause 65538: The CF card was removed.
1.Check whether the CF card needs to be inserted into the board.
�If the CF card needs to be inserted into the board, go to Step 2.
�If the CF card does not need to be inserted into the board, clear the alarm. Then, go to Step 4.
2.Insert the CF card into the corresponding slot on the MPU. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 3.
3.Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4.End.
�Cause 65539: Card is removed.
1.Check whether the subcard needs to be inserted into the board.
�If the subcard needs to be inserted into the board, go to Step 2.
�If the subcard does not need to be inserted into the board, go to Step 4.
2.Insert the subcard into the corresponding slot on the LPU. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 3.
3.Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4.End.
�Cause 65540: Frame is removed.
1. Locate the chassis in which the trap is generated.
�If the trap is generated in the slave CCC, go to Step 2.
�If the trap is generated in the CLC, go to Step 6.
2. Check whether the link between the master CCC and the slave CCC is normal.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 4.
3. Check whether the two MPUs in the slave CCC work normally. Run the display device command to check whether the MPUs are present.
�If so, go to Step 9.
�If not, go to Step 5.
4. Replace the cable between the master CCC and the slave CCC and then check whether the trap is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 10.
�If not, go to Step 9.
5. Replace the faulty MPU and then check whether the trap is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 10.
�If not, go to Step 9.
6. Check whether the cable between the CLC and the CCC is correctly connected.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If not, go to Step 7.
7. Replace the faulty cable between the CCC and the CLC and then check whether the trap is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 10.
�If not, go to Step 8.
8. Check whether the MPU in the CLC is working properly.
�If so, go to Step 10.
�If not, go to Step 9.
9. Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
10. End.
�Cause 65541: The optical module was removed from an interface of the subcard.

2. Install the optical module in the interface. Check whether the trap is cleared.
�If the trap is cleared, go to Step 4.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect the trap information, log information, and configuration of the router, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

2. Re-insert the CMU and check whether the trap is cleared.

3. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column4: LCS/1/hwGtlDataDamaged_active: The license fails to be activated during system startup because the license data is damaged. (Position=[hwGtlPosition]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

column1: The license data on the device is damaged. As a result, the license fails to be activated during system startup.
1. Upload the new license file to the device. To apply for a new license file, see the License Usage Guide of the corresponding product.
2. Run the license active <filename> command in the user view to activate the license file.

column1: The RSVP neighbor or the link over which the RSVP neighbor relationship is established became faulty.
1. Check whether the physical link or the RSVP neighbor is faulty.
�If so, repair the physical link or restart the RSVP neighbor.
�If not, go to step 2.
2. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether there is a route to the RSVP neighbor.

FTPS
column4: FTPS/4/FTPS_IP_BLOCK_CLIENT: FTP client IP blocked due to authentication failure in last [LogIntervalTime] [LogTimeFormat]. (IpAddress=[IpAddress], VpnName=[VpnName], BlockCount=[BlockCount])
column5: The IP address of the FTP client is locked because the authentication fails within the specified period.

column1: [LogTimeFormat]Indicates the time format, in the format of hour/minute/second.
[IpAddress]Indicates the IP address of the locked client.
[VpnName]Indicates the name of the VPN instance to which the locked client belongs.
[BlockCount]Indicates the number of times that the client IP address is locked due to authentication failures within a specified period.
The IP address of the FTP client is locked because the FTP client fails to be authenticated for multiple times.
By default, if the login fails for six consecutive times within 5 minutes, the account will be locked for 5 minutes.

Run the display vty ip-block vty-password-mode all command to check the IP address that fails to be authenticated. If the IP address is used for login, run the activate vty ip-block ip-address [ vpnname ] command to unblock the IP address.

(SysProcessId=[hwOspfv2ProcessIdIndex], HostName=[hwOspfv2PurgeHostName], HostIpAddress=[hwOspfv2PurgeIpAddress], RouterID=[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId], Area=[hwOspfv2AreaId], TotalNodeNum=[hwOspfv2TotalNodeNum], Log in to the following devices to locate the faulty device: (1) HostName=[hwOspfv2PurgeHostName1], HostIpAddress=[hwOspfv2PurgeIpAddress1], RouterID=[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId1] (2) HostName=[hwOspfv2PurgeHostName2], HostIpAddress=[hwOspfv2PurgeIpAddress2], RouterID=[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId2] (3) HostName=[hwOspfv2PurgeHostName3], HostIpAddress=[hwOspfv2PurgeIpAddress3], RouterID=[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId3])
column5: The local device received a flush LSA from a neighbor indicating that the OSPF LSAs advertised by a third device were flushed. In this case, log in to a possibly faulty node and check whether it is flushing LSAs. If it is flushing LSAs, reset or isolate it. If the possibly faulty node is not flushing LSAs, check other possibly faulty nodes.

column1: [hwOspfv2PurgeHostName]Hostname of the faulty node

[hwOspfv2AreaId]OSPF area ID

[hwOspfv2PurgeRouterId3]Router ID of the possibly faulty node.
The local device received a flush LSA from a neighbor indicating that the OSPF LSAs advertised by a third device were flushed.

1. Log in to the suspected faulty device and run the display ospf routing command to check whether any route is deleted. If yes, isolate the faulty device from the network (reset or isolate the faulty device). If not, check other devices.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

[RttMax]Indicates the maximum RTT.
[MaxDelaySD]Indicates the OWD from the source to the destination.
[MaxDelayDS]Indicates the OWD from the destination to the source.

Cause 1: The threshold was set too small.
Cause 2: The network was busy.
1. Run the display cpu-usage command in the system view to check whether the CPU has an excessive load.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 2.

2. In the NQA test view, run the display this command to know the current threshold. Then run the threshold jitter-ds command to modify the threshold as required. The recommended value is 20 ms. Perform the test again to check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

�If so, go to Step 3.

1. Check whether the faulty board is a flexible subcard board or a non-flexible subcard board.
�If it is a flexible subcard, go to Step 2.

�If so, go to Step 6.
�If not, go to Step 4.

�Cause 0: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

1. Check whether AddressFamily is IPv4. If AddressFamily is IPv4, the alarm is triggered in the IPv4 address family of a VPN instance. Perform the following operations:
�a. Run the display multicast pim sm statistics command to check whether the alarm trigger threshold or the number limit is low.
�If the alarm trigger threshold or the number limit is low, go to Step b.

2. Check whether AddressFamily is IPv6. If AddressFamily is IPv6, the alarm is triggered in the IPv6 address family of a VPN instance. Perform the following operations:
�a. Run the display multicast ipv6 pim sm statistics command to check whether the alarm trigger threshold or the number limit is low.
�If the alarm trigger threshold or the number limit is low, go to Step b.
�If the alarm trigger threshold or the number limit is not low, go to Step c.

�If the fault is rectified, go to Step d.
�If the fault is not rectified, go to Step c.

[DestData]Configuration change object. 1: existing startup file specified as the startup file for the next startup 2: running configuration 3: startup configuration file 4: local file, which is not a configuration file 5: FTP 6: hot swap

[ConfigChangeId]Sequence number of the configuration change. After the device is restarted in CFG mode, the sequence number in the log is not cleared and will be recorded again in CFG mode.
[LogTime]Configuration change time. It refers to the number of ticks since the system is started.
[CfgBaselineTime]Baseline time configured on the device. When the configuration changes (for example, the system restarts), the system updates the time.

column4: ISIS/6/ISIS_SEND_SELF_PURGED_LSP: ISIS [ProcessId] send a purged LSP. (Level=[Level], PduLspId=[PduLspId],LocalSystemId=[LocalSystemId], SeqNumber=[SeqNumber], CheckSum=[CheckSum])
column5: The IS-IS system sent a self-purged LSP to another system.

column1: [Level]Indicates the IS-IS level.
[PduLspId]Indicates the ID of the self-purged LSP.
[LocalSystemId]Indicates the local system ID.
[SeqNumber]Indicates the purged LSP's sequence number.
[CheckSum]Indicates the checksum of self purged LSP.
The IS-IS system sent a local purged LSP to another system.
1. Check whether the LocalSystemId field is filled in the log information.

2. Check the PduLspId field in the log. If the log is generated on the peer device, locate the peer device and check the IS-IS LSDB on the peer device. If the log is generated on the local device, check the IS-IS LSDB on the local device.
3. Check whether the LSP is cleared on the local device and whether the sequence number and checksum are normal.
4. View the log generation frequency to check whether interface flapping occurs.
5. If no exception is found, collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support engineers.
6. End.

The local device received a flush LSA from a neighbor, indicating that the OSPFv3 LSAs advertised by a third device were flushed.

1. Log in to the suspected faulty device and run the display ospfv3 routing command to check whether routes are deleted. If routes are being deleted from the suspected faulty device, isolate the faulty device from the network (reset or isolate the faulty device). Otherwise, check other devices.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

BGP
column4: BGP/3/hwBgpSidLabelConflict_active: The prefix-sid label conflict is detected. (label=[Label], Vpn instance =[Vpn-instance], BGP instance name=[InstanceName], Address Family=[AddressFamily], prefix=[Prefix])
column5: The prefix-sid label conflict is detected.

column1: [Vpn-instance]VPN instance name.
[InstanceName]BGP instance name. - indicates the default BGP instance, and other values indicate multiple instances.
[Prefix]route.
Cause 1: The label applied for the BGP route learned from another device is the same as the label applied for the network route on the local device.
Cause 2: The BGP and OSPF processes need to apply for the same label.
Cause 3: The BGP and ISIS processes need to apply for the same label.

1. If a BGP process label conflict occurs, run the network {<ipv4-address> [<mask> | <mask-length>]} route-filter <route-filter-name> [non-relay-tunnel] label-index <label-index-value> command on the source or local device to change the label-index of the route. 2. If the label of a BGP process conflicts with that of an OSPF process, run the network {<ipv4-address> [<mask> | <mask-length>]} route-filter <route-filter-name> [non-relay-tunnel] label-index <label-index-value> command in the BGP view to change the label-index of the route, or run the ospf prefix-sid {absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value>} [node-disable] command in the interface view to change the label-index of the interface. 2. If the label of a BGP process conflicts with that of an IS-IS process, run the network {<ipv4-address> [<mask> | <mask-length>]} route-filter <route-filter-name> [non-relay-tunnel] label-index <label-index-value> command in the BGP view to change the label-index of the route, or run the isis prefix-sid {absolute <sid-value> | index <index-value>} [node-disable] command in the interface view to change the label-index of the interface. 4. Collect alarm and configuration information and contact technical support engineers.

Cause 1: The physical link carried over the external time port is down.
Cause 2: Different time formats are specified for the external time ports on the upstream and downstream devices.
1. Check whether the physical link of the external time interface is Up.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Determine the reason why the physical link goes Down, check whether the connection is disconnected, and restore the link. Then, check whether the recovery alarm is generated.
�If yes, go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
3. Check whether the time port modes of the upstream and downstream devices match.
�If yes, go to Step 5.
�If no, go to Step 4.

4. The time format of the time port is correctly configured. For details, see System Management in Huawei Universal Service Router Configuration Manual. - If the configuration is incorrect, reconfigure the configuration and check whether the clear alarm is generated.

column4: MSDP/2/msdpBackwardTransition_active: MSDP peer exit the established state. (RemoteAddr=[RemoteAddr], PeerState=[PeerState], InstanceName=[InstanceName], ExitReason=[ExitReason])
column5: The status of the MSDP peer changes from Established to another state.

column1: [PeerState]Status of the MSDP peer relationship
[InstanceName]Instance name
[ExitReason]Causes triggering the alarm
�Cause 1: HoldTime expired
�Cause 3: Socket error
�Cause 4: Receive invalid TLV
�Cause 5: Receive notification TLV
�Cause 6: User operation
�Cause 1: HoldTime expired
1. Run the ping command to check whether the link between the and the peer is normal.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the unicast route to the peer is normal.
�If the route is normal, go to Step 3.
�If the route is abnormal, rectify the unicast route fault to clear the alarm.
3. Run the display msdp peer-status command in the MSDP view of the peer to check the status of the peer, that is, the State field.
�If the status is Up, go to Step 4.
�If the MSDP peer relationship is in the Shutdown state, run the undo shutdown command in the MSDP view of the MSDP peer to clear the alarm.
�If the status is Down, check the Connect interface field to see whether the IP address of the interface used to establish the TCP connection is correct.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If no, run the peer connect-interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command in the MSDP view to configure a correct IP address for the interface.
�In the case of other states, run the display msdp peer-status command to check whether the MSDP authentication configurations on both ends are the same.
�If they are the same, go to Step 4.

�If they are different, configure the same MSDP authentication on both ends of the peer peer-address password { cipher cipher-password | simple simple-password } or peer peer-address keychain keychain-name to clear the alarm.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 3: Socket error
1. Run the ping command to check whether the link between the MSDP peers is Up.
�If the link is Up, go to Step 3.
�If the link is Down, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display ip routing-table command to check whether the unicast route from the local device to the peer device works properly.
�If the route works properly, go to Step 3.
�If the route works improperly, you can clear the alarm by rectifying the routing fault.
3. Run the display current-configuration command to check whether multicast is enabled on both MSDP peers.
�If multicast is enabled on both MSDP peers, go to Step 4.
�If multicast is not enabled on both MSDP peers, run the multicast routing-enable command to enable multicast to clear the alarm.
4. Run the display this command in the MSDP view of both MSDP peers to check whether the MSDP peer relationship is configured.
�If the MSDP peer relationship is configured, go to Step 5.
�If no MSDP peer relationship is configured, run the peerconnect-interface<interface-type><interface-number> command in the MSDP view to configure the MSDP peer relationship to clear the alarm.
5. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 4: Receive invalid TLV
1. The MSDP implementations on both peers may be different. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 5: Receive notification TLV
1. Check whether the reset msdp peer command is run in the user view on the peer device.
�If the command is run, wait till the peer relationship is re-established.
�If the command is not run, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display this command in the MSDP view of the peer device to check whether the MSDP peer relationship is configured.
�If the MSDP peer relationship is configured, go to Step 3.
�If no MSDP peer relationship is configured, run the peerconnect-interface<interface-type><interface-number> command in the MSDP view to configure the MSDP peer relationship to clear the alarm.
3. Run the display interface brief command to check whether the shutdown command is run on interfaces connecting the MSDP peers.
�If the shutdown command is run, run the undo shutdown command in the interface view to clear the alarm.
�If no shutdown command is run, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 6: User operation
1. Check whether the reset msdp peer command is run in the user view.
�If the command is run, wait till the peer relationship is re-established.
�If the command is not run, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display this command in the MSDP view to check whether the MSDP peer relationship is configured.
�If the MSDP peer relationship is configured, go to Step 3.
�If no MSDP peer relationship is configured, run the peerconnect-interface<interface-type><interface-number> command in the MSDP view to configure the MSDP peer relationship to clear the alarm.
3. Run the display interface brief command to check whether the shutdown command is configured on interfaces connecting the MSDP peers.
�If the shutdown command is run, run the undo shutdown command in the interface view to clear the alarm.
�If no shutdown command is run, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column1: [TunnelInstIndex]Indicates the InstIndex of the tunnel.
[IngressLsrId]Indicates the LSR ID of the ingress on the tunnel.
[EgressLsrId]Indicates the LSR ID of the egress on the tunnel.
[mplsTunnelIfName]Indicates the name of a tunnel.
[hwMplsTunnelDownReason]Indicates the reason why a tunnel goes Down.
[hwMplsTunnelDownLSRId]Indicates the LSR ID of the error node on a tunnel.
[hwMplsTunnelDownIfAddrType]Indicates the IP address type of the error interface on a tunnel.
[hwMplsTunnelDownIfAddr]Indicates the IP address of the error interface on a tunnel.

�Cause 1: Others
�Cause 2: A static LSP went Down.
�Cause 3: A static CR-LSP went Down.
�Cause 4: The outbound interface of an RSVP-TE LSP's ingress went Down.
�Cause 5: RSVP-TE LSP resources were preempted.
�Cause 6: Transmission of an RSVP message timed out.
�Cause 7: RSVP Hello mechanism detected a downstream node failure.
�Cause 8: The bypass tunnel in use was Down or unbound from the primary tunnel.
�Cause 9: CSPF failed to calculate a path.
�Cause 10: The tunnel was manually shut down.
�Cause 1: Others

1. Run the display mpls te tunnel-interface <tunnel-name> command on the ingress (that is, the node that generates the trap) to check the configurations of the tunnel. View the Tunnel State Desc field to check whether the tunnel is in the Down state Then, run the display mpls te tunnel-interface last-error command to view the prompt.
�In the case of the following error prompts, do as required:
�If the error prompt is Cspf failed to calculate a path for Tunnel. (indicating that the ingress is enabled with CSPF, but the CSPF path calculation fails), go to Step 2.
�If the error prompt is Trigger Rsvp failed, go to Step 2.
�If the error prompt is One LSP is deleted at smooth period, go to Step 6.
�If the error prompt is One LSP is deleted at Tunnel aging period, go to Step 6.
�For other types of errors, go to Step 6.
�If there is no error prompt, go to Step 2.
2. Run the ping command on the ingress to check whether the destination IP address of the tunnel can be pinged.

�If the ping fails, rectify the route fault to ensure that the destination IP address of the tunnel can be pinged, and then check whether the alarm MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.46 hwMplsTunnelPrimaryUp is generated.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If not, go to Step 3.
�If the ping is successful, go to Step 3.
3. Run the display this command in the MPLS view of the ingress to check whether the mpls te cspf command is configured, that is, to check whether the CSPF is enabled.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 5.

4. Run the display mpls te cspf destination command on the ingress to check whether a path that meets the constraints is available. If so, the path of the TE tunnel is displayed, indicating that CSPF calculation is successful. If not, null is displayed, indicating that CSPF calculation fails.

�If the path is successfully calculated, run the display current-configuration interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command on the ingress to check the tunnel configurations, including the primary tunnel, protection tunnel, and the protection interface. Check whether the mpls te auto-frr command is configured in the MPLS view. If so, it indicates that Auto FRR is enabled. In this case, you can check the primary tunnel. If not, check whether the mpls te fast-reroute, mpls te record-route, and mpls te bypass-tunnel are configured to identify the primary and backup tunnels.
After the primary and backup tunnels are checked, you can check the explicit-path command to verify whether the explicit path is configured
column2: check the mpls te affinity property command to verify whether the affinity property is configured
column3: check the mpls te bandwidth command to verify whether the bandwidth is configured.

column1: Run the display mpls te cspf destination command and configure the parameters of constraints one by one, including the priority (priority setup-priority), bandwidth (bandwidth), explicit path (explicit-path path-name), affinity property (affinity properties), and hop limit (hop-limit hop-limit-number), and you can check whether the path that meets the constraints is available. If so, the path of the TE tunnel is displayed, indicating that CSPF calculation is successful. If not, null is displayed, indicating that CSPF calculation fails.

�a. If the explicit path fails to be calculated, check whether the interfaces along the explicit path are in the Up state and are enabled with MPLS and MPLS TE. If the explicit path is successfully calculated, check whether path calculation according to the affinity property and bandwidth is consistent with the explicit path by running the display mpls te cspf destination <ip-address> bandwidth ct0 <ct0-bandwidth> explicit-path <path-name> command.

�b. If CSPF path calculation fails after affinity property is configured, run the mpls te affinity property command in the tunnel view to modify the affinity property of the tunnel, or run the mpls te link administrative group on the interfaces along the tunnel to modify the administrative group property of the link.

�c. If CSPF path calculation fails after bandwidth is configured, run the display mpls te link-administration bandwidth-allocation interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command to check whether the bandwidth of each outbound interface along the tunnel is enough. If the bandwidth is enough, it is possible that the tunnel with a higher priority preempts the bandwidth of the current tunnel. Then run the mpls te bandwidth max-reservable-bandwidth and mpls te bandwidth commands in the interface view to increase the bandwidth.
�d. If CSPF path calculation fails because of other constraints, go to Step 6.
�Then, check whether the alarm MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.46 hwMplsTunnelPrimaryUp is generated.
�If so, go to Stpe 7.
�If not, go to Step 5.
�If CSPF path calculation fails, go to Step 5.

5. Run the display explicit-path command to check the interfaces along the tunnel. Then, run the display this command in the interface view of each interface of the tunnel to check whether the interface is enabled with MPLS, MPLS TE, and RSVP-TE.
�If MPLS, MPLS TE, or RSVP-TE is not enabled, run the mpls, mpls te or mpls rsvp-te commands in the view of the interface.

�If any interface along the tunnel is not in Up state, restart the interface. That is, run the shutdown and then undo shutdown commands in the interface view, or run the restartcommand in the interface view .
Then, check whether the alarm MPLS_LSPM_1.3.6.1.4.1.2011.5.25.121.2.1.46 hwMplsTunnelPrimaryUp is generated.
�If so, go to Step 7.
�If not, go to Step 6.
6. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
7. End.

SSH
column4: SSH/3/hwSSHLoginFailed_active: Users failed to login ssh server too frequently. (failed times=[hwUserInfoLoginFailedTimes], statistic period=[hwUserInfoStatisticPeriod] minutes)
column5: The number of login failures of SSH server during a specified period exceeded the threshold.

column1: [hwUserInfoStatisticPeriod]Indicates the interval for collecting the number of login failures.
The number of login failures of SSH server during a specified period exceeded the threshold.
1. By default, an alarm is generated if 30 or more login failures occur within 5 minutes, and the alarm is cleared if the number of login failures within 5 minutes is less than 20.
2. Contact the administrator to obtain the correct SSH user name and password and log in to the device again. After the login is successful, the alarm is cleared after a statistical period.
3. Run the display current-configuration configuration ssh include-default | include login-failed command to query the threshold for the number of SSH server login failures within a specified period.
�This alarm is cleared when the number of login failures within a specified period (unit: minute) specified by ssh server login-failed threshold-alarm is less than the alarm clearance threshold.

column5: Collect maintenance information about the Callhome function.

column1: Cause 1: The IP address and TCP port number of the NMS that sets up a CallHome connection with the device are incorrect.
Cause 2: The SNettconf service is disabled on the SSH server.
Cause 3: The number of NETCONF connections reached the maximum number of NETCONF users.
1. The handling methods for different causes are as follows:
Cause 1: Check whether the configured NMS IP address and TCP port number are correct.
If no, configure the correct NMS IP address and TCP port number.
If yes, go to step 2.
For cause 2: Run the display current-configuration configuration ssh | include snetconf command to check whether the SNETCONF service is enabled on the SSH server.
If no, run the snetconf server enable command to enable the SNetconf service.
If yes, go to step 2.
Cause 3: The number of NETCONF connections reached the maximum number of NETCONF users.
If so, run the max-sessions command in the NETCONF user interface view to change the maximum number of users.
If no, go to Step 2.
2. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

column4: OSPF/1/ospfRouteLoopDetected_active: The local device has detected an OSPF routing loop. (LoopType=[LoopType], DetectProtocolAttr=[DetectProtocolAttr], RedistributeID1=[RedistributeID1], RedistributeID2=[RedistributeID2])
column5: The device detects an OSPF routing loop.

column1: [DetectProtocolAttr]Information about the loop detection protocol.
[RedistributeID1]Re-advertisement device ID 1.
[RedistributeID2]Re-advertisement device ID 2.
�Cause 1:
If the loop detection type is OSPF, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 and RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the two devices where a routing loop occurs. When the OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 2:
If the loop detection type is OSPF-ISIS, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 correspond to the System ID of the ISIS processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs, RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs. When the ISIS/OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF/ISIS processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 3:
If the loop detection type is OSPF-BGP, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

When the BGP/OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF/BGP processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs. RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 1:
If the loop detection type is OSPF, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 and RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the two devices where a routing loop occurs. When the OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPF automatically increases the cost of the imported route to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the policy for importing routes in the OSPF processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospf process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.

After eliminating the risk source that causes the loop, run the clear route loop-detect ospf alarm-state command in the system view of the device that generates the alarm to clear the alarm and restore the cost of the imported route to the normal value.
�Cause 2:
If the loop detection type is OSPF-ISIS, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 correspond to the System ID of the ISIS processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs, RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs. When the ISIS/OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF/ISIS processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPF automatically increases the cost of the imported route to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the route import policy configuration in the IS-IS and OSPF processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospf process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.

After eliminating the risk source that causes the loop, run the clear route loop-detect ospf alarm-state command in the system view of the device that generates the alarm to clear the alarm and restore the cost of the imported route to the normal value.
�Cause 3:
If the loop detection type is OSPF-BGP, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

When the BGP/OSPF processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPF/BGP processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs. RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPF processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPF automatically increases the cost of the imported route to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the policy configuration for importing routes in the BGP and OSPF processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospf process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.

After eliminating the risk source that causes the loop, run the clear route loop-detect ospf alarm-state command in the system view of the device that generates the alarm to clear the alarm and restore the cost of the imported route to the normal value.

(hwClockSrcCfgChassisIndex=[hwClockSrcCfgChassisIndex], hwClockSrcCfgSourceTypeIndex=[hwClockSrcCfgSourceTypeIndex], hwClockSrcCfgSourceIndex=[hwClockSrcCfgSourceIndex], hwClockChassisId=[hwClockChassisId], hwClockSrcCfgFreqCheckResult=[hwClockSrcCfgFreqCheckResult], hwClockSrcCfgSourceDescr=[hwClockSrcCfgSourceDescr]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.

The signals of the clock source were faulty.
1. Run the display clock source command to check the current status of the clock source.
�If the clock source status is abnormal, go to Step 2.
�If the clock source status is normal, go to Step 5.
2. Run the display clock config command to check whether clock source switching based on frequency offset is enabled.
�If frequency offset-based clock source switching is not enabled, go to Step 5.
�If frequency offset-based clock source switching is enabled, go to Step 3.
3. Run the clock freq-deviation recover command in the interface view to check whether the clock status is restored.
�If the clock is restored, go to Step 4.
�If the clock status cannot be restored, go to Step 5.
4. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 6.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

Cause 1: VRRP negotiation of the master device timed out due to a network fault.
Cause 2: The priority of the device in the VRRP group was changed using the vrrp vrid virtual-router-id priority priority-value command.
Cause 3: The virtual IP address of the VRRP backup group was changed using the vrrp vrid virtual-router-id [ virtual-ip virtual-address ] command.
Cause 4: A master/backup switchover occurred in the mVRRP group. As a result, the device changed to the Master state.
Cause 5: The vrrp passive command was run to enable the passive mode, and the device was forcibly switched to the Master state.
This message is informational only, and no action is required.

column4: PIM/4/HW_UPSTREAM_NOPIM: In the VPN instance, PIM is not enabled on the upstream interface. (VPNName=[VPNName], IfName=[IfName], DestAddr=[DestAddr])
column5: PIM selects the interface as the inbound interface of PIM entries based on unicast routes. However, the interface does not support PIM. As a result, the device cannot generate complete PIM entries and cannot send PIM Join messages to the upstream device through the interface, causing a traffic diversion failure.

column1: [IfName]Interface name.
[DestAddr]Destination address.
PIM selects the interface as the inbound interface of PIM entries based on unicast routes, but the interface does not support PIM.
1. Obtain interface information based on the log information and check whether the interface supports PIM-SM.
�If PIM-SM is supported and multicast traffic passes through the interface as planned, run the pim sm command on the interface to enable PIM. Then, check whether multicast entries are normal.
�If yes, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 3.
�If PIM-SM is not supported, go to Step 2.

2. Configure a static route to generate a unicast route to the multicast source or RP. Ensure that the outbound interface of the unicast route is an interface that supports PIM-SM. Then run the pim sm command on the outbound interface of the corresponding PIM entry.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

The number of IFIT measurement flow reaches 90% of the upper limit.

column5: The DCN NE IP addresses conflict. When NEs with conflicting NE IP addresses exist on a network, the alarm is generated.

column1: �Cause 1: There might be two or more NEs with the same NEIP address.
�Cause 2: Two or more NEs are connected to two DCN domains.
�Cause 1: There might be two or more NEs with the same NEIP address.
1. Check whether NEs have the same NEIP address.
2. If yes, change NEIP addresses to be unique.
3. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: Two or more NEs are connected to two DCN domains.
1.Check whether the DCN domain configuration is correct. If the DCN domain configuration is correct, ignore this alarm. If the DCN domain configuration is incorrect, reconfigure the DCN domain.
2. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: OSPF/6/OSPFV2_LSDB_APPROACH_OVERFLOW: The number of AS-external LSAs in the LSDB of an OSPF process is approaching the configured maximum number.(ospfRouterId=[ospfRouterId], ospfExtLsdbLimit=[ospfExtLsdbLimit])
column5: The number of external routes in the OSPF LSDB reached or exceeded 90% of the maximum number.
column6: [ospfRouterId]hwOspfv2ProcessIdIndex: ID of an OSPF process Router ID

column1: [ospfExtLsdbLimit]90% of the maximum number of external routes allowed in the OSPF LSDB
The number of external routes in the OSPF LSDB reached or exceeded 90% of the maximum number.
1. Run the display ospf brief command. If OSPF is in LSDB overflow status is displayed in the command output, the OSPF LSDB in the current OSPF process is overloaded.
�If the OSPF LSDB is overloaded, go to Step 2.
�If the OSPF LSDB is not overloaded, this log message is informational only and no action is required.
2. Perform the following operations as required:
�If a change in the maximum number is allowed, run the lsdb-overflow-limit number command to increase it.
�If a change in the maximum number is not allowed, go to Step 3.
3. Contact technical support personnel.

DEVM
column4: DEVM/3/PHY_ERROR_PACKET: Port [STRING1] detected abnormal packets. ([STRING2])
column5: Packet loss occurred on a physical interface. When the number of upstream or downstream error packets exceeds the threshold, the log is recorded every 15 minutes until the alarm is cleared. The log records only new error packets that are lost within 15 minutes.

column1: [STRING2]Name and number of error packets on an interface. The value varies according to the interface type. Type of error packets received on an Ethernet interface: Overrun InRangeLength LongPacket Alignment Jabber Fragment Undersized Frame Type of error packets sent by an Ethernet interface: Overflow Underrun System Lost Type of error packets received by a POS interface: shortpacket longpacket lostpacket Lost Type of error packets sent by a POS interface: overrunpackets underrunpackets Type of error packets received by a WAN interface: Overrun InRangeLength LongPacket shortpacket Jabber Fragment Type of error packets sent by a WAN interface: Overrun System The actual interface types supported by the device are displayed in the help information after the interface command is executed.

Cause 1: Traffic packets were illegitimate. For example, the maximum length of packets that can be received by an interface is 9600 bytes, but the length of packets received from the peer end is greater than 9600 bytes. In this case, the interface reports LongPacket statistics logs.

Cause 2: The CRC encapsulation of traffic packets was inconsistent with that on the device. For example, the packets received by the device do not carry the CRC byte, but the device removes the CRC byte by default. In addition, the packet length is greater than the maximum packet length that is allowed by the interface. As a result, the interface reports Jabber statistics logs.
1. Run the display this interface command in the interface view to check whether the packet statistics displayed in the log on the interface are not 0.
�If so, go to Step 2.
�If not, go to Step 3.
2. Check whether the physical link is normal and collect the check result.
�If the interface is an electrical interface, check whether the network cable is normal.
�If the interface is an optical interface, run the display this interface command to check whether the receive optical power of the optical module is within the normal range.
�Check whether the configurations at both ends of the interface are consistent.
3. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.

6. End.

Cause 1: The network is faulty. As a result, the VRRP negotiation on the master device times out.
Cause 2: The priority of the device in the VRRP group is changed.
Cause 3: The virtual IP address of the VRRP group is specified.
Cause 4: A master/backup switchover occurs in the mVRRP group. As a result, the device changes to the Master state.
Cause 5: The vrrp passive command is run to enable the passive mode, and the device is forcibly switched to the master state.

[ChangeReason]The reason why the interface linkage status changes.
0) BFD DOWN.
1) bfd state up, exit linkage state.
2) bfd state unknown, exit linkage state.
3) bfd session is deleted, exiting the linkage state.
4) The neighbor protocol is down to delete the neighbor and exit the linkage state.
5) Delete the bfd linkage cost value, exit the linkage state, delete the neighbor.
6) When the number of neighbors changes to multiple, the number of neighbors changes to the linkage state and the neighbors are deleted.
This log message is informational only, and no action is required.

�Cause 3: VC was deleted.
1. Check whether the VPWS connection needs to be deleted.

�If no, go to Step 2.

�Cause 19: Interface was Down.
1. Run the display mpls static-l2vc interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command to check the AC state.
�If the AC interface is down, go to Step 2.
�If the AC interface is up, go to Step 3.

2. Run the display interface <interface-type> <interface-number> command to check the physical status and link status of the AC interface. If the interface is down, restore the physical and link status of the interface to up, and then check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 4.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 24: Tunnel was Down.
1. Run the display mpls static-l2vc command to check whether the tunnel ID exists.
�If yes, go to Step 3.
�If no, go to Step 4.

2. Check whether the public network-side interface is down. After the public network-side interface goes up, run the display tunnel-info all command to check whether the tunnel goes up. Then, check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 4.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
�Cause 32: PW was recreated.
1. Check whether the fault is rectified.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 3.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 41: Local PSN Fault.

1. Run the display tunnel-info all command to check information about the tunnel to the peer end. Adjust the configuration of the outbound interface on the public network to restore the tunnel to the peer end. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the fault is rectified, go to Step 3.
�If the fault persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

RM
column4: RM/2/hwL3vpnIpv6PrefixExceed_active: The number of IPv6 prefixes in the VPN instance exceeded the maximum value. (VpnInstanceName=[VpnInstanceName], PrefixCount=[PrefixCount], MaxValue=[MaxValue])
column5: The number of IPv6 route prefixes in a VPN instance exceeded the maximum number that is allowed.

column1: [PrefixCount]Current number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance
[MaxValue]Maximum number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance
Cause1: A large number of IPv6 routes were added to the routing table.
Cause2: The maximum number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance was reduced.

1. Run the display ipv6 routing-table vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> statistics command to check the total number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance and the number of routes of each routing protocol that are added to the IPv6 routing table. Then, run the display ipv6 routing-table limit command to check whether the number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeds the configured maximum number. - If the number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance exceeds the configured maximum number, go to 2. - If the number of IPv6 route prefixes in the VPN instance is less than the configured maximum number, go to 3. 2. Delete unneeded IPv6 VPN routes or run the prefix limit <number> { alert-percent | simply-alert } command to increase the maximum number. Then, check whether the alarm persists. - If the alarm persists, go to 3. - If the alarm is cleared, go to 4. 3. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel. 4. End.

column4: ISIS/2/ISIS_LSP_TOO_LARGE_TO_PROPAGATE: ISIS attempt to propagate an LSP which is larger than the dataLinkBlockSize for the circuit. (isisSysInstance=[isisSysInstance], isisSysLevelIndex=[isisSysLevelIndex], isisCircIndex=[isisCircIndex], isisCircIfIndex=[isisCircIfIndex], isisPduLspSize=[isisPduLspSize], isisPduLspId=[isisPduLspId], ifIndex=[ifIndex], IfName=[IfName])
column5: IS-IS attempted to send an LSP whose length was greater than the MTU on an interface.
column6: [isisSysInstance]Indicates the ID of the IS-IS process.

column1: [isisSysLevelIndex]Indicates the IS-IS level. 1: Level-1 2: Level-2

During LSP forwarding, the length of an LSP was greater than the MTU on an interface.
1. Run the display this include-default command in the interface view to check the MTU configured on the interface (related command: mtu <mtuvalue>).
2. Run the display this include-default command in the IS-IS process view to check the size of the received LSP (related command: lsp-length receive <max-size>).
3. Compare the MTUs of all interfaces with the LSP size to ensure that the MTUs of all interfaces are greater than the LSP length.
�If the MTU of an interface is smaller than the LSP length, go to Step 4.
�If the MTUs of all interfaces are greater than the LSP length, go to Step 5.
4. Change the MTU or LSP length based on service requirements.
5. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

column4: VRRP/3/VRRP_DOUBLE_MASTER_ERR: VRRP detected double masters. (IfIndex=[IfIndex], IfName=[IfName], VrId=[VrId], PeerIp=[SrcIpAddr], PeerPriority=[PeerPriority])
column5: VRRP detected two master devices.

column1: [IfName]Interface name
[VrId]ID of a VRRP group
[SrcIpAddr]Primary IP address of the remote interface where a VRRP group running IPv4 resides
[PeerPriority]Priority of the VRRP group on the remote interface
Cause 1: The local VRRP group failed to send out VRRP protocol packets.
Cause 2: The VRRP protocol packets sent by the local VRRP group were discarded due to overloaded links.
Cause 3: The configurations (authentication mode, authentication key, and list of virtual IP addresses) of the local and remote VRRP groups are different.
1. Run the debugging vrrp command to check the reason why VRRP packets are not sent.
2. Run the display cpu-defend car protocol vrrp statistics slot <slot-id> command to check whether the link is overloaded.

3. Run the display vrrp command to check whether the authentication modes and authentication keys on both ends are the same. If not, run the vrrp vrid <virtual-router-id> authentication-mode {simple {[plain] <key> | cipher <cipher-key>} | md5 <md5-key> } command to reconfigure the authentication mode for VRRP packets. The MD5 encryption algorithm has low security and has security risks.

4. Run the display vrrp command to check whether the virtual IP addresses and the number of virtual IP addresses are the same. If not, run the vrrp vrid <virtual-router-id> virtual-ip <virtual-address> command to reconfigure the virtual IP address of the VRRP group.
5. End.

�Cause 0: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: TCP/4/SOCKET_TCP6_TCP_AO_AUTHEN_FAIL: TCP6 TCP-AO authentication not success. (tcpConnLocalAddress=[tcpConnLocalAddress], tcpConnLocalPort=[tcpConnLocalPort], tcpConnRemAddress=[tcpConnRemAddress], tcpConnRemPort=[tcpConnRemPort], hwTCPProtocol=[hwTCPProtocol], hwTCPVrfName=[hwTCPVrfName])
column5: The TCP-AO authentication of the TCP6 connection fails.
column6: [tcpConnLocalAddress]Local IP address of a TCP connection.

column1: [tcpConnLocalPort]Local port number of a TCP connection.
[tcpConnRemAddress]Destination IP address of a TCP connection.
[tcpConnRemPort]Destination port number of a TCP connection.
[hwTCPProtocol]Name of an upper-layer application protocol.
[hwTCPVrfName]VRF name.
Cause 1: TCP-AO was configured on both ends of the TCP connection, but the encryption algorithms or keys in the effective key IDs were inconsistent.
Cause 2: Incomplete TCP-AO is configured on one end.
Cause 3: One end requires TCP-AO to take effect, but the other end is not configured with TCP-AO.

1. Run the display current-configuration command on the devices at both ends of the TCP connection to check whether TCP-AO is configured. If only one end is configured with TCP-AO, configure TCP-AO on the end that is not configured with TCP-AO. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 2. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.

2. Check whether the TCP-AO configurations on both ends are complete. A complete TCP-AO configuration must be bound to a keychain. A key ID must be configured, and the corresponding key ID, algorithm, key, and effective time must be configured in the keychain. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 3. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.

3. Check whether the parameters at both ends are consistent. Ensure that the key-id takes effect at the same time and has the same key and algorithm. For details about the configuration requirements, see the configuration manual. If the authentication failure persists, go to step 4. If the authentication succeeds, go to step 5.
4. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. The procedure ends.

�Cause 143872: The board temperature was extremely high.
1. Check if there are idle slots without filler panels on the device. If there are idle slots without filler panels, install filler panels to cover these slots.
2. Check if the filter screen of the fan module is clogged. If the filter screen is clogged, clean the filter screen.
3. Check the ambient temperature. If the ambient temperature is too high, reduce the temperature to a normal level.
4. Check if the fan module is faulty. If there is a fault on the fan module, rectify the fault first.

5. If the ambient temperature is normal but the alarm is still reported, the possible cause is that the module temperature is too high. In this case, collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

1. If an installed board has no services on it, check whether the board is properly installed, if pins have bent, and if the board connectors become faulty.
2. If the board is not securely installed, install it securely.
3. If the pins on the backplane have bent, do not install a new board into the improper slot, go to Step 6.
4. If only the board connectors are found to be faulty, replace the board.
5. If services on the board are normal, go to Step 6.
6. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support.
7. End.

column4: OSPFV3/1/ospfv3RouteLoopDetected_active: The local device has detected an OSPFv3 routing loop. (LoopType=[LoopType], DetectProtocolAttr=[DetectProtocolAttr], RedistributeID1=[RedistributeID1], RedistributeID2=[RedistributeID2])
column5: The device detects an OSPFv3 routing loop.

column1: [DetectProtocolAttr]Information about the loop detection protocol.
[RedistributeID1]Re-advertise device ID 1.
[RedistributeID2]Re-advertise device ID 2.
�Cause 1:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 and RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the two devices where a routing loop occurs. When the OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3 processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 2:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3-ISIS, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 correspond to the System ID of the ISIS processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs, RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs. When the ISIS/OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3/ISIS processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 3:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3-BGP, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

When the BGP/OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3/BGP processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs. RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs.
�Cause 1:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 and RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the two devices where a routing loop occurs. When the OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3 processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPFv3 automatically increases the cost of the imported route to attempt to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the policy for importing routes in the OSPFv3 processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospfv3 process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.
�Cause 2:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3-ISIS, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

RedistributeID1 correspond to the System ID of the ISIS processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs, RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs. When the ISIS/OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3/ISIS processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPFv3 automatically increases the cost of the imported route to attempt to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the route import policy configuration in the IS-IS and OSPFv3 processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospfv3 process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.

After eliminating the risk source that causes the loop, run the clear route loop-detect ospfv3 alarm-state command in the system view of the device that generates the alarm to clear the alarm and restore the cost of the imported route to the normal value.
�Cause 3:
If the loop detection type is OSPFv3-BGP, the possible causes of the alarm are as follows:

When the BGP/OSPFv3 processes on the two devices import routes from other OSPFv3/BGP processes, no import policy is configured or the import policy is incorrectly configured. As a result, a routing loop occurs. RedistributeID2 correspond to the router ID and process ID of the OSPFv3 processes on the devices where a routing loop occurs.

After detecting a loop on an imported route, OSPFv3 automatically increases the cost of the imported route to attempt to eliminate the loop. In this manner, the impact of the loop on services is automatically eliminated. The original risk source of the routing loop caused by the two re-advertisement devices still exists. In addition, the route cost adjusted by the system during automatic loop prevention may cause the traffic path to be different from the planned path. Therefore, after the system reports the alarm, modify the policy for importing routes in the BGP and OSPFv3 processes on the two re-advertisement devices as soon as possible to eliminate the risk source that causes routing loops. You can run the display ospfv3 process-id import-route loop-detect state command to view information about the routes that have encountered loops and are automatically removed. process-id specifies the process ID in the alarm parameter loop detection protocol information.

After eliminating the risk source that causes the loop, run the clear route loop-detect ospfv3 alarm-state command in the system view of the device that generates the alarm to clear the alarm and restore the cost of the imported route to the normal value.
