column4: DEVM/2/hwAuLopAlarm_active: The loss of pointer alarm in the multiplex section. (hwPhysicalPortIfIndex=[hwPhysicalPortIfIndex],BoardID=[hwPhysicalPortInSlot],CardID=[hwPhysicalPortInCard],PortID=[hwPhysicalPortInPort],InterfaceName=[hwPhysicalPortName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The optical interface of the local device received new data flags (NDF) or invalid AU pointer values in eight consecutive frames.

column1: [hwPhysicalPortInSlot]Slot ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInCard]Card ID.
[hwPhysicalPortInPort]Port ID.
[hwPhysicalPortName]Name of physical port.
�Cause 0: The optical fiber was broken.
�Cause 1: The optical loss was beyond the normal range.
�Cause 2: The remote device failed to send the optical signal.
�Cause 3: The cross-connect board of the remote device failed, was not installed, or was not installed properly.
�Cause 4: The clock board of the remote device failed.
1.Check whether any optical fiber is connected to the optical interface. If no optical fiber is used, shut down the laser of the optical interface and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
2.Check whether the optical fiber is broken. If the optical fiber is broken, replace the optical fiber and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

3.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is less than the minimum value. If the receive optical power is less than the minimum value, clean the optical fiber connector and the optical interface on the interface board. Check that the flange and the optical attenuator are properly connected and the optical attenuator value is in the normal range. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.

4.Check whether the receive optical power of the local device is high. If the receive optical power is greater than the maximum value, increase the attenuation value to adjust the receive optical power to the normal range and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
5.Check whether the laser on the corresponding interface board of the remote device is shut down. If the laser is shut down, switch on the laser and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
6.Check whether the transmit optical power is proper on the remote device. If the transmit optical power is proper, replace the corresponding interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
7.Check whether the clock board of the remote device fails. If the clock board fails, replace the clock board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
8.Check whether the interface board of the local device where the alarm was generated fails. If the interface board fails, replace the interface board and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to End.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 9.
9.Collect alarm information, log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: DEVM/4/hwUnstableAlarm_active: The physical entity was installed unstably. (EntityPhysicalIndex=[EntityPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalName=[EntPhysicalName],EntityTrapEntType=[EntityTrapEntType],EntityTrapFaultID=143361,Reason=The subcard was installed unstably.) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: A physical entity, such as a board, a power module, or a fan module, was installed improperly.

column1: [EntPhysicalName]The index for this entry.
[EntityTrapEntType]The textual name of the physical entity.
[EntityTrapFaultID]To describe the fault id of trap.
[Reason]Reason.
[EntPhysicalIndex]The index for this entry.
The subcard was installed unstably.

1.If the faulty subcard is just installed and no service is run, pull out the subcard and check whether any bent or broken pins exist on the connector of the subcard and the slot where the subcard resides.

2.If the slot where the subcard resides has bent or broken pins, do not install a new subcard into the faulty slot. Collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3.If only the connector of the subcard has bent or broken pins, replace the subcard.
4.Install the subcard securely, for example, tighten screws to fix the subcard.
5.If services on the subcard become normal but the alarm persists, collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
6.End.

1. Check whether channelState is Invalid.
�Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

2. Run the display remote-backup-service <service-name> [verbose] command to check the TCP-State field.
�If the TCP-State field displays Initial, Connecting, Listening, or --, the RBS is down.
�If the TCP-State field displays Connected, the RBS channel is up.
3. Compare the preceding status.
�If the status is consistent, no action is required.
�If the status is inconsistent, collect log and configuration information and contact technical support personnel.

EOAM-1AG
column4: EOAM-1AG/1/LOC_active: MEP is disconnected with the remote MEP. (MdIndex=[MdIndex], MaIndex=[MaIndex], MdName=[MdName], MaName=[MaName], MepId=[MepId], RmepId=[RmepId])
column5: The MEP does not receive any CCM frame from the peer MEP within the timeout period of the CCM frame.

column1: [MaIndex]MA Index
[MdName]MD Name
[MaName]MA Name
[MepId]MEP ID
[RmepId]RMEP ID
The MEP received no CCM in a period of time 3.5 times the interval at which CCMs were sent.
Perform the following operations to check the network operating status on the MEP:
�a.Run the display cfm mep [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> [ mep-id <mep-id> ] ] ] command to view the value of the Interface Name field. Obtain the interface type and number.
�b.Run the display interface <interface-type interface-num> command with the obtained interface type and number specified. View the value of the current state field.
�If the value of the current state field is Up, go to Step 2.
�If the value of the current state field is not Up, go to Step 6.
2.Run the display cfm mep [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> [ mep-id <mep-id> ] ] ] command to view the value of the CCM Send field on the RMEP. Check whether the RMEP is enabled to send CCMs.
�If the value of the CCM Send field is enabled, go to Step 4.
�If the value of the CCM Send field is disabled, go to Step 3.
3.Perform the following steps on the RMEP:
�a.Run the cfm md <md-name> command to enter the MD view.
�b.Run the ma <ma-name> command to enter the MA view.
�c.Run the mep ccm-send enable command to enable the RMEP to send CCMs. Check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 4.
4.Run the display cfm remote-mep [ md <md-name> ma <ma-name> mep-id <mep-id> ] command to view the value of the CCM Receive field on the MEP.
�If the value of the CCM Receive field is enabled, go to Step 8.
�If the value of the CCM Receive field is disabled, go to Step 5.
5.Perform the following steps on the MEP:
�a.Run the cfm md <md-name> command to enter the MD view.
�b.Run the ma <ma-name> command to enter the MA view.
�c.Run the remote-mep ccm-receive enable command to enable the MEP to receive CCMs. Check whether the trap is cleared. If the trap persists, go to Step 8.

6.Run the display this command in the interface view to check whether the local or remote interface is shut down. In the case of a sub-interface, you need to check whether a VLAN ID has been configured on the sub-interface and its peer sub-interface.

�If either interface is shut down, run the undo shutdown command to enable the interface. In the case of a sub-interface, run the vlan-type dot1q command on the sub-interface to configure a correct VLAN ID, and then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 7.
�If no interface is shut down, go to Step 7.
7.Check whether the physical link of the interface works improperly. That is, check whether the hardware such as the network cable or optical module is disconnected or loosely connected.
�If the physical link works improperly, you need to correctly connect the physical link and then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm is not cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the physical link works properly, go to Step 8.
8.Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

1. Run the display ip vpn-instance verbose <vpn-instance-name> command to check whether the tnl-policy field exists.

If a tunnel is configured with the mpls te reserved-for-binding command for VPN binding, the tunnel cannot be used by the tunnel type prioritizing policy.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If no, go to Step 3.
�If the tunnel policy is a tunnel binding policy, run the display interface tunnel command to check whether the tunnel interface bound to the tunnel policy is Up.
�If so, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 6.

3. Configure the required LSP tunnel or change the VPN tunnel policy according to the networking scenario, and then check whether the log L3VPNBASE/2/TNL_EVENT: The tunnel up event is occurred is generated.
�If so, go to Step 9.
�If not, go to Step 8.
4. Run the display this command in the tunnel interface view to check whether the mpls te reserved-for-binding command is configured on the tunnel interface.
�If so, go to Step 8.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Run the mpls te reserved-for-binding command in the tunnel interface view and check whether the log L3VPNBASE/2/TNL_EVENT: The tunnel up event is occurred is generated.
�If so, go to Step 9.
�If not, go to Step 8.

6. Check the configuration of the TE interface, confirm and rectify the fault according to the TE-related alarm, and then check whether the following log is generated: L3VPNBASE/2/TNL_EVENT: The tunnel up event is occurred.
�If so, go to Step 9.
�If not, go to Step 8.

7. Check the configuration of the LDP LSP, confirm and rectify the fault according to the LSP-related alarms, and then check whether the log L3VPNBASE/2/TNL_EVENT: The tunnel up event is occurred is generated.
�If so, go to Step 9.
�If not, go to Step 8.
8. Collect log and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
9. End.

column4: FEI/2/hwLinkHeartbeatDropAlarm_active: The link-heartbeat function detected that the packet loss rate reached or exceeded the threshold. (InterfaceIfIndex=[InterfaceIfIndex], InterfaceName=[InterfaceName], SendInterfaceName=[SendInterfaceName], RecvInterfaceName=[RecvInterfaceName])
column5: The link-heartbeat functin detected that the packet loss rate reached or exceeded the threshold.

column1: [InterfaceName]Name of the interface.
[SendInterfaceName]Name of the interface that sends packets.
[RecvInterfaceName]Name of the interface that receives packets.
Fault detection

Link heartbeat detection is used to detect service faults. Link heartbeats refer to ICMP detection packets. There are 12 packet templates in total. Each template sends two packets in sequence within a period of 30s. Therefore, a total of 24 packets are sent by the 12 templates within a period of 30s. After five periods, the system starts to collect statistics on lost packets and modified packets.
Link-heartbeat loopback detection is classified as packet modification detection or packet loss detection.

Packet loss detection checks whether the difference between the number of received heartbeat packets and the number of sent heartbeat packets is within the permitted range. If one of the following conditions is met, a trigger message is sent to instruct the SAID ping node to perform fault diagnosis:
1:The total number of lost packets exceeds 3.
2:After each packet sending period ends, the system checks the protocol status and whether ARP entries exist on the interface and find that there is no ARP in three consecutive periods.

3:The absolute value of the difference between the number of lost packets whose payload is all 0s and the number of lost packets whose payload is all Fs is greater than 25% of the total number of sent packets in five periods.
Fault diagnosis
After receiving the triggered message in the fault detection state, the ping service node enters the fault diagnosis state.

1:If a packet loss error is detected on the device, the SAID ping node checks whether a module (subcard, TM, or NP) on the device is faulty. If no module is faulty, the system completes the diagnosis and returns to the fault detection state.

2:If a packet loss error is detected on the device, the SAID ping node checks whether a module (subcard, TM, or NP) on the device is faulty. If a module fault occurs, the system performs loopback diagnosis. If packet loss or modification is detected during loopback, the local device is faulty. The system then enters the fault recovery state. If no packet is lost during loopback diagnosis, the system returns to the fault detection state.
Fault recovery
If a fault is detected during loopback diagnosis, the ping service node determines whether a counting error occurs on the associated subcard.

1:If a counting error occurs on the subcard, the ping service node resets the subcard for service recovery. Then, the node enters the service recovery determination state and performs link-heartbeat loopback detection to determine whether services recover. If services recover, the node returns to the fault detection state. If services do not recover, the node returns to the fault recovery state and takes a secondary recovery action. (For a subcard reset, the secondary recovery action is board reset.)

2:If no counting error occurs on the subcard, the ping service node resets the involved board for service recovery. After the board starts, the node enters the service recovery determination state and performs link-heartbeat loopback detection to determine whether services recover. If services recover, the node returns to the fault detection state. If services do not recover, the node remains in the service recovery determination state and periodically performs link-heartbeat loopback detection until services recover.
Service recovery determination

After fault recovery is complete, the ping service node uses the fault packet template to send diagnostic packets. If a fault still exists and a subcard reset is performed, the node generates an alarm and instructs the subcard to perform a switching for self-healing. If a fault still exists but no subcard reset is performed, the node generates an alarm only. If no fault exists, the node instructs the link-heartbeat loopback function to return to the initiate state, and the node itself returns to the fault detection state.
Fault alarm

If link-heartbeat loopback detects packet loss, it triggers SAID ping diagnosis and performs recovery operations (reset the subcard or board). However, services fail to be recovered, and the device detects packet loss and reports an alarm.

1. Run the display link-heartbeat command to check link-heartbeat packet loss information on the corresponding interface. Check whether packet loss is detected within five consecutive detection periods (150s).
�If no packet loss is detected within five consecutive detection periods (150s), the alarm is cleared. Go to step 3.
�If packet loss is detected within five consecutive detection periods (150s), the alarm persists. Go to step 2.
2. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

[InterfaceName3]Name of interface 3 involved in the duplication suppression period. If no interface exists, a hyphen (-) is displayed.

A loop occurred on the EVPN, or devices or hosts with duplicate MAC addresses existed on the EVPN.

1. Run the display evpn vpn-instance name <vpn-instance-name> mac-duplication [ bridge-domain <bd-id> ] [ mac-address <mac-address> ] command to query information about MAC duplication suppression and suppressed MAC routes. Check the network based on the command output. Remove the link that causes the loop or set a new MAC address for the device with the same MAC address to ensure that no loop occurs or no device or host with the same MAC address exists on the network.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.

�If the alarm is cleared and you want to restore the suppressed MAC routes immediately instead of waiting for the suppression recovery timer to expire, run the reset evpn vpn-instance <vpn-instance-name> mac-duplication [ bridge-domain <bd-id> ] [ mac-address <mac-address> ] command to clear the suppression state of the MAC routes.

column4: ARP/2/hwARPHostConflict_active: The host access interface frequently changed. (LocalIPAddress=[LocalIP], LocalBDID=[LocalBDId], LocalMAC=[LocalMAC], RemoteIPAddress=[ConflictIP], RemoteBDID=[RemoteBDId], RemoteMAC=[RemoteMAC], LocalInterface=[LocalInterface], RemoteInterface=[RemoteInterface], TunnelPeer=[TunnelPeer])
column5: The host access interface frequently changed.

column1: [LocalBDId]Local BD ID
[LocalMAC]Local MAC address
[ConflictIP]Remote IP address
[RemoteBDId]Remote BD ID
[RemoteMAC]Remote MAC address
[LocalInterface]Local interface
[RemoteInterface]Remote interface
[TunnelPeer]Peer IP address of the tunnel

In a BD gateway scenario, a user frequently migrates between local and remote devices or between different local EVC sub-interfaces. (The alarm reporting condition is controlled by the arp host ip-conflict-check command. By default, an alarm is reported when the number of migrations within 180s reaches 5.)
1. Based on the alarm information, determine the IP address, BD, and access interface of the alarm user.
�If the alarm user's information can be determined, go to Step 2.
�If the alarm user's information cannot be determined, go to Step 5.

2. Based on the network plan, service deployment, and alarm user information, check the user access information on the BD gateway and the user configuration on the device connected to the user access interface.
�If multiple devices connected to the BD gateway are configured with the same alarm user IP address, go to Step 3.

�Run the debugging arp packet command in the user view to obtain ARP packets of the alarm user, and run the display arp history command in the diagnostic view to check the user change information. If the user frequently goes online between distributed gateways or between different EVC sub-interfaces on the same device, go to Step 4.
�If the same alarm user IP address is not configured on the devices connected to the distributed gateway and packets of the alarm user for frequent access cannot be obtained, go to Step 5.
3. Change the conflicting IP address and check whether the alarm persists.
�If yes, go to Step 2.
�If no, go to Step 6.
4. Based on the user operation logs, check whether the frequent migrations of the alarm user are proper.
�If the frequent migrations of the alarm user can be determined to be proper, go to Step 6.
�If the frequent migrations of the alarm user cannot be determined to be proper, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

The system IDs of two remote IS systems conflicted on an IS-IS network.

�Locate the devices with the conflicting system ID based on the TheOtherDynamicName field and change the system ID of one device to ensure that the system IDs of the devices in the topology are different.

�Run the undo isis system-id auto-recover disable command on the device where a system ID conflict occurs to enable the device to automatically change its local system ID if a system ID conflict occurs on the network.

A configuration error occurred.
The leaf attribute was set for one AC interface, whereas the root attribute was set for the other AC interface.
1. Check whether the evpn e-tree-leaf command is run on both AC interfaces of the dual-homing PEs.
�If the command is run on both AC interfaces, go to 2.

�If the command is not run on both AC interfaces, run the evpn e-tree-leaf or undo evpn e-tree-leaf command to ensure that the AC interfaces on the dual-homing PEs have the same root or leaf attribute.
2. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3. End.

column5: The system configuration is incorrect.

column1: �Cause 144128: The version in the PAF file is inconsistent with that of the startup software package.
�Cause 144129: The boards and subcards were installed in incorrect slots.
�Cause 144130: The software versions on the master and slave control boards are inconsistent.
�Cause 144133: The memory size of the system master main control board was inconsistent with that of the system slave main control board.
�Cause 144134: The PTN start mode is inconsistent with that defined in the activated license.
�Cause 144135: The cfcard size of the system master main control board was inconsistent with that of the system slave main control board. One is larger than 4G and the other is smaller than 4G.
�Cause 144128: The version in the PAF file is inconsistent with that of the startup software package.
The PAF version was inconsistent with the version of the startup software package.

1. Manually change the PAF version to be the same as the version of the startup software package. Run the startup paf command to set the PAF as the next startup PAF. Then run the reboot command to restart the device.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 3.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 144129: The boards and subcards were installed in incorrect slots.
The boards and subcards are not installed in the corresponding slots.
�In 1:1 mode, insert NPUs.
�Cause 144130: The software versions on the master and slave control boards are inconsistent.
The versions of the active and standby main control boards are inconsistent.
1. Run the startup system-software command to change the version of the standby board to be the same as that of the master board. Then, run the reset slot command to reset the standby board.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 3.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
�Cause 144133: The memory size of the system master main control board was inconsistent with that of the system slave main control board.
The memory of the active main control board is inconsistent with that of the standby main control board.
�Contact the technical support personnel to replace the memory module and ensure that the memory of the master main control board is the same as that of the slave main control board.
�Cause 144134: The PTN start mode is inconsistent with that defined in the activated license.
Collect information and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 144135: The cfcard size of the system master main control board was inconsistent with that of the system slave main control board. One is larger than 4G and the other is smaller than 4G.
Contact technical support engineers to replace the CF card and ensure that the CF card sizes of the active and standby main control boards meet the requirements.

column4: MSTP/5/LOST_ROOT_PRIMARY: This bridge is no longer the root bridge of the MSTP. (InstanceID=[InstanceID])
column5: The device was no longer the root bridge.

column1: Cause 1: The local bridge receives BPDUs with a higher priority.
Cause 2: The priority of another bridge is changed and is higher than that of the root bridge.
�Cause 1: This bridge receives BPDU packets of higher priority.
1. Check whether the newly added physical link is the required one.
�If the physical link is required, go to Step 2.
�If the physical link is not required, go to Step 3.
2. Run the display stp command to check whether each port complies with the protocol calculation result.
�If the calculation result complies with the protocol, no action is required.
�If the calculation result does not comply with the protocol, go to Step 4.
3. Correctly deploy the network topology and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: The bridge priorities of other bridge is modified to be higher than the root bridge priority.
1. Run the display stp command to check whether the priority change operation in the network topology is normal.
�If this is a normal operation, no action is required.
�If the operation is abnormal, go to Step 2.

2. Run the stp [ instance <instance-id> ] priority <priority> command in the system view to reconfigure the priority of the local bridge as required. Alternatively, run the undo stp [ instance <instance-id> ] priority or undo stp [ instance <instance-id> ] root command to restore the default bridge priority. Check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 3.
3. Collect alarm and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.

3. Run the display logbuffer slot | include BGPFLOW command to check whether the conflict persists.

�Cause 131328: The dustproof of the cabinet not cleaned.
1. Clean the air filter on the chassis or cabinet.
2. In the NE Explorer, choose Entity Management > Chassis from Function Tree. Select the target chassis, right-click, and choose Reset Air filter from the shortcut menu to clear the air filter alarm.

If Entity Management > Chassis is not displayed in Function Tree of the NE Explorer, choose System Management > Device Management Configuration > Entity Management > Devm > Chassis > chassis. Then select the target chassis, right-click, and choose reset-dustproof-net from the shortcut menu to clear the air filter alarm.
3. If the air filter alarm persists, collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support.
4. End
�Cause 131330: MPU in the chassis is not full.
1. Install an additional main board in the chassis. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 3.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect trap, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support.
3. End.

5. If services on the board are normal, go to Step 6.

Cause 1: When the SSL connection is not TLS1.3, the processed data volume reaches 1 GB.
Cause 2: The SSL connection is not TLS1.3, and the connection duration exceeds 1 hour.
Cause 3: When the SSL connection is not TLS1.3, the interval between the last renegotiation and the last renegotiation exceeds 1 hour.
SSL-initiated renegotiation fails.
Cause 1: The SSL connection is disconnected.
Cause 2: The peer end does not support renegotiation.

column4: LDT/4/ALD_LOG_TRIGGERDOWN: The interface turned to trigger-down state, because of the loop detected on this interface. (Interface = [IfName], DomainType = [DomainType], DomainName = [DomainName],Trigger Source = [TrggerSourceifName]).
column5: A loop was detected during proactive loop detection, which was triggered when an interface went Up or was bound to a VSI. The interface was blocked in trigger-down mode and a log was recorded.

column1: [DomainType]Indicates the type of the Layer 2 forwarding domain.
[DomainName]Indicates the name of the Layer 2 forwarding type.
[TrggerSourceifName]Indicates the interface that forms a loop.
A loop was detected during proactive loop detection, which was triggered when an interface went Up or was bound to a VSI. The interface was blocked in trigger-down mode and a log was recorded.
1. Run the display loop-detect trigger trigger-down all command to check whether there is an interface in the trigger-down state. If so, go to Step 2. If not, go to Step 4.
2. Check whether a loop occurs on the interface. If a loop exists, go to Step 3. If no loop exists, go to Step 4.

3. After the loop is eliminated, run the reset loop-detect trigger trigger-down command or run the shutdown and undo shutdown commands on the blocked physical interface to unblock the interface. If the loop alarm is cleared, no further action is required. If the loop alarm is not cleared, go to Step 4.

�If proactive loop detection is triggered when an interface is bound to a VSI, the interface is unblocked when the interface is removed from the VSI. If the loop alarm is cleared, no further action is required. If the loop alarm is not cleared, go to Step 4.

�If proactive loop detection is triggered when an interface physically goes Down, the interface is unblocked and loop detection is performed again when the interface is removed from the VSI. If the loop alarm is cleared, no further action is required. If the loop alarm is not cleared, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact Huawei technical support personnel.

column4: PTP/4/hwPTPRingFiberLengthChange_active: The optical fiber length of the ring-network is changed. (hwPtpPortName=[hwPtpPortName], hwPtpPortIfIndex=[hwPtpPortIfIndex], hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue=[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue], hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag=[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The length of the fiber on the ring network changed.

column1: [hwPtpPortIfIndex]Index of the current port.
[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValue]New time offset caused by the fiber length change of the current port (the configured fiber asymmetry compensation value is added). Unit: ns
[hwPtpPortRingFiberLengthChangeValueFlag]Plus or minus sign of the new time offset caused by the fiber change of the current port. The values are as follows: Negative sign (0). Positive sign (1).
The difference between the time offset caused by the fiber length change and the set asymmetric correction value exceeded the acceptable range (from - 200 ns to + 200 ns).
1. Run the display alarm active command to check whether the alarm parameter value is 1048575 (0xFFFFF).
�If yes, the fiber measurement on the ring network fails. In this case, go to Step 2.
�If no, the fiber measurement on the ring network is successful and the threshold is exceeded. In this case, go to Step 4.

2. Run the display ptp all command to check whether the time synchronization status of the current device is locked and whether the clock class of the GM traced by the current device is smaller than 187.
�If yes, go to Step 5.
�If no, go to Step 3.

3. Check and modify the PTP configuration to ensure that the time is locked and the clock class of the traced GM is smaller than 187. Run the shutdown and undo shutdown commands to trigger fiber measurement on the ring network again and observe the alarm status.
�If the alarm is cleared, the measurement is successful and the threshold is not exceeded. In this case, go to Step 6.
�If the alarm persists and the alarm parameter is not 1048575, the measurement is successful and the threshold is exceeded. In this case, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm persists and the alarm parameter is still 1048575, go to Step 5.

4. Run the ptp asymmetry-correction { positive correction-value | negative correction-value } command in the interface view to configure a new asymmetry correction value. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If yes, the restore is successful and go to Step 6.
�If no, go to Step 5.
5. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
6. End.

�Cause 1: Other
�Cause 2: A static LSP went down.
�Cause 3: A static CR-LSP went down.
�Cause 4: The outbound interface of an RSVP-TE LSP's ingress went down.
�Cause 5: RSVP-TE LSP resources were preempted.
�Cause 6: Transmission of an RSVP message timed out.
�Cause 7: RSVP Hello mechanism detected a downstream node failure.
�Cause 8: The bypass tunnel in use was Down or unbound from the primary tunnel.
�Cause 9: CSPF failed to calculate a path.
�Cause 10: The tunnel was manually shut down.
�Cause 1: Other
Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
�Cause 2: A static LSP went down.
1. Check whether the configurations for the current tunnel interface, RSVP, an IGP, link connectivity, and bandwidth for links along the tunnel are correct.
�If a configuration is incorrect, correct the configuration and commit the new configuration. Then check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 5. If not go to Step 4.
�If all configurations are correct and the alarm persists, go to Step 2.
2. Run the display mpls te tunnel-interface last-error command to check error information. And deal with the problem according to the error information. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 5.
�If not, go to Step 3.
3.Run the display mpls lsp statistics command to check whether the number of LSPs exceeds the upper limit.
�If the number of LSPs exceeds the upper limit, delete unwanted LSPs and check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 5. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
�If not, go to Step 4.
4.Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
5.End.
�Cause 3: A static CR-LSP went down.
The same as Cause 2.
�Cause 4: The outbound interface of an RSVP-TE LSP's ingress went down.
1. Check the configuration and status of the current tunnel interface. If the outbound interface is incorrectly configured, reconfigure it correctly. Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3.End.
�Cause 5: RSVP-TE LSP resources were preempted.
1. Change the setup and holding priorities on the tunnel interface.Then check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If so, go to Step 3.
�If not, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
3.End.
�Cause 6: Transmission of an RSVP message timed out.
Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

column4: LDP/1/mplsLdpSessionDown_active: The LDP session status is Down. (PeerLsrId=[PeerLsrId], VrfName=[VrfName], SessionType=[SessionType], IfName=[IfName], SubReason=[SubReason], Reason=[Reason])
column5: An LDP session went to Down or remained in the Down state.

column1: [VrfName]VRF for an LDP session.
[SessionType]LDP session type: - Local - Remote - Local and remote
[IfName]Name of the physical interface.

[SubReason]Detailed reason for the LDP session down event. If an LDP session goes down because an error packet is received, the detailed error type is displayed. If an LDP session goes down because a Notify message is received, the detailed Notify type is displayed. Examples of typical error causes: A packet with an incorrect LDP ID was received (1). A packet with an incorrect version number was received (2). A packet with an incorrect PDU length was received (3). A packet with an incorrect message length was received (5). A packet with an incorrect TLV was received (7). A hello timeout notification message was received (9). A shutdown notification message was received (10). A keepalive timeout notification message was received (20). IGP deleted RLFA IID (1056968430). If an LDP session goes down because a socket error is received, the detailed error cause or error code is displayed. The following are examples of typical error causes: TCP connection reset (54) TCP connection timeout (60) If an LDP session goes down because LDP packets fail to be sent or received, the detailed cause is displayed. The following are examples of typical causes: A large number of LDP packets are not processed. Failed to receive the packet. Failed to send the packet. If an LDP session goes down because LDP fails to set the socket option or LDP receives a socket close message, a detailed error code is displayed. If the LDP session goes down due to other causes, the value of this field is 0.
[Reason]Alarm cause.

column4: TUNNEL-TE/4/hwMplsApsMismatch: The protection group detected an APS configuration inconsistency betweeen two ends of the APS tunnel. (WorkTunnelIfIndex=[WorkTunnelIfIndex], WorkTunnel=[WorkTunnel], MismatchReason=[MismatchReason])

column1: [WorkTunnel]Name of a working tunnel in a protection group
[MismatchReason]Inconsistency reason type

Cause 1: APS is configured on one end but not on the other end of a tunnel, an alarm about channel inconsistency is sent to the NMS. Cause 2: If the 1+1 APS tunnel protection group is configured on one end and the 1:1 APS tunnel protection group is configured on the other end, an alarm about bridge inconsistency is sent to the NMS. Cause 3: If bidirectional APS is enabled on one end and unidirectional APS is enabled on the other end, an alarm about switching inconsistency is sent to the NMS. Cause 4: If retrieve APS is enabled on one end and non-retrieve APS is enabled on the other end, an alarm about operation inconsistency is sent to the NMS.
1. Check whether an alarm about channel inconsistency is displayed.
�If such an alarm is displayed, go to Step 2.
�If the alarm is not about channel inconsistency, go to Step 3.
2. Run the mpls te aps-version G8131 command to enable APS. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
3. Check whether an alarm about switching inconsistency is displayed.
�If such an alarm is displayed, go to Step 4.
�If the alarm is not about switching inconsistency, go to Step 5.
4. Configure a bidirectional tunnel. For the configuration procedure. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
5. Check whether an alarm about operation inconsistency is displayed.
�If such an alarm is displayed, go to Step 6.
�If the alarm is not about operation inconsistency, go to Step 7.
6. Modify the switchback mode and ensure that the switchback modes on both ends of the tunnel are the same. Check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is cleared, go to Step 8.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 7.
7. Collect the alarm information, log information, and configuration information, and then Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel..
8. End.
NTP
column4: NTP/2/NTP_SYNCHRONIZE_STATUS: NTP state changed from synchronized to unsynchronized. (SynchronizationSourceAddress = [Source] , VpnInstance = [VpnName], Reason = [Reason])
column5: NTP synchronization status.
column6: [Source]IP address of the server for local NTP clock synchronization.

column1: [VpnName]VPN instance and remote end for local NTP clock synchronization.
[Reason]Reason why the NTP clock status changes to unsynchronized.
The possible causes of the NTP status change from synchronized to unsynchronized are as follows:
Cause 1: VPN change detected
Cause 2: Peer reachability lost
Cause 3: Authentication failure
Cause 4: Authentication configuration changed
Cause 5: KOD DENY received
Cause 6: Manycast discovery restarted
Cause 7: Unicast server configuration removed
Cause 8: Unicast peer configuration removed
Cause 9: Reference clock configuration removed
Cause 10: Stratum increase detected
Cause 11: Peer clock unsynchronized/unselectable
Cause 12: Manycast configuration removed
Cause 13: Configuration changed
Cause 14: Clock selection failed - Excessive falsetickers
Cause 15: Clock selection failed - No selectable clock
Cause 16: Clock change detected
Cause 17: NTP IPv4 Service is disabled
Cause 18: NTP IPv6 Service is disabled
Cause 19: Peer is restricted to select
Cause 20: Staled manycast session
Cause 21: Peer is preempted
Cause 22: Invalid stratum/Server not synchronized
Cause 23: NTP test failures
Cause 24: Synchronization loop is detected
Cause 25: System peer stratum is better
Cause 26: Synchronization distance greater than distance threshold
Cause 1: VPN change detected
Select another VPN.
Cause 2: Peer reachability lost
1. Check whether the link to the remote clock source is reachable.
2. If the link is unreachable, rectify the network fault or configure a new remote clock source.
3. If the link is reachable, check whether the source interface is correctly configured.
Cause 3: Authentication failure
Authentication failure packets are discarded and cannot be synchronized.
1. Check whether the key is configured. If no, configure the key. If yes, check whether the key is correct.
2. Check whether the key is set to reliable.
3. Check whether the clock source configuration carries a key.
Cause 4: Authentication configuration changed
If the authentication configuration is changed, rectify the fault according to Cause 3.
Cause 5: KOD DENY received
The client receives a KOD packet with the DENY code, and the remote clock source restricts the synchronization time of the client. Reconfigure a new remote clock source.
Cause 6: Manycast discovery restarted
The manycast client restarts the discovery process. No action is required.
Cause 7: Unicast server configuration removed
The unicast server configuration has been deleted. Reconfigure the NTP unicast server.
Cause 8: Unicast peer configuration removed
The unicast peer configuration is deleted. Reconfigure the NTP unicast peer.
Cause 9: Reference clock configuration removed
The configuration of the master clock is deleted. Reconfigure the NTP local clock as the NTP master clock.
Cause 10: Stratum increase detected
1. The stratum of the remote clock source increases. Check whether the current clock is in the synchronization state.

2. If the clock source is in the synchronous state, check whether the precision meets the requirement. If the precision does not meet the requirement, reconfigure a remote clock source with higher precision.
3. If the remote clock source is not synchronized, reconfigure a new remote clock source.
Cause 11: Peer clock unsynchronized/unselectable
1. The stratum of the remote clock source increases. Check whether the current clock is in the synchronization state.

2. If the clock source is in the synchronous state, check whether the precision meets the requirement. If the precision does not meet the requirement, reconfigure a remote clock source with higher precision.
3. If the remote clock source is not synchronized, reconfigure a new remote clock source.
Cause 12: Manycast configuration removed
The manycast client configuration is deleted. Reconfigure the NTP manycast client.
Cause 13: Configuration changed
Check whether the client configuration is deleted. If yes, add the NTP client configuration again.
Cause 14: Clock selection failed - Excessive falsetickers
Clock selection fails due to excessive fake clocks. Delete invalid clock sources and reconfigure valid clock sources.
Cause 15: Clock selection failed - No selectable clock
Clock selection fails because no clock source is available. Configure a valid clock source.
Cause 16: Clock change detected
The time of the clock source changes abruptly. Check the time of the clock source or reconfigure a new remote clock source.
Cause 17: NTP IPv4 Service is disabled
The NTP IPv4 service is disabled. Enable the NTP IPv4 service again.
Cause 18: NTP IPv6 Service is disabled
The NTP IPv6 service is disabled. Enable the NTP IPv6 service again.
Cause 19: Peer is restricted to select
The peer cannot be selected. Reconfigure the NTP peer.
Cause 20: Staled manycast session
The dynamic multicast session is outdated, and no action is required.
Cause 21: Peer is preempted
The peer is preempted, and no action is required.
Cause 22: Invalid stratum/Server not synchronized
1. The stratum of the remote clock source is invalid or not synchronized. Check whether the current clock is in the synchronized state.

2. If the clock source is in the synchronous state, check whether the precision meets the requirement. If the precision does not meet the requirement, reconfigure a remote clock source with higher precision.
3. If the remote clock source is not synchronized, reconfigure a new remote clock source.
Cause 23: NTP test failures
Failed to verify the NTP standard. Configure a new remote clock source.
Cause 24: Synchronization loop is detected
An NTP synchronization loop is detected. Check the NTP configuration on the network.
Cause 25: System peer stratum is better
The system has a better number of peer layers, and no action is required.
Cause 26: Synchronization distance greater than distance threshold
If the synchronization distance is greater than the distance threshold, adjust the synchronization distance threshold or reconfigure a better clock source.

column1: [ProbableCause]Trap cause.
[EventType]Alarm type
[PhysicalIndex]Physical index
[PhysicalName]Entity name
[RelativeResource]Relevant resource name

[UsageType]Overload type. The value 1 indicates the CPU. The default sampling interval is 10 seconds, and the number of overload sampling times is 48. The value 2 indicates the memory. The default sampling interval is 1 second, and the number of overload sampling times is 2. The value 3 indicates a disk. The value 4 indicates flash memory. The value 5 indicates the CF card. The value 6 indicates the physical memory.
[SubIndex]Entity sub-index
[UsageValue]Storage usage
[Unit]Unit
[UsageThreshold]Threshold
The memory usage of one process exceeded the pre-set overload threshold. The max memory size is 3G for one process.
1. Run the display memory slot <slotid> command to check the process that uses the most memory.
2. Delete unnecessary services and configurations. Wait for 1 minute and check whether the alarm is cleared.
�If the alarm is no longer generated, go to Step 4.

[RcvCVid]Inner VLAN ID of the received packet

The local device has an ARP entry and receives a non-gratuitous ARP packet from the remote device. The source IP address of the packet is the same as an IP address in the local ARP entry, but the source MAC address is different from the MAC address in the local ARP entry. The interface receives a Probe ARP packet, and the destination IP address of the packet conflicts with the local interface address.
1. Check whether an IP address conflict occurs on the network.

1. Run the display cfm mep [ md <md-name> [ ma <ma-name> [ mep-id <mep-id> ] ] ] command on both the MEP and RMEP to view the value of the Level field. Check whether the MD levels are the same.

2. Perform the following steps on the MEP:
�a. Run the undo cfm md name <md-name> command to delete existing MD configurations.
�b. Run the cfm md <md-name> level <level> command to reconfigure an MD the same as that on the RMEP.

BGP
column4: BGP/4/BGPFLOWSPEC_V6: The ipv6 route [REIndex] includes conflict rules (ReasonID is [ReasonID]).
column5: The rules contained in the IPv6 route with the index of REIndex conflict.

column1: [ReasonID]Conflict cause.
The mapping causes of reason IDs are as follows:
�ReasonID = 1. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with the interface type and either of the source or sink interface type.
�ReasonID = 2. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type.
�ReasonID = 3. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a protocol type and any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type. The protocol type is not TCP or UDP.
�ReasonID = 4. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a protocol type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type. The protocol type is not ICMP.
�ReasonID = 5. Currently, types of rules configured for the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route were not supported.
�ReasonID = 6. Values of parameters in rules configured for the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route exceeded the allowed range.
�ReasonID = 7. The value range was not specified for the same type of rules configured for the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route.
�ReasonID = 8. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a protocol type and the TCPFLAG type. The protocol type is not TCP.
�ReasonID = 9. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and the TCPFLAG type. No protocol type is configured.
�ReasonID = 10. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with the TCPFLAG type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type.
�ReasonID = 11. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with the TCPFLAG type and the fragmented packet type.

�ReasonID = 12. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with any of the interface type, source interface type, and sink interface type and either of the ICMPTYPE or ICMPCODE type. The fragmented packet type is configured.
�ReasonID = 13. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a protocol type and the fragmented packet type. The protocol type value is not 44.
�ReasonID = 14. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a protocol type and the non-fragmented packet type. The protocol type value is 44.
�ReasonID = 15. The BGPFlowSpec IPv6 route was bound to an interface group and configured with DSCP rules.
�ReasonID = 16. The BGPFlowSpec IPv6 route was bound to an interface group and configured with packet length rules.
�ReasonID = 20. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a packet length type, which was not supported by the current board.
�ReasonID = 21. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a packet length type, which was not supported in non-Admin-VS or VPN scenarios.
�ReasonID = 22. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was bound to an interface group, which was not supported by the current board.
�ReasonID = 23. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 VPN route cannot be bound to an interface group.
�ReasonID = 24. The BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route was configured with a DSCP type, which was not supported by the current board.

�ReasonID = 25. The DSCP and TCPFLAG rules configured for the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route conflict with each other. When DSCP is enabled, the TCPFLAG rule is not delivered. When DSCP is disabled, the DSCP rule is not delivered.
�ReasonID = 26: The number of rules configured for a single BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route exceeds the upper limit supported by the hardware.
1. Check whether a conflict occurs in the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 route based on the index and reason ID in the log information.
2. Modify or delete the conflicting rule in the BGP FlowSpec IPv6 routing information, and then reconfigure the route to be sent.
3. Run the display logbuffer slot | include BGPFLOW command to check whether the conflict persists.
�If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
�If no, go to Step 5.
4. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
5. End.

column4: MSTP/4/PROPORT_BPDU_GUARDED: The MSTP process's edge port with BPDU protection enabled will be shut down, because it received a BPDU packet. (ProcessID=[ProcessID], InstanceID=[InstanceID], PortID1=[PortID1], PortID2=[PortID2], PortID3=[PortID3], PortID4=[PortID4], PortIDFlag=[PortIDFlag], PortState=[PortState], IfIndex=[IfIndex], PortName=[PortName])
column5: Specify that the edge port receives the BPDU packets when BPDU protection was enabled

column1: [InstanceID]Indicates the instance ID.
[PortID1]Indicates ID 1 of the port in the MSTP process.
[PortID2]Indicates ID 2 of the port in the MSTP process.
[PortID3]Indicates ID 3 of the port in the MSTP process.
[PortID4]Indicates ID 4 of the port in the MSTP process.
[PortIDFlag]Indicates the port flag.
[PortState]Indicates the port state.
[IfIndex]Indicates the interface index.
[PortName]Indicates the port name.
The edge port received BPDUs, and BPDU protection was enabled globally.
1. Check whether the interface is directly connected to a user terminal and can be specified as an edge port.
�If the interface is directly connected to a user terminal and therefore can be specified as an edge port, go to Step 2.
�If the interface is indirectly connected to a user terminal and therefore cannot be specified as an edge port, go to Step 3.
2. Locate the source of the BPDUs on the interface and check whether the malicious attack exists.
�If the malicious attack exists, go to Step 4.
�If the malicious attack does not exist, go to Step 3.

3. Run the undo stp root-protection and undo shutdown commands in the interface view to delete the configuration of the edge port and restart the interface. Then, check whether the alarm is cleared. If the alarm persists, go to Step 4.
4. Collect alarm information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.

AM
column4: AM/4/IPCONFLICT: IP address is conflict. (Conflict ip=[ConfIP],PoolNo.=[PoolNo],PoolName=[PoolName])
column5: IP addresses conflicted.

column1: [PoolNo]Address pool index
[PoolName]Address pool name

Cause 1: When the DHCP server was assigning an IP address to a DHCP client, the dhcp server ping command output showed that the IP address had been used. Cause 2: After discovering that the assigned IP address had been used already, a DHCP client sent a Decline message to the DHCP server.
1. Run the display ip pool command to check whether the address pool has available IP addresses.
�If yes, no action is required.
�If no, go to Step 2.
2. Check whether the conflicting IP address should be used as planned.
�If yes, no action is required. The DHCP server can continue assigning IP addresses only after all IP addresses are released from the address pool.
�If no, go to Step 3.

3. Run the conflict auto-recycle command to configure the interval for automatically reclaiming conflicting IP addresses. After conflicting IP addresses are reclaimed, these IP addresses become available and can be assigned to clients.

column4: NVO3/4/NVO3_TUNNEL6_DOWN: The status of the IPv6 VXLAN tunnel changed to down. (SourceIpv6Addr=[SrcIpv6Addr], DestinationIpv6Addr=[DstIpv6Addr], TunnelStatus=[Tnl6Status])
column5: The IPv6 VXLAN tunnel went Down.
column6: [SrcIpv6Addr]Source VTEP IPv6 address of the IPv6 VXLAN tunnel

column1: [DstIpv6Addr]Destination VTEP IPv6 address of the IPv6 VXLAN tunnel
[Tnl6Status]1: The tunnel is Down. 2: The tunnel is Up.
Routes at both ends of the IPv6 VXLAN tunnel were unreachable.
1. Run the display ipv6 routing-table command to check whether the routes destined for the source and destination VTEP IPv6 addresses are reachable.
�If they are reachable, go to Step 3.
�If they are unreachable, go to Step 2.

2. Configure static routes or dynamic routes that are reachable to the source and destination VTEP IPv6 addresses. Then run the display vxlan tunnel command to check whether the IPv6 VXLAN tunnel goes Up.
�If the tunnel goes Up, go to Step 4.
�If the tunnel remains Down, go to Step 3.
3. Collect log information and configuration information, and then contact technical support personnel.
4. End.
SOC
column4: SOC/4/hwL3LoopDetectAlarmVPN_active: L3 loop detect alarmed. (ChassisID=[hwL3LoopDetectChassisID], Slot=[hwL3LoopDetectSlotID], IP=[hwL3LoopDetectIPAddr], VPN=[hwL3LoopDetectVPNName]) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: Layer 3 loop detection detected route loops.

column1: [hwL3LoopDetectSlotID]Board ID.
[hwL3LoopDetectIPAddr]IP address.
[hwL3LoopDetectVPNName]VPN name.

When a routing loop occurs, a large number of TTL timeout packets are generated on the network. If the number of TTL timeout packets sent to the CPU is greater than or equal to 6000 within 1 minute, a 1-minute timer is started for sampling and analysis. If the number of packets reaches 1024 or the number of packets exceeds 100 when the timer expires, the destination IP addresses and VPN name of top 5 packets are tracerted one by one. If a routing loop exists, an alarm is generated.
1. Tracert the destination address and VPN of the route displayed in the alarm to check whether a loop occurs on the link.
�If a loop exists, remove the loop. If the alarm is cleared after the loop is removed, go to Step 3. If the alarm persists after the loop is removed, go to Step 2.
�If no loop exists, go to Step 2.
2. Collect alarm, log, and configuration information, and contact technical support personnel.
3. End.
PIC
column4: PIC/1/hwCardInvalid_active: The card failed completely. (EntityPhysicalIndex=[EntityPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalIndex=[EntPhysicalIndex],EntPhysicalName=[EntPhysicalName],EntityType=[EntityType],EntityTrapFaultID=135430,ReasonDescription=The heartbeat of the subcard was faulty.) In VS mode, this log is supported only by the admin VS.
column5: The card failed completely.
column6: [EntityPhysicalIndex]Indicates the index of the physical entity.

column1: [EntityType]Indicates the type of the physical entity.
[ReasonDescription]Indicates the description of the cause of the trap.
The heartbeat of the subcard was faulty.
1. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides does not support FPIC, go to Step 5.
2. If the motherboard on which the subcard resides resets, no action is required.
3. Power off the subcard and then power it on again.
4. If the subcard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the subcard is registered, replace the subcard.
5. If the motherboard supports only one subcard, power off the motherboard and then power it on again.
6. If the motherboard does not support FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the motherboard.

7. If the motherboard supports FPIC, and the motherboard cannot be registered or the alarm persists after the motherboard is registered, replace the subcard. If the fault persists, replace the motherboard.
8. Collect the information about alarms, logs, and configurations, and then contact technical support personnel.
9. End.

Configuration Precautions for STP
(Optional) Configuring DHCPv6 Relay Dual-Device Hot Standby in a VRRP
1.Configure basic VRRP6 group functions.
1.Run system-view
The system view is displayed.
2.Run interfaceinterface-typeinterface-number [ .subinterface-number ]
The view of the interface where a VRRP6 group needs to be configured is displayed.
3.Run ipv6 enable
IPv6 is enabled for the interface.
4.Run ipv6 address { ipv6-address prefix-length | ipv6-address-mask }
An IPv6 address is configured for the interface.
5.Run vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-idvirtual-ipvirtual-addresslink-local
A VRRP6 group is created and assigned the first virtual IPv6 address.
When a VRRP6 group is created on an interface, the first virtual IPv6 address assigned to the VRRP6 group must be a link-local address.

When the first virtual IPv6 address is assigned to a VRRP6 group, the system creates the VRRP6 group. If another virtual IPv6 address is assigned to the VRRP6 group, the system adds the address to the virtual IPv6 address list.
6.Run vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-idvirtual-ipvirtual-address
A virtual IPv6 address is configured for the VRRP6 group.

Multiple virtual IPv6 addresses can be assigned to a VRRP6 group. A single virtual IPv6 address serves a separate user group, in which users have the same reliability requirements. This setting helps prevent the default gateway addresses from varying according to changes in VRRP6 device locations.
7.Run vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-idpreempt-modetimerdelaydelay-time
A preemption delay is set for the device in the VRRP6 group.

You are advised to set the preemption delay to 0 on a backup device to allow it to preempt the master role immediately after the master device fails or set the preemption delay to a non-0 value on the master device so that it can preempt the master role after a specified delay if a master/backup VRRP6 switchover is performed.

�The interface on which a VRRP6 group is created and the interface on which DHCPv6 relay is configured must belong to the same main interface. Otherwise, VRRP6 cannot detect link faults on the DHCPv6 relay interface.

�In DHCPv6 relay dual-device hot standby scenarios, to ensure that the master device can completely back up user session information to the backup device, you are advised to set a preemption delay greater than or equal to 1800s for the master device.
8.Run vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-idprioritypriority-value
A priority is configured for the device in the VRRP6 group.

Before running this command to perform a master/backup VRRP6 switchover, ensure that the routing entries on the master and backup devices are the same. If they are different, user packet loss may occur.
9.(Optional) Run vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-idtimeradvertiseadvertise-interval
An interval for sending VRRP6 Advertisement packets is set.

The interval at which a device sends VRRP6 Advertisement packets cannot be less than the time that the device takes to perform a master/slave main control board switchover. If the interval is less than the switchover time, protocol flapping may occur during a master/slave main control board switchover. It is recommended that the interval be set to a value greater than 1s.
10.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
11.Run quit
Exit the interface view.
2.Configure an RBS.
1.Run remote-backup-serviceremote-backup-service-name
An RBS is created, and the RBS view is displayed.
2.(Optional) Run bind ssl-policyssl-policy-name
An SSL policy is bound to a TCP connection.
3.Run peerpeer-ip-addresssourcesource-ip-addressportport-id
TCP connection parameters are configured for the RBS.

source-ip-address and peer-ip-address specify the IP addresses of the master and backup devices, respectively. The IP addresses must have been configured on their own interfaces, sub-interfaces, or logical interfaces (such as loopback interfaces) and be able to ping each other.
port-id specifies a TCP port number. The TCP port numbers configured on the master and backup devices must be the same.
4.(Optional) Run batch-backupservice-typedhcpv6-relaynow
The DHCPv6 relay service configured in the RBS is immediately backed up.
5.(Optional) Run batch-backup service-type dhcpv6-relay dailydaytime
The DHCPv6 relay service configured in the RBS is backed up at a specified time on a daily basis.
6.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
7.Run quit
Exit the RBS view.
3.Configure an RBP.
1.Run remote-backup-profileprofile-name
An RBP is created, and the RBP view is displayed.
2.Run peer-backuphot
A backup mode is configured for user information backup.
3.Run vrrp6-idvridinterfaceinterface-typeinterface-number
The RBP is bound to a VRRP6 group.

vrid specifies the ID of a VRRP6 group. The ID must be the same as the VRRP6 group's ID that was configured using the vrrp6 vridvirtual-router-id [ virtual-ipvirtual-address ] command in the corresponding interface view.
4.Run backup-idbackup-idremote-backup-serviceservice-name
A backup ID is configured for the RBP, and the RBP is associated with a specified RBS.

backup-id specifies a backup ID for an RBP. You can use a backup ID and an RBS to determine an RBP. The backup IDs configured for the same RBP must be the same on the master and backup devices and can no longer be configured for other RBPs.
5.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
6.Run quit
Exit the RBP view.
4.Enable DHCPv6 relay remote backup.
1.Run remote-backup-profileprofile-name
The RBP view is displayed.
2.Run service-type dhcpv6-relay
DHCPv6 relay remote backup is enabled.
3.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
4.Run quit
Exit the RBP view.
5.Bind the RBP to an interface.
1.Run interfaceinterface-typeinterface-number [ .subinterface-number ]
The view of the DHCPv6 relay interface where DHCPv6 relay dual-device hot standby needs to be configured is displayed.
2.Run remote-backup-profileprofile-name
The RBP is bound to the DHCPv6 relay interface.
DHCPv6 relay must be configured on the interface to which the RBP is to be bound. Otherwise, DHCPv6 relay dual-device hot standby does not take effect.
3.(Optional) Run dhcpv6 relay pd-route degrade-costcost-value
A cost value is configured for PD routes generated by the backup device in the DHCPv6 relay dual-device hot standby scenario.
4.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
Configuring Transparent Transmission of PDUs on a VLL
1.Run system-view
The system view is displayed.
2.Run interface { interface-name | interface-type interface-number }
The sub-interface view is displayed
3.Run link-protocol transport { lacp | lldp | bpdu | cdp | udld } { untag | untag-vlan-check }
The types of Layer 2 protocols that the interface can transparently transmit are configured.
4.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
Configuring a PCE Client to Disable PPAG
column3: GMPLS Capability Negotiation in Open Messages

column1: 1.Run system-view
The system view is displayed.
2.Run pce-client
The PCE client view is displayed.
3.Run { ppag | | srpag | gmpls } negotiate disable
PPAG/SRPAG/GMPLS capability negotiation is disabled in PCEP Open messages.

To allow Huawei devices to communicate with non-Huawei devices that do not support PPAG/SRPAG/GMPLS-based PCEP negotiation or non-Huawei devices that support this function but deliver error packets, disable PPAG/SRPAG/GMPLS capability negotiation in Open messages.
�The ppag parameter indicates the PPAG function in MPLS TE.
�The srpag parameter indicates the SRPAG function in SR Policy.
�The gmpls parameter indicates the GMPLS function. For details about how to configure a GMPLS UNI, see GMPLS UNI Configuration.
4.Run commit
The configuration is committed.
